speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on December 11, 1991, the Prime Minister signed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child on behalf of all Canadians. Article 9:1 reads:
States Parties shall ensure that a child shall not be separated from his or her parents against their will, except when competent authorities subject to judicial review determine, in accordance with applicable law and procedures, that such separation is necessary for the best interest of the child.
As Canadians we all agree with the United Nations that the family is the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well-being of all its members, and particularly children.
I therefore urge members of this House to support my Motion No. 634 and petition to the Minister of Employment and Immigration and urge the minister to change his policy to allow spouses and children of refugees to be reunited in Canada as do the United States and France.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to express my support for the dairy, poultry, and egg farmers of Canada in their efforts to impress upon this government the extreme importance of protecting and strengthening article XI and preserving our supply management system.
There are approximately 700 farmers and farm families in Prince Edward Island who will be at risk. It is estimated that as many as 6,250 jobs in Atlantic Canada could be lost. If the farm quota restrictions are devalued, what will happen to the balance sheets and the net worth of our farmers?
No area will be harder hit than Prince Edward Island. Island farmers hold a greater proportion of the nation's butter fat quota.
Since Island farms tend to be smaller than the national average, the Prince Edward Island dairy industry will be more vulnerable to United States competition.
Supply management products play a proportionally larger part in the economy of Prince Edward Island. Supply management must be preserved.

Mr. Speaker, the Immigration and Refugee Board has done it again. Two Ahmadi brothers from Pakistan claimed religious persecution-identical cases, one was accepted, and one was rejected; two different tribunals and two difference decisions on the same evidence. Amnesty International reports:
Members of the minority Ahmadiyya community in Pakistan
continue to be charged and condemned to prison terms for the
peaceful exercise of their religious beliefs.
There is no consistency in the decisions of these IRB tribunals.
I therefore join with refugee coalition groups and the churches in calling for an independent inquiry into the decision-making process of the IRB, the increase of negative decisions, the use of prefabricated, fill-in-the-blanks prepared decisions on the negative, and the outrageous conduct of some members when hearing cases.

February 19, 1992
I also call on the minister to review the case of the 23-year old Ahmadi and allow him to remain in Canada, as is his authority to do, on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday I sat in this House in amazement, listening to a partisan New Democrat painting his party as the champion of medicare. His holier-than-thou rhetoric failed to mention that all first ministers of all political stripes and the Prime Minister agreed to discuss user fees at their meeting last week.
It was not until three days after the conference ended that the B.C. NDP took a stand on the issue, long after my leader and myself again stood in this House and challenged the first ministers.
Let it be known that the current Canada Health Act was introduced as a Liberal initiative in this Parliament in 1984.
It has since guaranteed that Canadians would not need to go first to the bank before they go to the hospital.
The message is clear. The federal government shall not be allowed to renege on its financial and moral commitment to the provinces to ensure the continued survival of medicare.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is with pleasure that I would like to draw the attention of the House to another Canadian athlete who won a medal in Albertville today.
I want to congratulate Myriam Bedard of Neufchatel, Quebec, who won a bronze medal in the women's 15-kilometre biathlon. She displayed all the technical skills and endurance required in this demanding Olympic sport. This is the first Winter Olympics in which women officially participate in the biathlon.
Canadians feel joy and pride over such an Olympic performance, which is also very motivating for all athletes in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, a recent edition of The Financial Times explained the circumstances of yet another plant closure.
Sit-Rite Products Ltd., a manufacturer of ergonomic office and industrial work place furnishings, closed a
48,000	square foot facility in Atlanta, Georgia, in order to expand its facility in Mississauga.
On the basis of consistent quality, delivery, and service performance, Sit-Rite management found that products out of the Mississauga plant were superior to those from Atlanta.
Though Canadian employees earned higher wages, other factors such as lower employee turnover rates, access to skilled tradespeople, and better supplier reliability favoured the Mississauga plant.
The benefits of Sit-Rite's consolidation efforts are showing as the company reported a 30 per cent improvement in sales in 1990 to approximately $15 million.
Who says Canada cannot compete?

Mr. Speaker, February is Black History Month in Nova Scotia.
This month has been set aside to recognize the outstanding contributions of black Nova Scotians, who have played a vital role in the history of my province since the early 17th century.
As a Nova Scotian, I take great pride in celebrating Black History Month, but I find this pride is overshadowed by the continued existence of hate literature.
Almost three months have passed since I asked the Minister of Justice to initiate investigations and, indeed, actions against the distribution of a racist piece of literature entitled Stop Apologizing.
Literature such as this only furthers the problems minority Canadians face on a day-to-day basis. Yet three full months later all the minister has done is write to me
February 19, 1992

to say the issue really is not her responsibility and maybe I should contact the Ontario Attorney General.
I find this non-action not only unacceptable but offensive. Each day the minister did not act was another day this deplorable hate literature sat on Canadian bookshelves.
As a sign of respect for Black History Month in Nova Scotia, I call on the Minister of Justice to take the necessary action today to stop passing the buck and to use the weight and influence of her office to stamp out this and other examples of bigotry and racism in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, on Monday I met farmers in my riding, in Lachute. Yesterday, the Prime Minister of Canada met Canadian farm leaders to reassure them about our position in GATT.
Except for Mr. Proulx, the president of the UPA in Quebec, they all said that they were very satisfied with this meeting and confident that the Canadian delegation, which leaves for Geneva tonight, will gamer significant support from the hundred other GATT member countries.
What was Mr. Proulx doing yesterday morning when he met the leader of the Bloc Quebecois several hours before his meeting with the Prime Minister? It is easy to understand that the strategy developed by these two leaders who are dedicated to Quebec separation is clear, and they especially do not want Canada to succeed and prevail on the subject of article XI.
Many farmers think that Mr. Proulx has no choice but to resign, and I agree with them, because he showed yesterday that his political interests take precedence over Quebec agriculture.

Mr. Speaker, a welcome is in order for the many Liberals who are in the national capital region for the Liberal convention.
But this welcome should also be accompanied by a warning to those actual and potential Liberals who are opposed to the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement or free trade with Mexico and want to see these agreements abrogated: You are at the wrong convention.
To those actual and potential Liberals who are opposed to the GST and proposing tax loopholes for the rich, you are at the wrong convention.
To those who wish to preserve medicare over and against the wishes of many Liberal premiers, you are at the wrong convention.
You are welcome to attend the next NDP convention where you will find a party that is not funded like the Liberal Party is, by the same people who fund the Tories.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a message for our farm producers in Quebec.
Yesterday, Jacques Proulx, president of the Union des producteurs agricoles, decided to support the policies of the leader of the Bloc Quebecois whom he had met that morning. Mr. Proulx decided that, to him, Quebec's separation was more important than what happens to all farm producers in Quebec.
I want to say to all our farm producers that, together with Canadian producers and with the support of Quebec's genuine farm producers, our national delegation will be leaving this evening for Geneva to support their cause. We are convinced that despite the withdrawal of Jacques Proulx all farm producers are with us all the way.

February 19, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Department of National Health and Welfare continues to disregard the perils to the health of Canadians.
For the fourth time, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has disallowed MMT as an additive in American fuel. Studies have indicated it causes an increase in hydrocarbon emissions.
A main component of MMT, manganese, has also been linked to such disorders as Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease.
MMT has been added to Canadian gasoline since the early 1970s. If the government were serious about protecting our environment and removing risks to our health, it would take immediate steps to ban the use of this additive in Canada.
There is a clean and readily available alternative. Ethanol could be used, significantly reducing the damage to our environment and potentially to our health.
At the same time Canadian farmers could sell their grain for the production of this clean burning and safe additive.
When will this government act to support Canadian farmers and consumers?

Mr. Speaker, I want to take this opportunity to express my complete disapproval of the attitude of the president of the UPA of Quebec. Mr. Proulx, after a meeting attended by our Prime Minister, decided not to join the Canadian delegation that is going to Europe to defend our agricultural policies.
All this makes me wonder about his sincerity, since it seems to me that as a leader he should be on the firing line to defend his troops. That firing line happens to be in Europe at the present time. I fail to understand why, and I am also very sorry that a constituent from my riding
who is also president of the UPA has refused to join this delegation.
The game is not over until it is over. The third man at bat still has a chance to hit a home run. I therefore urge UPA delegates to call their president and insist that he go to Europe.

Mr. Speaker, I was glad to read in the Toronto Star the other day that the member for LaSalle-Emard supports funding for the retraining of unemployed workers, eliminating violence against women, and cleaning up the environment.
That is exactly what this government has been doing in that $1.8 billion has been earmarked for retraining unemployed workers.
In partnership with industry and local school-boards we kick-started Skills Canada which emphasizes skills training at the high school level. As promised in the throne speech, a non-partisan panel of women is working to find ways of eliminating violence against women.
Since its inception, the green plan has been increasingly effective in helping Canadians feel they can make a difference in helping to clean up their environment, as well as attacking environmental problems at the industrial level.
If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, I think this government should feel flattered by the hon. member for LaSalle-Emard.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday we heard that Dominion Textiles was closing its plant in Valleyfield, Quebec. This means a loss of 225 jobs in a region where the unemployment rate is already 15 per cent. Thirty jobs were also lost in Montreal. This marks the end of the textile industry in the region. Furthermore, Bell Helicopter has announced 80 lay-offs at Mirabel. In Quebec, the unemployment
February 19, 1992

rate is now 13 per cent. Is that supposed to be cost-effective federalism?
Quebec's unemployment rate has always been higher than the Canadian average due to federal policies that tend to overlook Quebec in terms of industrial investment and research and development. The government's next budget will do nothing for Quebec. This government is ignoring millions of Quebecers who are unemployed or living on welfare. Quebec has no choice but to go its own way.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
Yesterday the Minister of Finance said that his budget will take into consideration the realities of the day. The reality today is that 1.5 million Canadians are unemployed. The reality today is that 2.5 million Canadians are on welfare. The reality today is that Canadians are suffering. They are desperate.
My question to the Prime Minister is this: Does his government's definition of reality take into account the human suffering? Does his definition of reality take into consideration that millions of Canadians do not know how they are going to pay the rent or do not know how they are going to pay the mortgage? They do not know how they are going to feed their kids.
How does the Prime Minister propose to alleviate the fear, the pain, and the suffering, the problems and the reality today?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance announced yesterday that next Tuesday, February 25, at 4.30 p.m. he will be delivering his realistic budget. I would suggest that between now and then the opposition and many of the media will be writing that budget for him, but I would ask them to have patience till next Tuesday afternoon when the Minister of Finance will bring down what I believe will be a budget that will be widely supported by Canadians.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is again for the Prime Minister.
The casualties of this government's economic policies are mounting and all the Prime Minister can offer Canadians in terms of an economic plan is more of the same. This government's policies are laying waste to our industrial capability, especially in southwestern Ontario. The human costs are staggering: 3,600 jobs lost at Ford, 3,600 jobs at Imperial Oil, 2,000 at IBM, 1,450 at Dofasco, 1,300 at Dylex, and the list goes on and on and on.
Why are the Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance not prepared to employ creative solutions to immediately kick-start the Canadian economy? Canadians cannot wait until next year. They cannot wait until next month. They need help and they need it today. That is the reality of today.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think we should draw to the attention of the House that most of the statistics that the hon. member rhymed off today are companies that are making these adjustments, not only in Canada but around the world. This is a restructuring that is going on today in the world. This is the realistic structure that we have to face here in Canada. As a matter of fact, there is a report out today from the Royal Bank of Canada which says that Canada has been behind in keeping up with what is going in the world today in the restructuring and that we have some catching up to do.
I want to quote from that report. The report applauded federal government efforts to control inflation, curtail spending, and reduce budget deficits. Some of its recommendations are to remove national and interprovincial trade and investment barriers. That is exactly what this government is doing.

Mr. Speaker, my third question is directed to the Prime Minister, and I hope he will reply.
In the province of Quebec, 400,000 people are unemployed and 650,000 people are on welfare. Last year 10 per cent of Quebec's forestry workers lost their jobs.

February 19, 1992
Oral Questions
My question to the Prime Minister is this: What kind of realistic solutions does the Prime Minister intend to include in next Tuesday's budget to give Quebec's economy a boost and put Quebec's workers back to work?

Mr. Speaker, I will tell you what we will not do. We will not pursue policies at the national level that would have the effect of raising interest rates to 21.75 per cent, where they were when my hon. friend's party was in power. Yes, 21.75, while today interest rates are around 7.5 per cent.
This morning the inflation rate was at 3.8 per cent, but when my hon. friend was in power it was 12.9 per cent. I agree the unemployment rate is too high and we are trying to get it down, but today it is 10.4 per cent and when the Liberals were in power it was 12.8 per cent.
I can assure you that we will pursue policies but not yours.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
Statistics Canada reports that Canadian families are paying far more of their wages in personal income taxes than they did in 1986. Since then this government has chosen to shift the tax burden away from corporations and onto the backs of ordinary children. The personal share of tax revenue has risen 11 per cent, while the corporate share has dropped by nearly 14 per cent.
When will the Prime Minister admit that his government is engineering a massive transfer of wealth from ordinary workers to the shareholders of large corporations?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
No, that is not true at all, and I think the facts point that out. Our tax rates in Canada for corporations and small businesses must be comparable to those of our competitors. We cannot tax our industries and our businesses a higher rate than our competitors or we will lose all our businesses in this country, so that is not accurate.
As far as increases in taxes are concerned, there has been some increase in income taxes in this country. I
must remind the hon. member that it was done in a period of time when there was tremendous growth in this country, when house prices where rising at 15 to 20 per cent a year, income taxes at 2.5 per cent a year, and salaries were increasing at 6 and 7 per cent a year. Compared with the other prices that were increasing in our economy, the income taxes rose at a very low rate. I might add that most of the savings, over two-thirds, that we have realized in this government has come from cost cutting.

The minister's words are small comfort to the families that are struggling to make ends meet. This government's big business, small grocery basket agenda is particularly appreciated by foreign shareholders. While Canadian families were hit with stiffer tax bills, foreign shareholders made off with 38 per cent more interest and dividends in 1990 than in 1989, double the increase I might add that Canadian shareholders were able to bring home from abroad. When will the minister put an end to his government's policy of exporting Canadian jobs and wealth?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is saying that people have invested here in Canada, that they are creating employment here in Canada and jobs for Canadians, that they are realizing a return on their investment and they should not have that. This country needs foreign investment if we are to grow and expand. I am not sure what the hon. member is getting at, but if the policy of the Liberal Party is no more foreign investment, let her say so.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. The finance minister spoke yesterday of a realistic budget. The reality for 1.5 million Canadians is that they have no jobs and their families have little hope. The reality is that we have an income tax system which lets the wealthy off the hook. It favours wealthy Canadians. The reality is that this government would rather close hospital beds than close tax loopholes. The reality is that unemployment in this country is costing Canadians $30 billion a year.
February 19, 1992

I want to ask the Prime Minister this: By " realistic", does his government mean that it will bring in a budget that will create jobs for Canadians or just do more of the same that has put Canadians out of work?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has raised a very legitimate point, one that concerns us all, namely unemployment and how we can get it down. In the first term we brought it down from 11.7 down to 7.3. It is up to 10.4 and we hope to bring it down again by following programs that will reduce interest rates, keep inflation down, and invite foreign investment to join with national investment to create new and productive and durable jobs. I am surprised at the rhetoric of my hon. friend. All of her prefatory remarks are gratuitous and quite offensive because they bear no resemblance to any degree of reality.
I would have thought that since the NDP presented its last budget last May in Ontario my hon. friend would have realized how difficult it is for an NDP government or any government to bring in a budget.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians are looking for a government that cares about them. Canadians are looking for a government that understands what unemployment means to Canadian families, is willing to look at it seriously and do something about it.
One thing that can be done is to look at our tax system. Statistics Canada shows that between 1982 and 1990 under both Liberal and Conservative governments the income taxes of lowest income Canadians have gone up 600 per cent. That is six times the increase incurred by the wealthiest Canadians. This does not count the GST and other sales taxes.
My question to the Prime Minister is this: Is this a realistic tax policy? Is the Prime Minister prepared for his government to bring in a realistic tax policy? Will he make the tax system fairer so that everyone pays their fair share?

Mr. Speaker, I think it is generally recognized that any tax system can be improved and successive governments seek to do that. One of the facts is that the Minister for International Trade, in his previous incarnation as Minis-
Oral Questions
ter of Finance, closed more tax loopholes for the wealthy than any Minister of Finance in Canada's recent history. He did an excellent job of closing these unfair loopholes.
My hon. friend says, in regard to this: do something about it. Her position is always the same. When asked and pressed what do something about it means, her view of doing something about it was to spend more borrowed money. That we will not do. We have a policy of bringing down interest rates, of bringing down the inflation rate to just about a 20-year low, and of creating in the process new, durable and competitive jobs. That is a little less glamorous and a little more difficult than spending borrowed money, our children's and grandchildren's money, and throwing it at the problem.
We will not do that. We are on a course that will restore Canada to a sensible degree of economic growth and durable prosperity.

Mr. Speaker, it will come with great astonishment to the Canadian people that a government that doubled the deficit during its term can lecture Canadian people on how to manage the economy.

I have a suggestion for the Prime Minister that could save him $2 billion. Will he just cancel the capital gains exemptions? In that way, he would no longer need to cut back his programs. Will he cancel the capital gains exemptions and thus recover $2 billion in taxes?

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance will announce his intentions on tax measures on Tuesday night. That is the tradition and we will respect tradition.
Second, and I quote, the New Democratic leader just said: that the government doubled its deficit during its term. It is an absolute falsehood. The deficit went from $38.9 billion down to $31.5 billion. That was false.
Now my hon. friends are yelling they made a mistake; they are talking about the debt. The debt did indeed increase from $206 billion to $420 billion, every nickel of which was compound interest on the debt we inherited from the Liberals, every single one.

February 19, 1992
Oral Questions FISHERIES

Mr. Speaker, this government has agreed in 1992 to give fish quotas inside our 200-mile zone to Cuba, Japan, Norway, Poland, and Russia for redfish, witch, capelin, and squid. In fact the Russians have been allocated a quota of 1,600 tonnes of cod in a zone 50 miles east of the riding of the minister of fisheries.
Will the government now cancel all of these foreign quotas inside the 200-mile zone? We need the fish. Are we going to tell our own people to sit at home while they watch as these licences are issued to foreign nations that have quotas inside our 200-mile zone?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as always, we need to listen carefully to each word of the hon. gentleman so that we can understand what facts are being obscured.
The situation is that NAFO paid international quotas to the U.S.S.R., Cuba, and other places mentioned for
1992.	We can, if we wish, agree to them fishing for some of these quotas inside our 200-mile limit. We usually do agree with respect to the former U.S.S.R. and Cuba because they are firm supporters of ours in NAFO in establishing quotas and observing the moratorium on cod catches outside 200 miles in 2J-3K-L. But, if we allow them to fish inside our 200-mile limit to catch these international quotas of redfish, witch, or whatever then they pay us licence fees in the thousands of dollars. They also have our observers onboard so we know exactly what they are doing and control exactly what we are doing.
This is a very intelligent application of policy by Canada to regulate the fishery. The hon. gentleman should be celebrating it, not attempting to denigrate it in this House.

Mr. Speaker, those are the quotas for foreign nations inside our 200-mile zone.
This year the government, against the advice of eveiy scientist in this country, in Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, and Ottawa in the federal Department of Fisheries and Oceans, has agreed to the reopening of the cod fishery
on one of the chief spawning grounds outside the 200-mile zone, on the Flemish Cap where there has been a moratorium for years on the fishing of cod.
Why did this government decide to reopen the fishery in 1991 with quotas for 1992 to the EEC, Denmark, Russia, Norway, Poland, Cuba, 12,800 tonnes, and Canada, 100 tonnes? Why is this government party to the destruction of this major cod spawning ground?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let us just examine again what the hon. gentleman is proposing.
This is the Flemish Cap which is well outside the 200-mile limit and it is a fishery that is governed by the NAFO, the international organization.
At one time there was a moratorium in connection with the catching of cod on the Flemish Cap. Canada does not have a cod fishery there. That is why our quota is so small, 100 tonnes, and no one bothers to catch it.
Denmark and Norway, two of our staunch supporters in NAFO, asked in 1990 that the moratorium be lifted because certain countries were cheating and not observing it. They who depend upon this particular area and the fish there thought it was better to have no moratorium than to have a moratorium that was not being observed by countries such as Spain and Portugal.
We supported it. We abstained from voting. In return, Denmark, Norway and other countries supported us in our bid to get aerial surveillance accepted for surveillance enforcement outside 200 miles. They supported us in getting the hail system instituted. That is why we abstained.
The hon. gentleman should be able to see, if he cares, how sensible this is. We have to co-operate with other countries if we want them to co-operate with us, which is exactly what they did and we did. There are certain countries that are not co-operating, but not the ones gaining by our abstaining in that moratorium.

Mr. Speaker, co-operation is a two-way street, and so far Canada has not seen much co-operation from the nations that have overfished our waters.
February 19, 1992

The senior scientific adviser to the minister of fisheries has told the minister, and indeed has told members on this side of the House, that the collapse of the northern cod stock is so severe that a period of up to five years of deep quota cuts, deep restrictions on the right of Canadian fishermen to fish in their own waters, may be required to allow those now fragile cod stocks to rebuild, to regenerate to a healthy and stable level.
I want to ask the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans: Why should one pound of fish be taken in Canadian waters by foreign vessels during the next five years when Canadian vessels and Canadian fishermen must tie up and stay at home?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that certainly sounds veiy patriotic and sensible until one examines it again.
First, the northern cod stock is not in as bad a state as the hon. gentleman suggests. In December the scientists advised me that the biomass was 1,130,000 tonnes. Seven weeks later they revised it downward to 780,000 tonnes. That is the difficulty we are dealing with. As they say, their scientific calculation of stock could be 25 per cent off one way or the other. That is what creates the difficulty in management.
With respect to foreign vessels, they are not allowed to fish inside our 200-mile zone for any fish or any stock that Canadians are interested in. If they fish inside then it is because we are observing the Law of the Sea convention or they are catching fish for Canadians to be processed on shore.
Does the hon. gentleman want to close Canso? Does he want to close Burgeo? Does he want to close dozens of other plants that get fish landed by foreign vessels because we do not have the technology and vessels to land the stocks at those particular plants? Is he out to do Canso and Burgeo in?
Finally, with respect to our campaign, the ambassador from South Korea was in to see me today and South Korea has already agreed to withdraw a vessel from this fishing area this year and another one in the first half of next year to start the process of withdrawing its operations in the northwest Atlantic. That is the effect of our efforts, the Prime Minister's efforts, and the efforts of
Oral Questions
the Minister for International Trade. That is the kind of effect we are having. We are getting some progress.

Mr. Speaker, the minister of fisheries has asked if we want to close Canso, if we want to close Burgeo, if we want to close Canadian fish plants and shut down Canadian vessels. No, we do not. We want to close the 200-mile limit to foreign exploitation and overfishing. We want this minister to show some backbone and some guts and understand that the fishery of Atlantic Canada is not a little regional issue; it is a national issue, a matter of national pride and national interest. It is time this government stood up for the people of Atlantic Canada.
I ask Canada's Prime Minister, the Prime Minister of all of Canada: Will he now stand up for those Canadians who have been abandoned by his minister in the region of Atlantic Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when we listen to this effusion what does it all come down to? It comes down to zilch.
While the hon. gentleman is effusing, what are we doing to help the situation? We have approved 575 projects in fisheries alternatives, $41.9 million in assistance, and 1,547 new jobs in alternatives to the fishery. In alternatives, $19 million was spent to create jobs outside the fishery. We helped Canso and Burgeo to reopen. Grand Bank is reopening this February with 225 jobs because of our assistance, and on and on I could go.
That is the kind of quiet, effective work we are doing when all we hear is false hysteria and play-acting by hon. gentlemen opposite.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister or the Minister for International Trade.
Yesterday we heard the Prime Minister addressing farm groups, reiterating what some of his agriculture ministers have been saying, namely that Canada has presented a balanced approach at the GATT negoti-

February 19, 1992
Oral Questions
ations. It has attempted to protect supply management by working for a clarified and strengthened article XI.
Canada's initial presentation to the negotiating group on agriculture, presented October 20, 1987, outlined our definitive stance on agricultural negotiations. Given that it did not mention anything about article XI, could the minister or the Prime Minister tell us at what point that became part of the official negotiations? When did we enter a strengthened and clarified article XI into the negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend is very well aware-I cannot tell him precisely when that happened; I was not in the portfolio at the time-of the strong position that this government has taken for some period of time, led by the Prime Minister, in support of the supply managed sector and in support of strengthening and clarifying article XI.
This has consistently been a part of our negotiating position and it is why my colleagues and I, along with farm leaders, will be leaving this afternoon to visit Bonn, Brussels, and Geneva in support of that position.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question.
Along with farmers, I have believed that this was our negotiating position because this is what I heard in the House and throughout Canada, but I cannot find any evidence that that was the position in the negotiations.
When did we present in writing a position that clarified what it was we were looking for? It does not show up in the documents. When did we do this and what documentation can we be provided with?

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am sure the hon. member is looking for answers in a realistic way.
The reason he has had some difficulty looking back in 1986 is that the position Canada has been continually presenting since we laid documents in 1990 in front of the GATT negotiating council has been the position for clarification and strengthening of article XI. The position was developed with the industry in light of other findings that article XI was not going to be able to give
them the supply and the border control to continue supply management.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister ought to be aware that last year the Government of Canada issued 100 factory freezer trawler licences to foreign nations to fish within Canada's 200-mile limit.
The Prime Minister ought to know, as I am sure the minister of fisheries knows, each of those particular licences represents a floating fish plant.
I want to ask the Prime Minister if he would explain to people in my district and throughout the rest of Atlantic Canada the fairness of asking Canadians to stop fishing in their own waters and, on the other hand, allowing foreign nations to fish at will.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is simply another misstatement of the situation.
There is no foreign fishing vessel permitted to fish within the Canadian 200-mile economic zone unless all Canadians who are interested in the fishery or even not interested in the fishery have had a chance first to say they want the fish stocks or indicated they do not want the fish.
If we have stocks that are surplus and cannot use, such as the grenadier and others it is not economic for us to fish, then foreign countries have to be offered the opportunity to catch them. We offer that opportunity to countries that support us in NAFO, that play the game in conservation, that support us when we need their support, like the former U.S.S.R., Cuba and so on.
We do not offer them to any other country that is out there despoiling fish stocks like Spain and Portugal. We allow foreign vessels in if Canadians beg and plead with us to do it for the over the side sales. The fishermen can sell the fish they cannot otherwise sell. We also allow them in if Canadian processing plants need them to catch fish that we cannot catch and land them at Canadian plants where Canadian workers process them. They are the only things keeping Canso going and Burgeo going.
