The House resumed, from Tuesday, February 18, consideration of the motion of Mr. Mazankowski that Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee E.

Madam Speaker, I welcome this opportunity today to speak to Bill C-56. With this legislation the federal government intends to control government expenditures. The bill arises from the conclusions of a federal finance committee which in 1991 decided there should be some control of government spending.
I rise in the House today to speak to this bill because it is an absurd piece of legislation. After looking at this government bill, it becomes clear that the government does not really intend to control its spending. That is a serious matter because today spending is out of control. We are faced with a total debt of more than $420 billion, more than twice what our debt was when the Tory government came to power in 1984.
The bill proposes to set a 3 per cent spending limit on government expenditures. However, and this is the absurd part, if they fail to keep a 3 per cent limit on spending they will try to save on other items. If the minister decides for some reason to spend 15 per cent more than last year, which means 12 per cent more than would be allowed under this bill, the government can go to another department and make enough cuts in its programs to make up the difference. The problem is that there is no way to check whether the government actually made the cuts in other areas, which would justify proposed increases in another department. What we have here is an elaborate smoke screen, because there is no way of knowing how much the government has cut back on its spending.
There is another major drawback to this bill. Let us say that two years ago the government increased spending in certain departments by 15 per cent-as in my former example-to recover the difference of 12 per cent. There is a spending limit of 3 per cent per year, which means the government may spend up to 3 per cent but not more. Two years ago when the government was looking for ways to cut spending it adjusted its budget to correct the 12 per cent overspending. This is incredible! And we cannot check what the government did to make up the difference over a period of two years. It will be extremely difficult and extremely complicated, and I think it will be impossible to verify.
February 19, 1992

Now this government may be incompetent, and it may have betrayed its sacred trust, but it certainly is not stupid. This is a very smart bill. It can camouflage all kinds of expenditures and even provide for all kinds of spending up till the next election, because if we are talking about two years, it means that two years from now. In fact, we know perfectly well the government will call an election a year and a half from now, at the latest.
This bill is an excellent opportunity for the government to spend money left and right, to give political handouts, and to create other Hibernias with the billions of dollars it will spend in it attempt to buy another election.
Although Bill C-56 seems intended to control spending, the real story is quite different. The government is not really trying to control spending; it is mostly trying to hide what it spends until the next election, so that it can buy the next election. I can tell you that will not work because the people, the voters, know that it is a sham, that this government is unable to cut its spending. That is clear.
We can talk about cuts the government has made to date, but do not look for statistics or figures. Thke the presentation made to the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee by the Quebec City Chamber of Commerce, which talked about the federal government wasting $15 billion a year because of overlapping provincial and federal jurisdiction. Fifteen billion a year, Madam Speaker, is a lot of money. This bill does not deal with that at all.
Neither does this bill deal with the GST. I must tell you that 96 per cent of the population oppose the GST, and rightly so. Why? Because it is a bad tax at the wrong time. It is not visible, despite what the federal government promised us. It is a hidden tax. Worse than that, as the late journalist Marjorie Nichols wrote in an excellent report in which she had all the figures on the GST, this tax produced about $18 or $19 billion. She said that was not right because it cost between $18 and $19 billion to set up and administer this whole system. In other words, they spent $18 or $19 billion to make $18 or $19 billion. We were no further ahead than before the GST came into effect. [DOT]
Madam Speaker, I can tell you right away about five consequences of this GST First, the price of consumer
Government Orders
goods has risen about 2.6 per cent. Retail sales for all retailers, small and large, are off from 5.3 to 5.6 per cent in Canada. Exports to the United States have declined by
2.9	per cent while imports to Canada have increased 5 per cent. The icing on the cake, Madam Speaker, is that Canadians, frustrated with the GST, do up to 10 per cent of their shopping for consumer goods across the border. That amounts to nearly $2.5 billion a year.
Madam Speaker, the government is not serious with this Bill C-56. We urgently need to cut the GST now. The federal government should also cut its spending because people in Quebec and elsewhere are fed up with seeing you throw money out the window.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted to join this debate on Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures.
Immediately, even with the title of the bill, we can see an admission on the part of this government that it has been unable to manage our fiscal and monetary policies. It is clear that this bill-excuse me, Madam Speaker.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I apologize if the hon. member was disturbed. I was simply trying to answer a question which was asked by another member and I was using my fingers. I apologize and I will make sure that the time is added at the end of the hon. member's interruption.

Thank you, Madam Speaker.
As I was saying, this bill is an admission of guilt on the part of this government that over the last few years it has failed to govern, that it has failed Canadians. Why do we say that? If we start from the document, the proposed spending control act, produced by the Standing Committee on Finance last November, a committee of this House that was controlled by the majority government members, we notice immediately that even in this proposed bill, some of the excellent recommendations, and I will only mention two, that the committee proposed are not included. I refer to the definition of emergency, for example. The use of this provision must be clarified and must be subject to parliamentary approval. Without that clarification and clear delineation, I question the forthrightness of this government.

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
Moreover, a second proposal by this committee, that a strict definition of good management initiatives should be included in this proposed act, is missing from this piece of legislation.
Right from the beginning I questioned the forthrightness of this government and why this bill was being introduced. Page 5 of the bill, clause 4(1) states:
The President of the Treasury Board may certify that a proposed
increase in the expenditures for a specific program for a controlled
fiscal year is justified by reason of good management-
Does that mean that the budget may be spent even if it does not fulfil good management? Does it mean that good management ought to be a criterion only when we have to increase the expenditure over the controlled fiscal proposal that is being made in this bill?
Let me tell you why there is a basis to believe that. Good management is not the intent of this government. I will cite a few of the facts and figures available to me at this point. From 1984 to 1990, according to the Auditor General's report, about $23 billion has been mismanaged and wasted by this government.
Let me cite a few recent examples. In 1988 a payment to a shipbuilder in advance of need resulted in the shipbuilder investing in certain securities for a loss of $4.25 million in interest payments and an estimated further loss of $1.8 million by the time of completion.
Second, in the same year it took Revenue Canada until May 27 to deposit all taxes paid, resulting in a loss of $3.4 million. This was improved later but by no means corrected.
Third, $14.3 million was spent for a bypass highway and $2.1 million was spent between 1985 and 1987 to build two bridges unrelated to offshore oil and gas and not yet connected to any road.
The International Centre for Human Rights, which is an institution I support, was established in September 1988. A cheque for $1 million was paid to the centre even though there was no one available to receive it since no employees had been hired as of July 31, 1989.
In 1990, CIDA provided $2.3 million to finance a coal washing plant in Pakistan which had achieved less than 1 per cent of capacity over 10 years. No feasibility study was completed when the project was approved.
We would like to fund useful projects. We would like to fund good initiatives, but it has to be done through proper and good management. Since 1984 who has had control over government expenditures? The answer is clear: this government. Who has doubled the national debt? The answer is clear: this government.
When you look at this so-called spending control bill, it is clear that this is a sham, a cosmetic make-up, and a camouflage, to say the least. Really, what is at issue here is not to stop spending arbitrarily but to institute good management and avoid waste and extravagance.
Earlier today in this House we heard of the many realities facing Canadians. We have 1.6 million Canadians unemployed and there are no jobs to be found. We have over 2 million on welfare and they want to work. We have seniors who remain unemployed and poor, as indicated recently by the Canadian Human Rights Commission. That is a reality.
We also have the reality that over the last many years under this government taxes have been increased several hundredfold. We also have the reality that the middle class has continued to be squeezed.
Of course I have alluded to the reality of waste, mismanagement and the scandals of this government. We have equally one reality and it is that this government has cut essential, not frivolous, cash transfer payments to the provinces. They are essential because these are payments for education of our youth and for the health of all Canadians.
Madam Speaker, if you can tell me that this government can justify letting Canadians be ill and unattended under the so-called umbrella of controlled spending, that we will not invest in our youth because we have to control spending, then I tell this government that it does not know how to manage. My leader has indicated five principles that will guide the future Liberal government. We would ensure a truly fiscally responsible government that will create an industrial strength for Canada, ensure a fair tax system, develop comprehensive and creative adjustment policies, and thereby ensure a balanced economic growth. When that happens, we can assure Canadians we will restore Canada's national purpose, to serve Canadians.
February 19, 1992

I believe, and I am sure you and the government will believe with me, that Canadians would rather be working than on welfare. They would rather be paid for jobs than handed unemployment insurance cheques. They would rather be able to buy clothes for their children and bread for the table than succumb to deprivation and hunger. They would rather pay their utility bills, rents, and mortgages than be frozen in their homes or evicted from them. The issue before us is not this bill, camouflaged with cosmetic make-up in preparation for an election, telling Canadians that this government wants to be serious. It has never been serious at all.
What we need is sound public policy and that means the government must exercise discretion and not delude Canadians as to its purpose. It must be sensitive to the needs of Canadians and not create a sham experiment with this bill. It must be caring and not arbitrarily control expenditures. This bill hides incompetence, extravagance, and insensitivity on the part of this government, and is an, attempt once more to delude Canadians. I say that Canadians have learned. In conclusion, I would not like this government to find an excuse to renege on its moral and financial commitment to the provinces and to Canadians with this bill.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to take part in this debate on the motion by the Minister of Finance for second reading and referral to Legislative Committee E of Bill C-56, the Spending Control Act.
I must tell you that I have trouble understanding all the reasoning behind such a bill. Until today I thought that the government had full authority to run the country using the budget, the budget estimates, and all the other means at its disposal to reduce and control spending. I wonder why such a bill is necessary, especially at this time.
Canadians are cynical about politicians, and I think that the debate in this House on this bill at this time is something of a joke. I think that the time has come for
Government Orders
the government, if it is serious and responsible, to present the nation's financial situation to the people. We must change our accounting rules. The Income Tkx Act requires all Canadians to report their financial activities to the government on an accrual basis, but the government continues to run the country on a cash basis; that is, it subtracts expenditures from receipts to come up with a deficit that is added to the total debt. We do not have a balance sheet showing our assets and liabilities. As soon as a project is financed and paid for, it is shown as an expense in that year. Once the project is complete we do not have a record of costs to show exactly what major capital projects the government has carried out across the country, for example airports or any other large-scale capital project.
If we had a better perception, a balance sheet of all these activities, I think it would be easier for Canadians to understand what the government does with the money it collects in taxes and perhaps there would be a better understanding of our situation, because Canadians are very concerned now about the deficit, about the debt that has doubled in seven years. They wonder how this can be, since taxes have increased enormously at the same time. This morning we read in the papers about the result of a study showing that between 1986 and 1990, taxes on family income rose by more than 4 per cent, which is huge. Every weekend when we go to our ridings, Canadians tell us enough is enough. They have had it. They do not want to be taxed any more.
I do not know what is in the budget that will be tabled next week. The Minister of Finance knows and will tell us on February 25. But I think it is time to have a responsible accounting system so that we can report to our people who pay the taxes and they can know what is done with their money. Maybe all together-governments, elected officials, public servants-we could be more accountable to the citizenry in a way that every year they would have a realistic statement of the situation that they could understand.
I remember the previous Parliament from 1984 to 1988. At one point the Minister of Finance was not able to meet his deficit target. To increase his revenues, he announced to us in early January that deductions at

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
source which were paid once a month, before the 15th of the following month, would from then on have to be paid twice a month. This enabled him to receive two more deductions at source by the end of the fiscal year on March 31 and he thus came up with $2 billion more to meet his budget forecasts. In actual fact nothing changed because the $2 billion gained in that fiscal year did not appear in the next fiscal year. All he did was shift the amount around.
We have the same problem with the freeze that the government has imposed on all departments, ministers, agencies, and Crown corporations until March 31 on account of the deficit. In most cases, the expense will be postponed until April 1. That is not how we should administer our affairs. I wonder why a government would need a bill to control its spending. Why? It is as if I went to see a lawyer or a notary to draw up a contract stipulating that I could not spend more than $100 a week. Why would I need such a contract? This shows that Canadians have reason to be cynical about us. The government has the power; of course it can cut spending. It is the government's prerogative. If it cannot do it, it should let someone else take over.
I remember that the former Auditor General worked with the Auditor General of the United States on a proposed financial statement to change the system, that is, the way we report to the people on the activities of the Government of Canada. That was in 1985, when I was a member of the public accounts committee. With the Auditor General of Canada, we even met the Auditor General of the United States when we went to Washington to discuss the system. It is now 1992, and nothing has changed. The government has tabled a bill which I think is useless, so useless that it is hard to find reasons why I will vote against the bill. It is a big nothing, a bill that should never have been tabled. How can anyone vote in favour of a bill that does not do a thing? Today I think we are wasting our time and taxpayers' money by debating a government bill to legislate spending limits.
I see here in the House the former President of the Treasury Board. He had the power, and his successor has the power now, to cut spending. They do not need a bill to control expenditures. What they need is the political will and the courage to do so. What is the point of this
bill? It will just encourage Canadians to be even more cynical about politicians, because we are wasting time trying to give the impression we want to control spending. We do not need this bill.
I am sorry to say so, but the government is incompetent. I see the Minister of Immigration who is laughing. It was his department, Madam Speaker, that appointed commissioners-I am not sure of their exact title-to control refugee claims. They earn a salary of about $92,000, and to do what? We could have dealt with these problems differently. It would have cost very little and we would have this tremendous backlog of people who have been waiting for two or three years and meanwhile have started a family here and are obliged. Today we have people who do not know from one day to the next whether they will have to go back to their country of origin or will be allowed to remain in Canada.
We should not spend time debating a bill that will not solve a thing. After all the government has the power, as it did before and will have in the future, to spend or not to spend. It just takes enough political will to decide. I hope the minister of immigration will be able to help reduce spending and will look at the whole refugee system, because despite the millions of dollars that have been spent we still have the same problem we had in 1985-86 when the legislation was passed.
Madam Speaker, you are signalling that my time is up. I wish to thank you for your patience.

Madam Speaker, I would just like to participate for a few minutes in the closing portions of this part of the House's consideration of this bill.
The bill deals with the government's proposals for so-called ceilings and restraints on government spending.
I would like to suggest, as others have done, that the bill is simply window-dressing. It is government electioneering a year and one-half ahead of a likely election.
The bill does not come to the heart of the problem. I would like to illustrate that by looking at two points.
Clearly the issue of government spending is an important one for all Canadians who pay taxes. We want to see that our taxes are well spent and efficiently spent.
February 19, 1992

Therefore, the government needs constantly to be managing the Public Service and the government services as efficiently and effectively as it can.
To that extent there exists Treasury Board, Auditor General, and committees of Parliament designed to keep an eye on public spending.
My own personal experience is that in many respects most government departments operate veiy efficiently and very well.
Clearly, in anything the size of the federal government, there is room for improvement and there constantly can be more. This bill really does not address that issue. It is window-dressing.
The bill fails to address the real problem in terms of the government's pushing of public spending as an issue in its response to the Reform Party agenda on this issue.
Government spending should properly be understood in most cases to be spending on needed public services. The issue of so-called overspending by government is invariably a right-wing Conservative agenda designed to reduce, as far as possible, the public sector in this country at the expense of the private sector. We have seen over and over again, in terms of tax policy, how successive Liberal and Conservative governments have begun the shift from the corporate sector to individuals, to lighten the burden on those who can most afford to pay and pass the burden on to those who cannot. They also do it by constantly cutting back on public services of various kinds. They once said you do not need a bake sale to buy a tank or a submarine. But you do have to have bake sales for so many public services in this country. It is a question of priorities, and this government and its predecessor Liberal government, have constantly given the social sector in this country the most difficult time squeezing out any kind of money at all for very needed social services, often at the long-run expense to the public treasury.
Over and over again those who look at the issue of crime prevention have come up with the point that if money was spent at the beginning to prevent crime you would not have to spend so much on penitentiaries. That same analogy could be used on all kinds of public expenditures in this country.
Government Orders
As the public considers this bill it is important for it to understand the underlying hypocrisy of the government's position in suggesting that it is promoting control of public spending, when in fact over and over again it fails to put a reasonable priority on public spending and to rein in unnecessary and valueless private spending.
In the debate we constantly hear the attack on public spending and yet if we look at over-spending around our society, we see that over and over again there is unnecessary private consumption compared to the requirements of so many in our country and around the world.
Let me complete my contribution by focusing the House's attention on one other area. This government and its predecessors have failed to challenge the very assumptions of their own policies. While the government looks in the comer to try to save a nickel, it is still spending billions of dollars over here without challenging the assumptions of that spending. I refer in particular to spending in the area of defence.
For over 40 years both the Liberal and Conservative governments of Canada have spent billions and billions of Canadian taxpayers' dollars in maintaining forces in Europe. Now in the early days those expenditures were entirely necessary and valuable and were supported on all sides of the House. But as early as the sixties the government and the defence people had come to the conclusion that spending was no longer necessary for military or defence purposes. It is now well recorded that the government of the day seriously proposed withdrawing our Canadian forces from Europe back in the early seventies, but backed off because the American government did not want them to.
That issue has come up over and over again, but as early as the 1980s and certainly by 1985, according to all intelligence reports, it was very clear that if there had ever been a Soviet threat to western Europe that threat was withdrawn and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics had changed its defence strategy into a defensive one. That was clearly documented and recorded by at least 1985. There is a lot of writing in the field that suggests there never was such a threat, but clearly by 1985 that was established. By 1988 and 1989 there could be no more doubt about it whatever; the threat had disappeared.

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
Yet this government continued to spend over a billion dollars a year in maintaining Canadian forces in Europe. That assumption was never challenged by the government. Only last year did the government finally make a decision to make a significant cut in our forces in Europe, and that cut is not to take effect until 1994 and 1995.
Even so, the government persists in maintaining 1,100 troops in Europe beyond 1995. The defence committee was recently in Europe and the evidence we received from our own military people was that 1,100 troops could not provide any useful, constructive military presence in Europe. Eleven hundred is simply a meaningless number.
They have no support, no logistics. There is no place for them. There is no strategy for them and they will obviously have no military role. Yet, the government even now persists in spending the taxpayers' money in that way.
I suggest that the government should realize that the real overspending is in its own programs and its failure to critically analyze the assumptions that underlie its policy. Its Pavlovian reaction to anything the Americans say should happen and its support of NATO over recent years, despite the fact that circumstances have clearly changed, suggest that this government's priorities are all wrong.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate briefly in the debate on Bill C-56.
I listened with great care to my hon. friend from Victoria. It seems to me that the NDP talking about spending control has all the credibility of an arsonist talking about fire control. I nevertheless listened with great interest to his remarks.
I think this spending control act is very important. It is not only a constriction on government spending but is a very important signal to the people of Canada that this government is serious about bringing the finances of this nation, and hence the economy of this nation, under control.
This act was part of the plan for economic recovery enunciated in the 1991 budget. It is there to make sure
that spending is restrained and that the budget announced annual program spending would be limited by law.
Last summer, on the day the Minister of Finance announced this program, I had the privilege of representing him at a meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, attended by 80 to 100 business people, the people who are involved in creating employment in this country, small business people for the most part.
They were very pleased to see that the government was putting its money where its mouth is, that it was going to put the constraints on itself in such a way that it was not just up to the government to maybe do what it says or maybe not.
We will do what we say. We have done what we have said. Now we are legislating it so that there will be no doubt whatsoever where this government stands.
That legislation was presented in draft form on that day in July. It was then, in this draft version, brought forward to the House of Commons finance committee for review in the hope that it might be able to make some improvements to the bill. Indeed, the bill now before Parliament reflects that review. The committee tightened and reviewed the legislation.
I want to tell my hon. friends opposite that Canadians are unequivocally telling governments to keep spending under control. My friends in the NDP might remind their colleagues in Ontario of that. This new law provides assurance that higher taxes cannot be used to pay for higher spending. New programs will have to be funded within the total legislated ceiling.
There have been suggestions by some members in this debate that the spending limits in this bill are different than the ones announced by the minister. I want to assure the House that is not the case. The minister accepted the advice of the Standing Committee on Finance.
It recommended that we restrict the number of self-financing programs and do not exclude any incremental funding for the self-financing programs, incremental funding to what was included in the February 1991 budget, but exclude all spending related to those self-financing programs. This has been done.
The limited number of self-financing programs has been reduced from 11 to four: Unemployment Insurance programs, the Crop Reinsurance Program, the Agricul-
February 19, 1992

tural Stabilization Account and the Gross Revenue Insurance Program.
By excluding the February 1991 budget projections for these programs from total program spending subject to the spending limits we have reduced the over-all limits. We have not increased the limits. These revisions do not change the substance of the draft legislation. The same level of program spending is being controlled now as before. In addition, the new provision to offset any overspending through reductions over the next two fiscal years makes this bill even tighter than the previous one.
Some programs were exempted simply because it did not make sense to the government to put spending control limits on things that could not really be controlled: things like interest on the national debt; urgent and critical emergencies to which the government had to respond but for which it could not properly budget; self-financing programs such as UI and the farm income protection act; and incremental funding for management initiatives that in fact are put in place to reduce the deficit.
Therefore, the government is putting itself on the line with this bill. If spending exceeds the limit in any one year the amount of overspending must be made up through cuts in following years.
The Minister of Finance is not allowed to present a budget that is inconsistent with this act. The annual public accounts will contain a statement by the Minister of Finance indicating compliance with this act and the Auditor General will report to Parliament on whether or not the act has been complied with.
Indeed, the Minister of Finance will be required in the 1994 budget to recommend whether or not the act should be extended beyond the end of 1995-96 fiscal year.
There is a very clear signal going out to Canadians with his piece of legislation: This government is serious about spending control and this government intends to make the most effective use of every tax dollar raised for the benefit of the taxpayers.
Government Orders
In conclusion, I would like to say that there have been discussions with the various representatives of the parties. I believe you will find that I have unanimous consent for the following motion:
That the motion for the second reading of Bill C-56, an Act
respecting the control of government expenditures be amended by
having the bill referred to the Standing Committee on Finance
rather than Legislative Committee E.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Does the hon. member have the unanimous consent of the House to put the motion?
Agreed.
Motion agreed to.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to see that Bill C-56 will be referred to the finance committee, because the latter has already examined this issue and even travelled to the United States to see how things work down there. You will remember that the committee tabled in this House a report to which I will refer in my comments.
One must seriously question if it is really necessary for a government in a British parliamentary system to propose in this House a measure to control public spendings. One wonders, or at least takes a critical view of the proposal and is somewhat sceptical.
You may ask yourself whether the Conservative government is trying to make Canadians believe that it manages the affairs of the country in a sound manner. It is obviously not the case because we have been in a terrible recession for over two years, we have a great number of Canadian workers who are unemployed. We have had high interest rates that have caused tremendous problems. On top of that recession, the government brought in some 33 new taxes. The last one was the GST which is among consumers the source of tremendous problems both at the family and regional levels.
The present government bragged, when it was elected in 1984, that it would put order in the financial affairs and the administration of the country. If this were already the government's stated goal in 1984, a goal which it repeated on numerous occasions, I wonder why it did not come up four, five or six years ago with a bill that would have put before Canadians the measures proposed in Bill C-56. Why did the government wait for

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
so long? Why did the government hesitate until almost the end of its mandate to present a bill which, in my opinion is not very clear and has no policy statement telling us where we are going with this legislation. Therefore, it will be very difficult to interpret this bill, and the wording of some of its sections leaves something to be desired.
That is the reason why I said earlier that I am pleased that the Standing Committee on Finance will be able to look at this bill, because I trust those people. With the approach that they will take, the members of the Committee will be able to examine the proposal with an open mind and possibly come back to us with proposals for amendments.
It is easy to table this bill because all those who know the workings of a parliamentary system are well aware that we have here a government, with a Prime Minister and a cabinet elected by the people, which has the power to do exactly what Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government's expenditures, allows them to do. The system is built like that. It is not an American system; it is not the Congress. It is a system based on a parliamentary majority where the government is empowered, and even has the right, to limit expenditures or to inform the Canadian population of the reasons it may want to bring in some budgetary restraints.
In the United States the legislative power and the administration are rather clearly separated. There have been problems. On occasion, it has been necessary to use legislation to solve conflicts; I am thinking of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act and the one that came after, the Budget Enforcement Act, on the implementation of budgetary measures. The Americans wanted to solve a dispute between the administration of the country on the one hand, which is for the most part controlled by non-elected people appointed by the President and the legislative power on the other hand, which is controlled by elected people. Such pieces of legislation were necessary to solve the problem. But it is not our problem in Canada and I wonder why this government must force upon us a measure which is almost American and which, according to me Madam Speaker, is irrelevant in a Canadian environment.
Let me refer to the report prepared by the finance committee after a visit to Washington during its study of the government working paper before the tabling of this bill; I read from paragraph 35.
Budget control legislation is a distinctly American approach to problems arising in a quite unique legislative environment. Just because the American system might need such controls does not imply that the Canadian parliamentary system would necessarily benefit from the same approach, despite the fact that both countries face similar fiscal problems.
In other words, the American solution is not necessarily the good one for Canada. I don't understand why we are losing our time studying a bill which is useless since, in our British parliamentary system, government can do exactly what is suggested in Bill C-56.
We only have to recall for example that not so long ago the Minister of Finance announced that it would be impossible to respect, presented, last year's estimates. There will be a 1.5 billion shortfall. The minister did not have to consult the House or anybody else, before making the decision to announce this shortfall, this accumulated deficit. No, he had the right to do it and he did.
The Minister of Finance has decided to freeze all discretionary expenditures until March 31, a saving of $200 million apparently. Did he come and explain to the House that he was doing this to comply with a bill introduced to control government expenditures? Not at all. He decided on his own authority, probably after consulting with cabinet, that he was going to do that. So they did. They did not need a law to do it. They had the power to do so.
If government is serious about controlling its expenditures, we should know what is really in its mind. It should tell us why it is introducing a bill such as this one. I do not understand it. I have read it. I have gone over it and found things that are absolutely unacceptable. I shall come to that immediately because I am running out of time.
Section 8 of the bill says, and I will quote because it is relevant to the annual report the Auditor General of Canada is about to table in this House. It actually creates the obligation for him to do certain things. Here is what section 8 says, and I will tell you my concern as part of my comments:
February 19, 1992

8. In reporting to Parliament in respect of the accounts of the government for a controlled fiscal year, the Auditor General of Canada shall express an opinion as to
(a)	whether this Act has been complied with in respect of that year; and
(b)	whether the statement referred to in subsection 6(1) fairly presents information in accordance with stated government accounting policies.
From this wording it is obvious that this whole thing is pretty unclear. The Auditor General will express an opinion on the government's accounting methods, but this provision does not provide for what we call a continuity factor. Who can give the Auditor General the assurance that the accounting methods used that year are at least the same from one year to the next? Nobody.
We compare bananas, cucumbers, carrots, and tomatoes. The same problem comes up every year with one exception and that was last year or the one before that when the Auditor General did not comment on or express reservations about the government's accounting procedures. It is the job of the Auditor General to come out every year and say that the government does not keep its books in accordance with recognized accounting methods widely used by experts in the industry, in the private sector as well as in the public sector, by governments. Something about continuity should be included in section 8 to ensure we are talking about the same thing.

It says here; "whether the statement referred to in subsection 6.(1) fairly presents information in accordance with stated government accounting policies".
We have had disagreements before between the public accounts committee and the government on the accounting methods that are used. This year it used $2 billion to reduce its deficit. We are not saying that it was correct or incorrect. We are just saying we have great difficulty understanding the facts as they are given to us in politics and given to the people of Canada and assessing those facts in a credible manner so we understand where we are going.
Government Orders
This government is doing things which are not correct in terms of accounting procedures and practices. It should correct them and that should be an amendment to this bill. Article 8 would see a continuity factor put into this and that the accounting methods used are at least the same from one year to the next.

Madam Speaker, I am happy today to be able to contribute to this debate on Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures.
I am prompted to rise to my feet today because of the simple fact that I believe Canadians are being led down the garden path, so to speak, by the government on this bill. There is no doubt throughout my constituency and in other parts of Canada as well that Canadians are frustrated, angry, and cynical. All these emotions are aimed at the present government and stem from the fact that their income security, personal security about the future, and confidence in the future of Canada have reached an all-time low.
The people of Canada I have talked to in my constituency and elsewhere have indicated a very strong desire to see something happen that will give them confidence in the future. They want confidence to believe what governments tell them. We now have a population that is very cynical about the way governments operate. They do not want to believe the things governments say to them. They have been given every reason not to believe the things they have been told. Frustration, anger, and cynicism flow out of individuals whenever they are together in coffee shops and in other places where people gather to discuss matters of interest and concern to them.
This bill talks about controlling government expenditures. In fact, that is something that many people in my constituency talk about. They talk about the government controlling expenditures because they see the media reports about the government spending money on things that have no relationship whatsoever to the ability of the individual within my constituency and elsewhere to live a better life, to have a stronger quality of life. They see the government spending money in ways that are not directly affecting them personally, when they are losing their farms, their jobs, and the opportunity to send their children to school. They are losing control of their own

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
lives. It is that loss of individual control that has led to directing those energies against the government.
Obviously, as I read it, this bill is an attempt to convince the Canadian population this government is serious about taking actions that will not cause them any more difficulties. There is an awful lot more at stake here. When we talk about the ability of governments to give the population of the country a quality of life and a confidence in their future, there is more to it than simply controlling government expenditures. There are two sides to every coin and governments can raise money and they can spend money. If they control spending it is one thing; if they allow revenues to disappear that is another matter. I could elaborate to some degree about the way this government has allowed revenues to slip away and how it has taken other revenues out of the economy, the GST for example, that could be utilized for other purposes and applied them to its own purposes within government.
The hon. member who spoke earlier from the government's side, from Nova Scotia, talked about New Democrats as being big spenders. I think we have to look at history to be able to understand what has happened in this country with spending.
We recall that Tommy Douglas was a sound and strong premier in the province of Saskatchewan. He inherited a very large debt and managed a government that left office without a debt in the province of Saskatchewan. Allan Blakeney, another New Democratic Party premier, managed the province of Saskatchewan for 11 years with 11 straight balanced budgets. When he left office in 1982, the province of Saskatchewan had a surplus of close to $200 million at a time when the economy was strong and continued to remain strong.
For nine subsequent years the Conservative government in the province of Saskatchewan managed to take that surplus through some good times and later some poor times and turned it into an almost $5 billion debt in a province where the annual revenues add up to less than $5 billion. In fact, the revenues available to the province of Saskatchewan equal just $4.5 billion. Obviously a $5 billion debt is beyond the ability of the people of that province to finance adequately.
In this last year we have seen the people of the provinces of Canada turn to the New Democratic Party to get them out of messes that have been created by others. As I mentioned, in the province of Saskatchewan the people left a mismanaged economy, a debt created by the Conservatives, and turned to the New Democrats to get them out of the mess.
In Ontario, the people, frustrated by Liberal deficit, turned to the NDP to manage that province properly.
In British Columbia, the people turned away from a Social Credit managed government and a Social Credit developed deficit and asked the New Democratic Party to clean up the mess.
I think that it will not be too long in the future that the fiscal mess created by this government will also be one that the people ask the New Democratic Party to clean up. I have every confidence that the New Democratic Party will be able to solve many of the problems that have been created by the present government.
When we talk about specific priorities, there is one in my own constituency that I have to talk about one more time. I have raised it in this House on numerous occasions. It is one which I have to raise again under this bill. It is the northern tax allowance program. This program recognized the inability of people who lived in northern and remote communities to have the same access to government services and resources that people in the more urban communities had access to.
In my own constituency a large number of people have asked for and received in the past the northern tax benefit. In some of those communities they received it for one year and then had it taken away from them by this government, after being told that they qualified and made the applications, people in the rural municipality of Beaver River, the rural municipality of Loon Lake, the towns of Loon Lake and Makwa.
A very unfair thing has happened to the people in those communities, people who deserve to have a benefit because of their so-called isolation from the other parts of Canada.
We recognize that everyone in Canada pays taxes. Anyone who has an income in this country above a certain level will pay taxes. We recognize that in return for those taxes the government provides a certain amount of service and a certain expectation about service. The people in communities such as Beaver River, et cetera, have an expectation about government services that can be supplied to them. They have recog-
February 19, 1992

nized that because they do not have the same access to those programs that people in Saskatoon and Regina have the government has an obligation not to charge the same tax that is charged to the people in Saskatoon and Regina.
What the northern tax program did was provide some of that funding to those people in recognition of the fact that they were not as close to the services and to the quality of life that governments can provide. Mind you, they do have access to many government services and that is why they continue to pay the taxes they do.
No one is saying that they should not be paying taxes, but there has to be recognition that the taxes that are paid by northern residents should be somewhat less than are paid by other residents of Canada.
I am asking for a fair program to be instituted once again by this government, a fair program that understands and recognizes the needs of the people in these communities. At no time does a program which is going to deal with expenditures and not revenues deal with the matters affecting the constituents who live inside the boundaries of my constituency. These are people who are frustrated, angry, and cynical about the actions of this government. They have every reason to remain so as long as this government continues to take steps that do not deal with the problems directly affecting them. Farmers see the government providing funds to them, but the funding is inadequate because they continue to lose their farms and move off their farms into larger communities.
While this bill is attempting to address matters of concern to people of Canada it is missing the point entirely. If this government were serious about dealing with the fiscal problems, it would deal with the revenue side and it would deal with the other problems Canadians are experiencing.

Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to have an opportunity to speak on Bill C-56 respecting the control of government expenditures. As a member of the House of Commons finance committee I spent many hours with other members of the committee hearing testimony concerning this bill when it was in the form of proposed legislation. Our committee went to Washington in a very worth-while endeavour to
Government Orders
examine the experience the United States has had with spending control legislation.
The work of that committee on this proposed legislation was an example of how parliamentarians can work together in a very non-partisan way, despite the differences among us on the fundamental principle of whether such a bill should be enacted in the Canadian parliamentary system. We studied how it worked in the United States under their system and we looked very carefully at the proposals before us in coming up with a set of unanimous recommendations on how the bill could be made to work better in Canada.
I want to emphasize, particularly for those watching, that this report I am referring to was not a Liberal Party report or a New Democratic Party report but a report of the House of Commons finance committee unanimously agreed to by all members of that committee, a majority of which were from the Conservative Party. Despite the fact that an all-party committee made unanimous recommendations on this report the government chose to adopt very few of them, and none of the most important ones.
First, I would like to express my concerns about whether this has any place at all in a parliamentary system. This is where we ran into the contradictions between our system and the U.S. system. Let it be understood that similar legislation in the United States, although it may have a place in its congressional system, has not worked.
The original attempt at deficit control legislation in the United States, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, projected a balanced budget for the current fiscal year. The President recently brought down his proposed budget for the coming year and it projects a U.S. budgetary deficit of $399 billion for one year alone. That figure is just a little bit shy of what our total accumulated debt is and somewhat more than 10 times our projected deficit at the federal level in Canada.
If spending control legislation works the United States is not an example of it because it has failed to work there. Experts we met in Washington described the most recent version of it, the spending control act of 1990, as the incumbent re-election act. They regarded it very cynically as merely a means to take the pressure off incumbents by allowing them to go home to their districts in their system and say: "Sorry, we can't get you the new spending project you're looking for because of

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
the spending control act". Nevertheless, the deficit in the United States continues to mount.
So we in our committee first of all acknowledged that the debt that the Government of Canada faces is a significant problem, and there was all-party agreement on that.
What we said was that what needs to be attempted is to achieve an objective of reducing our debt as a ratio of our national income.
Focusing merely on the size of the deficit is really quite misleading. It is like any family that needs to be concerned about the level of their household debt; it is only a problem if their income is insufficient to pay their debts as they become due. And so the committee focused on that point.
On the assumption that the government was intent on bringing this legislation in, which clearly was quite accurate an assumption, we then looked at how the legislation could be improved.
The first point we focused on was the fact that there cannot be an attempt to achieve a reduction in the debt as a ratio of our national income if only government spending is looked at. Instead, one has to look not only at spending, but also at revenue.
This proposed bill has a loophole that you could drive a truck through. This bill permits the government at any time to reduce taxes, reduce the amount of revenue that it brings in, even on the eve of an election without in any way infringing the provisions of the Act.
At least in the U.S. system any proposed tax reduction that any member of Congress wants to make must be offset by a reduction in spending somewhere else in the plan.
This government has brought forward a bill that enables it, just before the next election campaign, to introduce spending cuts without in any way affecting this proposed Bill C-56.
Our committee unanimously recommended that tax expenditures be included in the control plan.
The second thing we suggested is that Parliament should be able to suspend this bill in the event of an economic downturn upon the presentation to Parliament of a report by the Minister of Finance indicating that a downturn or recession is about to occur.
In other words, if things are going really badly in the economy it may well be necessary to increase spending for a short term in order to respond to that. All that we suggested, again unanimously, was that Parliament be consulted and enabled to lift the provisions of the act.
Another recommendation we made was that this Act be tightened. One of the things that we suggested-I know I am running out of time, but I want this to be clearly understood-we suggested that cash transfers to the provinces be removed from the base which this act controls.
Now let me explain the implications of that. This bill provides for certain controls on total government spending. Included in those amounts being spent is the amount that is transferred to provincial governments under programs for the federal assistance in post-secondary education and health.
Over the past few years we have had experience of governments reducing the amount of these transfer payments, and that has been very controversial in the House of Commons.
By leaving transfer payments in the spending control base, the government can increase spending in other areas while reducing transfer payments to the provinces and still meet the requirements of the spending control act.
In other words, the government could fail to address its underlying deficit problem by transferring the problem to the provinces by cutting back what is available to them under the EPF arrangements and still not have offended Bill C-56. This to us constituted a very important loophole. There are many other loopholes. We discussed some of them with the Auditor General and his staff when he appeared.
February 19, 1992

Let me give one further example to indicate why I have concerns about controlled spending for five years. The effect of it is only to control spending some time after the Auditor General's report for a previous year is received. In the last years of the controlled spending program a report will necessarily be received too late for anything to be done because it will be outside the statutory period.
My reaction to this bill is that it may have good intent but is of questionable pertinence to the parliamentary system and so riddled with loopholes as to be laughable even to those who would want to support it.

Madam Speaker, I too am very pleased to stand in the House today to speak to Bill C-56, an act respecting control of government expenditure.
Here we have a government that is scrambling by producing a bill that is nothing short of smoke and mirrors. It is nothing more than another effort by this government to confuse Canadians into thinking it is really a government of good fiscal managers.
Are not governments really supposed to be in control of expenditures? Do they really have to pass a bill to convince themselves and others? Is this not something they should already be doing? Canada is in and has been in a recessionary period for almost a year.
First the government refused to use that famous "R" word and once members did learn how it was difficult for them to imagine that their own high interest rates at that time and high dollar policy helped create this made-in-Canada recession. Since then the government hit Canadians with the GST a year ago. Consumer spending and consumer confidence was shattered and that prolonged the recession.
Since this government came to power a tremendous cynicism has shrouded Canadians. It took over $160 billion in debt in 1984 and increased that debt to more than $400 billion today, in 1992. It has collaborated with the policies of the Bank of Canada to keep interest rates high and our dollar at a high level, only reducing them recently.
The high Canadian dollar is discouraging exports from Canada. One wonders what deal this government made
Government Orders
with the U.S. government to keep our dollar rate so high.
We have seen cutbacks in transfer payments to the provinces, especially with the cap on the CAP for the provinces of Ontario, British Columbia, and Alberta. Does the government not realize how many jobs have been lost, particularly here in Ontario?
Does the government not know that in Toronto alone the jobless rate and the number of people on welfare is at an all-time high, the highest in the history of that city? Does the government not know that if we in Canada are to continue to compete in the global market we must maintain a high education standard and must ensure that retraining programs are in place for those who lost their jobs?
Here we have a government whose policies have decimated our fishing industry by callously ignoring its own people and giving preference to foreign fishermen.
Where in the world is the heart and the soul of this government?
Our Canadian farming industry is on its knees begging: "Let supply management remain in place, let this government defend its farmers at the GATT".
Now this government wants to pass legislation which would confine ministerial spending to the cumulative amount.
In other words this government cannot control its own ministers to live within its own budgets. It has to pass legislation to make sure they do.
These ministers have been shown to be incompetent. We know that on this side of the House. The Prime Minister knows they are incompetent. This begs the question as to why the Prime Minister allows them to stay. I say get rid of them. If you do not have trust in your frontline cabinet officials and if you have no trustworthy persons to replace them with, then for goodness sake let us call an election.
The Prime Minister presents a bill to legislate his ministers to keep them in line. In our parliamentary system of governing, budgetary controls are enacted. One would think that if a system of government is powerful enough to control its own fiscal policy, it could control its own spending.

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
This bill is nothing more than another sneaky measure to fool the people into thinking government members are responsible people.
It is hardly likely the Canadian people will elect this government again after what they have seen of it, especially since the election of 1988. They have seen the effects of the free trade deal; the GST; the government interest rates; its high dollar rate; its cutbacks in health and education and research and development; its negative impact on the CBC, VIA Rail, and Canada Post; the government's unravelling of the very fabric of this country; the closing of air bases in parts of Canada that were simply decimated by it.
This bill is to apply for five years starting in the fiscal year 1991-92. It is so desperate that it is an attempt to try to win back public support. This bill could cause the government to spend beyond the limits for each year set out in the bill. If this bill is intended to have a real impact, it would mean a new government elected would be unable to proceed with the programs for which it was elected. It would be unable to move immediately to carry out those priorities.
Of course a new government could amend legislation. But if this can be done, let me ask again: What is the point of the legislation in the first place? What is the point of proposing this bill if its life does not go beyond that of this Parliament?
This legislation does not exclude from its coverage its restraints and its limitations, programs like the old age pension and family allowances. What happens under this bill if the government's forecasts about the amount required for the old age pension is wrong? What happens if more of the population becomes older and lives longer than forecasted, creating greater need for expenditures under the old age security system? Is the Conservative government saying in this bill that it will cut back on the old age pension, even if there are older Canadians who expect and need these payments?
Liberals are concerned about issues of government expenditures and deficits. I want to make this abundantly clear. However as I have said at the outset, this proposal, this bill before the House is really nothing more than cosmetic. It simply puts into legislative form what this government has been doing anyway and that is working to live within its own budgetary projections.
I want to point out to those Canadians concerned about government expenditures and government activities that this bill does nothing to address their concerns, the concerns of Canadians about this government's ways and excessive taxes. In short this government is proposing legislation to do what it already has the authority to do. The proposal is simply an attempt by the Conservative government to hoodwink Canadians into thinking they are a great bunch of guys and gals on the other side of the House. They are finally coming to grips with the negative effects of their own economic incompetence and mismanagement.
This government ignores Canadians. It ignores the businesses that have shut down and want more than cosmetic measures from this government. They want a government that is concerned with the good management of itself and this country's affairs, one that helps rather than harms their basic confidence. More than this bill, Canadians want an election to give themselves a new and better government.
I am sure all Canadians, and not just my colleagues in the House and I, are continually distressed with the measures and the actions this government is taking, especially this bill which is nothing more than an attempt to deceive Canadian taxpayers into thinking that the government is a good fiscal manager and that it is concerned about the economy and budgetary controls.
I am pleased to speak against this bill on behalf of the constituency of Nepean.

Madam Speaker, thank you for giving me this opportunity to say a few words about Bill C-56 on behalf of the constituents of Scarborough West.
When I look at bills the very first thing I do is try to analyse what is going to affect the people of Scarborough West. I try to read the bill as objectively a way as I can and try to determine how to explain the contents and the decision making that went into putting forward a bill like Bill C-56.
I like to put myself in the position of the people in the coffee shop discussing this piece of legislation. When I do so-and I am trying to be fair-it conjures up an image to me. The image this entire bill conjures up is somebody in front of a low table on which there is a pea and the halves of three walnut shells. That person wants you to watch where the pea is, watch it be moved around
February 19, 1992

and then decide under what shell the pea should be. That is called the old shell game. Another name for it is the con game.
Why would that kind of an image be conjured up in my mind when I look at Bill C-56? Let's start with what it is supposed to do. It is called: "an act respecting the control of government expenditures". If we look inside we see that the very first section says:
This Act may be cited as the Spending Control Act.
They are three very simple words that I think most Canadians would probably interpret in the following way. Spending means paying out money; control means controlling the amount of spending being done. I would think that most constituents of Scarborough West when looking at the spending control act would say: "My goodness, we have finally got an act that is going to get government spending under control and ensure that spending is done in a controlled fashion".
When the Minister of Finance was responding to recommendations of the Standing Committee on Finance in December 1991, he referred directly to one of the comments made in recommendation No. 1 of the finance committee, which was specifically that "all members were not in agreement that a spending control act was either necessary or desirable".
What did the Minister of Finance say to that criticism? What he said is very relevant, I feel, in discussing the methodology of Bill C-56. He said quite clearly: "The government and most of the witnesses appearing before the committee strongly feel that continuing to exert firm control over expenditures is essential to ensure that the deficit is reduced and that public debt as a percentage of the economy declines".
Here is the interesting portion: "The spending control act will provide assurance to Canadians that Parliament shares this view and will demand discipline from government". I stress those words: "will demand discipline from government".
When we look at this bill we ask: Does it in fact demand discipline from any particular government? We do not have to go very far before we begin to see what is really happening and where the shell game begins. We see the spending limits, and most Canadians will be happy to know that the spending limit for the 1991-92 fiscal year is a mere $97.2 billion. The following year it
Government Orders
will be just $100.9 billion. The year after that it will be $104 billion. It is increasing each year. The year after that, 1994-95, it will be $107.4 billion. After that, it will be $111.25 billion. Constant increases. Do not forget, this is called the Spending Control Act. Yet, the spending is going up.
Section 3 addresses what will happen if we underspend. Presumably most Canadians are hoping that if this is the Spending Control Act spending will be controlled and that amount will not be met in the spending of the government.
The act provides that where the minister announces that it appears the spending limit for the preceding year will exceed the program spending for the preceding year the minister may allocate all or part of that excess to the particular year. The spending limit for the particular year shall be increased by the amount so allocated. We have to read that about 10 times before we can make any sense of it. We are moving the shells around and trying to figure out where the pea is.
What happens if spending is going to be increased and we go beyond the limit, because this spending control bill allows the government to spend beyond the limits it has set? It says, and I am sort of compressing it because the wording is unbelievable, the minister may propose program spending for the particular year that exceeds the spending limit for the particular year, if the minister allocates the excess to the two next following controlled fiscal years in such proportions as the minister shall determine.
The spending limit for the year 1992-93 happens to be $100.9 billion. Should the minister decide that expenses will be beyond $100.9 billion he will simply advise us that it is the case and the increase, whatever it may be, will be carried forward into the upcoming two years.
Where is the spending control the spending control act is talking about here? Is it doing anything more than moving the pea around underneath the shell on the table? The answer is no. The minister can do what I have just read anyway. One would presume that any responsible Minister of Finance would want to ensure that he gets the best value for every dollar spent. Naturally, if the minister can get the same services for less money, that is to his or her credit. I would hope that would be one of the things the Minister of Finance would be striving for.

February 19, 1992
Business of the House
Should it happen that the minister does come in under budget lo and behold we have a little extra money. Hopefully that would be used to pay down the debt or for whatever else we Canadians think the money should be used for.
If it should happen that the minister is wrong and he or she has to spend more money than was originally allocated the minister can take that into account in any future budget. The minister can already do what the so-called spending control act is putting into words.
What is the purpose? Why have another act? Why take up the time of the House of Commons? Why take up the time of committees to examine an act which is merely putting into words what the minister can already do, as any good finance minister should do, as any reasonable person in their own home does?
You have a certain amount of money. If you manage to buy the things you wish to buy and have a few dollars left over you can apply it to the Visa bill, put it into the bank, or do what you want with it. On the other hand, if you have made a miscalculation and end up spending a little bit more money, then you adjust for that the next month.
On a huge scale the Minister of Finance is doing what we in our homes do each and every month. We do not need a piece of legislation to tell us what we need to do. We need some common sense. Common sense is something that is very prevalent in the riding of Scarborough West. The constituents of Scarborough West ask, through me: "Why do we need a bill that already tells us what the minister can do?"
It is for cosmetic purposes, as our critic the hon. member for Windsor West has already said. We are just putting a little make-up on the government to make it look good. We are going into an election year. Things do not look veiy good for the government right now. It is going to try to put a happy face on disastrous policies. That happy face will say: "We're going to control spending". We do not have to go beyond the third section of the so-called spending control act to see that it is nothing. It is a shell game. If the government overspends, it will overspend. If it underspends it will do what it wants anyway.
For that reason the people of Scarborough West, using their common sense, know they cannot support this legislation.

speakeroldname: Hon. Charles Mayer (for the Minister of Agriculture) moved
speakerposition: Minister of Western Economic Diversification; Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)
speechtext:
that Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee D.
He said: Mr. Speaker, Bill C-54 before us amends the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
We all know that we face difficulties in the agricultural industry on many fronts but we do have a pretty efficient and a well-recognized industry, not only at home but internationally. We feed ourselves with a smaller percentage of disposable income than any country in the world. We produce in surplus for export markets and when we do sell into those markets our reputation is very good.
When we look around at what is likely to be the situation in the future, we find we will have to be more and more adaptable as time goes on. We think, and a lot of producers and producer organizations agree, that one of the ways to best accomplish this is to have the wherewithal, where it is possible, and to some extent the decision making for how we adapt, in the hands of the producers that are involved.
Government Orders
The government said in the throne speech:
We guarantee our future not by running from global competition,
but by meeting it head on by equipping ourselves to compete with
the best.
In many ways that is what this bill is designed to do. It is enabling legislation. It is designed to provide the opportunity for producers to put in place what has come to be known as a check off, to use the money for research and promotion, for things like the advertising that we see on a regular basis. The Beef Information Centre in Toronto that advertises beef is an example. The money will be used for consumer education, domestic and foreign marketing efforts, as well as research into production of a product, processing of a product, distribution, and marketing.
There are many examples of why we should do that. Essentially we are taking what has come to be known as the Farm Products Marketing Act and changing its name because it will have a broader scope. The new title will be the Farm Products Agencies Act. The bill changes the name from the Farm Products Marketing Council to simply the Farm Products Council. At the same time we will be putting a new section 3 in the bill that will provide for the establishment of levies or check-offs so that they can be set up nationally, as I said, for promotion and research into various products.
There is pretty wide support for this, Mr. Speaker. The Canadian Cattlemen's Association, the Canadian Horticultural Council, the Canadian Pork Council, the Canadian Fruit Wholesalers Association, the Fresh for Flavour Foundation, the Western Grain Research Foundation, the Canadian Honey Council, and the Canadian Nursery Trade Association all support this. All of these groups have expressed interest in a national check-off system.
These groups have indicated that they would spend a portion of the funds on primary production research projects. This type of national check-off is consistent with pillars in the agrifood strategy that came out in the paper two years ago called "Growing Together", one of them asking the industry to be more self-reliant and more market oriented.
In saying that, I want to emphasize that this in no way indicates the government has any intention of backing away from support for the industry, either in some of the things we have been doing directly or in the kind of money that has been spent in the past on research. I want to knock that one in the head as quickly as I can. Anybody who wants to look at this as a signal that the

February 19, 1992
Government Orders
government is intending to back away and use this legislation as a way of doing so, that is simply not the case at all. Quite the contrary. What you will find is if you can raise some producer money yourself, either from the private side or governments or a combination thereof, you can use it, as it has come to be known, to lever additional money.
I would also suggest that if you are a barley producer and have the ability to raise funds for research and advertising and do it at a very basic level, and you want to get involved with a check-off, to spend a little bit of money on each tonne or each bushel that is marketed in this type of a way, you are going to have a pretty good feel for what in fact this money should be spent on.
On that basis I would suggest that you are going to get pretty good use of the money as opposed to collecting and running it through various sets of committees and bureaucracy, not to mention the fact that they all cost money to run. You will have less diffusion of objectives coming from the producer if it is done by a system of raising money directly from producers themselves.
Some of the activities that could be supported by check-offs include market research, new product development, consumer education, advertising, and promotion. There are examples of that already in place. The Canadian Cattlemen's Association, as I mentioned, has for a number of years through their provincial associations, sponsored and run the Beef Information Centre out of Toronto. We see those ads on a reasonably regular basis on television. That is the kind of thing that would be envisioned. The Canadian Horticultural Council and the Canadian Produce Marketing Association through the Fresh for Flavour Foundation promote fresh fruits and vegetables but they find, I am told, that funding is not always adequate.
The Americans have a check-off in place for their cattle industry. Some of us have followed this. They have had, I think, two national referendums to get one in place. It has been established now for a number of years and their estimate is that for every dollar they spend on advertising they get a $4 return. It is not to say that is always the case but there is pretty good evidence that the money spent in this way is useful in promoting what we
have in this country, which is some very healthy and wholesome food.
I believe that we have, for several reasons, some of the best conditions for growing wholesome food that is very pure. We find this all the time in our grain markets, for instance, where our customers recognize Canada as one of the prime areas in the world for producing food in a very wholesome way.
Just as an example, I had a chance in the last couple of years to talk to people from Europe who had visited the Peace River country and found that in some cases they could not believe what they were seeing, an area very rich in soil, in climatic conditions and in environment, which had not been farmed very long and therefore not had a chance to be polluted by pesticides or chemicals. Because of that they thought there was an opportunity to market products out of that area in an environmental way simply because of the purity of the environment the food is produced in. But to do that we have to get our message out and this is the type of legislation that could be used.
As I said, it is enabling legislation. It can provide for either a mandatory check-off or what would be a mandatory check-off with the ability to have money refunded. It will be run and looked after by the National Farm Products Council, as it will be known when this legislation is passed.
In summary, this is legislation that has been asked for by farmers themselves. It is, as I said, enabling legislation. There is nothing compulsory about it. Producers would be able to organize themselves and ask the government through the National Farm Products Council to put this type of legislation in place. They would, at the same time, need the concurrence of their various provinces.
There is evidence from what we have been doing up to now that this kind of check-off system works. There is evidence internationally that it works as well. There are new products that are available now to satisfy consumers' needs. Food is no longer simply a means of sustenance. It has become in many cases a way of life that involves many other things than just the product itself.
