degree of compliance by pharmacists with the program is unknown. Some provinces allow the pharmacist to levy a surcharge on the drug costs. Others allow the pharmacist to keep the difference between the actual drug cost and the formulary price.
"In addition, there are the private and the employee drug plans for which there are not readily available public data. The extent of a free market for the remaining prescriptions differs among provinces as has been described earlier. To summarize, there are not uniformly reliable data on the financial reward to dispensing drugs".
What would be an appropriate question, on the basis of that quotation, is what should be the concern of the Government of Canada with respect to this issue, given that the market exists? We do not do investigations into the prices of everything, and I think that is quite simple. The issue is simply based upon the fact that a very large proportion of our publicly funded health costs are incurred in the acquisition of medicines required by patients. Those costs are paid out of the public purse.
As we have seen from the research that we have been able to do, nobody really has a handle on how all of these costs are arrived at. We cannot pin down what the level of mark-up is stage by stage in the process. There is some question as to how competitive the acquisitions are. It seems eminently reasonable, therefore, in the face of that, that we should be supporting the idea of a commission undertaking or embarking upon a study into these prices.
I want to make clear that what we are dealing with here is not the issue of innovative drug manufacturers versus generic drug manufacturers; that issue is entirely separate from this particular issue. In either case, we need to deal with the level of mark-up that occurs through the system.
What can certainly be said in general terms is that if an imperfect market exists, prices will not always be reasonable in relation to costs. What we have in this case is a very imperfect market where the consumers of medicines are often unconcerned with the cost because they, in person, do not incur the costs and where the provinces have the difficulty of trying to either compensate users or force them to pay premiums over the costs of their drugs.
Private Members' Business
To refer to the Gagnon study relating to when drugs can be put on the market or to refer to the Patented Medicines Prices Review Board as providing the information that such a royal commission could obtain and make available as part of the over-all study that must be ongoing continually at both the federal and provincial levels with respect to health care costs, is fundamentally to miss the point.
I would like to conclude by saying that the proposals that the member for Davenport has made in his motion, that the House urge the government to launch a royal commission to look at the level of mark-ups throughout the distribution chain in the pharmaceutical industry, is an entirely reasonable one and one that I am pleased to support.

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this motion which I wish to support is, I believe, a very simple motion and I am surprised that we do not have the support of the Conservative side of this House. I heard the hon. member from the Conservative side saying that this is not necessary.
I just want to go back to the Liberal motion so that we understand what we are talking about. It is absolutely necessary to support it.
The motion says:
That this House urges the government to launch a royal commission into pricing practices in the pharmaceutical industry to determine the rate of mark-ups in price at each transaction, from manufacturer to wholesaler or distributor, from wholesaler or distributor to retailer, and from retailer to the public, in order to determine how such mark-ups affect the Canadian consumer.
That means we want to know whether the Canadian public is getting fleeced, is getting ripped off. I would like to see this royal commission because I have my own opinion and my opinion comes from the people I represent in my riding of Chambly. The senior citizens group from St. Mathias told me about the high price of their medication, as did the senior citizens groups from St. Bruno in the town of Chambly and St. Basile le Grande. If there is one thing these people tell me, it is that they are getting ripped off on the price of pharmaceuticals. The problem is that they cannot get a 10 or 15 per cent raise in their pension income because it is not there.

Private Members' Business
We are talking about the fact that pharmaceuticals are costing so much nowadays, but that is okay because the province is paying for them. They are free. I am sure my friends on the other side would say: "There is no such thing as a free lunch". Well there is no such thing as a free pill. The province is paying for it, which means I am paying for it and that you are paying for it.
I must say that as a consumer advocate I have seen certain patterns emerge among businesses. I do not think the pharmaceutical business is that much different. They get their foot in the door, get a monopoly on a product, and then they make sure that nobody else gets in.
That is why I welcome this motion. It is a Liberal motion but I think it is a motion that everyone can identify with. I do not think there is any question of partisanship here. It is a motion which gets down to the nitty-gritty. Are we being ripped off or not in pharmaceuticals?
We must take a look at the cost of medication nowadays, particularly in view of patent legislation where I believe we have been sold down the river by this government as far as increasing patent protection and shutting out the generic companies is concerned.
I am sure the members on the other side will say: "No, that is not the case. By making sure that generic drugs which are cheaper do not get into the marketplace too soon, we are creating more investment. We are getting more money in R and D". I looked at that. Do you know what? The R and D represents about $200 million a year, maybe $250 million. Some companies in Quebec said: "Well, we may invest this year or maybe not. We are waiting for the Constitution to settle down". But it represents about $250 million per year or let us say $300 million. I will tiy to be as factually correct as I can.
Mr. Speaker, if you take a look at just one province, the province of Ontario, it has said that the patent protection changes will represent increases of approximately how much? This is not a quiz, but I see that my colleagues on the other side are silent. Well, let me help you. It is not $200 million. No, it will cost more than that. It is not $300 million to equal the R and D, but 450 million bucks. That is why we are going to pay more.
As I said, there is no free lunch and there is no free pill. In reality, it is not the provincial government that is paying, it is the taxpayers who are paying. That is what is scandalous about this whole deal.

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext: Where do you want the drugs made?

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Where would I like the drugs made? I do not care where the drugs are made necessarily as long as we are not paying more than our fair share for them.
I do not know what members on the other side know about drugs but I was a medic in the U.S. army and I remember the difference and cost of different drugs, generic versus the regular drugs. I will give you an example, Diazapan. Do you know what Diazapan is? It is Valium. You buy it as Diazapan it costs you pennies, you buy it as Valium which is the trade name and it costs you about 25 times more. It has been on the market for decades and they are still ripping off the public as far as the amount of money they are getting under the Valium label.
Let me talk to you about tetracycline hydro-chloride. Do you know what that is? It is an antibiotic and it is called Terramycin. The same rule applies. Do you want me to tell you about aspirin? Aspirin is not generic, Aspirin is actually a trade name. That is why if we mention Aspirin outside this House the drug companies are going to say: "Whoa, make sure that you say aspirin is a registered trade mark" because they do not want to lose their trade mark. Aspirin is acetysalicylic acid and it costs pennies but when it is Aspirin or Bufferin or Bayer-I could talk to you about all the Aspirin wars in the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s but I will not waste your time-when it gets into that trade name then you are going to pay a lot more for the same product.
I would not care. I would not be up here speaking about this if this drug monopoly and drug pricing were not affecting the most vulnerable people in our society, but it is, and you know it when you go down and see your people who are in the senior citizens groups. You know dam well that is the case. It is not just pricing.
One of the first cases I had when I was elected here about two years ago was one dealing with a medication which used to control angina and they found out that it had an arthritic affect. So they took that same medication, renamed it and they boosted the price five times. I had to go on Market Place. I had to complain. I had to make a big issue of it until a drug company said: "Oh,
February 19, 1992

yes, you are right; it is the same product". Well let us bring it down to a reasonable price.
I believe fundamentally we are getting cheated. I believe fundamentally there is a need for this type of royal commission. When we talk about the $25 million it might cost, I just bring you back to the Auditor General's report against this government that complains that this government has wasted over $20 billion in not investing properly our pension funds, which it has. So do not talk to me about $20 million to $25 million. I want to make sure that we stop fleecing senior citizens on the cost of medication in this country.

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to rise on this motion because it gives me a chance to tell some of the members who were elected in 1988 and who are new here, as well as any Canadians who might happen to be watching, my particular perspective on the history of this whole drug issue.
Needless to say, I am opposed to the royal commission because in a sense the Prices Review Board is an ongoing royal commission looking at the prices of drugs charged in Canada all the time and it puts the companies to very strict examinations and presentation of information as to what they are charging. It is an ongoing body, very professional, and has had a dramatic impact on the price of drugs in this country.
As well, there are parliamentary committees and we have standing committees that can take up, any issue we want. So if the members of the opposition truly believe and can make a prima face case that there that there is a rip-off, there is absolutely no doubt that the standing committee on health can take up the topic and follow up on it. We do not need to hire maybe 10 people at $800 or $900 a day on a royal commission to do this type of a study.
What I am more astounded about is the continued opposition and the continued hatred displayed by the members of the opposition toward public corporations in this country because that is really the underlying current that they are getting at. [DOT]
If a company becomes public and large, they are inherently opposed to it. They are particularly opposed to manufacturing companies.
Private Members' Business
Look at all the decades that the Liberal-NDP coalition carried on that manufacturers sales tax, all the while knowing that every other country in the whole world had abolished manufacturers sales taxes against their manufacturing firms.
Canada was the only country in the whole world that continued that anomalous manufacturers sales tax. This is primarily because manufacturers are big companies and they just do not like them. The fact of the matter is, they do not like them.
What they are also getting at when they are opposed to those companies and those companies surviving is that they are attacking the research and development.
They are attacking our universities and the training of basic scientists who have to work there. I will talk about that further, particularly with respect to drugs.
There is no doubt that during the latter parts of the 1950s and 1960s that drug companies were charging a lot for their drugs. The rate of increase was higher than it ought to have been, but that was occurring around the globe.
So governments reacted. In virtually every other country of the world where they acted at all on it, a prices review board was brought in with the power to call the companies in, to subpoena their records, to examine the research and development they were doing and the cost of developing these drugs. That is very expensive; $200 million or $300 million is nothing to develop a new drug and it then takes from 9 to 12 years to even get it on the market.
Most other countries came up with a prices review board. Not Canada, not the Liberal-NDP coalition that ran this country for many years together, always hand in glove.
Oh, they would have a lover's tiff from time, to time, particularly around election time, to make sure the NDP could get a few elected, but when they got right down to it they were always sticking together just like that.
I sat back here a couple of rows in 1979 when they brought down the Clark government and there has been a continuing history of that.

Private Members' Business
What did they do? They abolished patent protection. There was no prices review board. They took away the patent rights.
So what did the companies do? If you want to invest in a drug company, are you going to start your company in Canada and make drugs, hire Canadian university graduates, our chemists, our physicists, our scientists, to develop these drugs when you could go to Switzerland, to Britain, to France, to the United States, anywhere around the world but Canada?
Of course, they did not come here; they went to these other countries. So research and development got smaller and smaller in Canada. It did not mean we were using less drugs. It meant that the drugs our people had to buy were manufactured by young people, workers and scientists in other countries.
It did not save us one cotton-picking cent, but what it did cost us was tens of thousands of slots in universities and science positions in universities where Canada could have been developing the drug so that everyone else in the world would be paying a small royalty to us. And it could have been self-sustaining.
Because of the Liberals and the New Democratic Party, the country that developed insulin, that should have been a leader right into the next century went into a Third World status in terms of drugs. That is what we inherited in 1984.
It was exactly the same with respect to plant breeders rights. They opposed it. The NDP is on record as having opposed it for years and years. The combination of the NDP and the many organized church groups who were totally off-base in their opposition meant that new varieties and new grain types were being developed around the world, but not in Canada.
By the time we come along and get the modest patent protection for drugs through, we are 10 to 15 years behind.
The same with plant breeders rights. By the time we got that through this House, our scientists, who for the first time could get some patent protection and therefore develop varieties and get a royalty, are 15 years behind.
In high technology companies, when you are one year behind you are a dinosaur. If you are 10 or 15 years behind, you have an absolutely huge burden to get over.
That is exactly what the Liberal Party left this country. Fortunately in terms of the third bill that involved patents they learned, and I must give them credit, by the time we came along to the Integrated Circuits Topography Act. I know that because I was the parliamentary secretary and ran it through.
They are these little chips. They are really like an apartment building. There is layer after layer of silicon with wires going between them, or some other connection. It is like an apartment building.
We have 25 companies in this country that build these integrated circuits. It is an enormous job creation place for our talented young people. It is a bit like an architect designing how the pipes will go up through apartments.
With no patent protection of course companies were not going to do it here. So we got a bill through the House, and I must say that both the Official Opposition and the New Democratic Party voted for that bill. Finally, they realized that in this country we have to do research and development. To get research and development we have to have patent protection. That is really a step ahead.
Let us not forget our history. This resolution is just a return to that typical attitude that they have that they are against anyone who is doing corporate work or anyone who is doing R and D.
Was it successful? Yes. The drugs in this country only take 6 per cent of total health care costs. The R and D being done in 1986 was less than $100 million. This past year it was $300 million.
Think of the young people who are working today, our scientists who are working who were not working even four years ago. They are going to use the drugs anyway. Finally, they can use drugs that were developed and manufactured in this country.
I am looking at a chart which shows that every other country offers many more years, almost twice to three times the patent protection that we do. It is very important that this resolution not be passed because it will reduce a very substantial and healthy business in this country.
February 19, 1992

subsubtopic: ESTABLISHMENT OF ROYAL COMMISSION INTO PRICING PRACTICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to stand here in support of the motion of my colleague from Davenport:
- urge the government to launch a Royal Commission into pricing practices in the pharmaceutical industry to determine the rate of mark-ups in price at each transaction from manufacturer to wholesaler or distributor, from wholesaler or distributor to retailer, and from retailer to the public, in order to determine how such mark-ups affect the Canadian consumer.
I guess I have been somewhat shocked at the previous speaker's comments. I would like to say why I can support this motion.
The pharmaceutical industry in Canada is a substantial business. Its activities amount to $4.5 billion every year.
For certain products called patent drugs, the industry enjoys a substantial monopoly situation which could be strengthened and amplified if the present negotiations at GATT are successful.
The whole question of mark-ups in the price of pharmaceutical products affects the consumer. Markups in this industry also affect the taxpayer and the public purse.
Why is this a public issue? It is a public issue in two respects. This is an industry that is federally regulated. The cost of prescription drugs is covered by provincial health care plans with public funds.
It is so simplistic. As a result of this brief overview I find it very difficult to understand the previous speaker from the government side of the House. This affects the public purse.
We as Canadians have been very proud of our health care system that ensures that all Canadians receive complete and thorough medical treatment regardless of income or economic standing. But an important part of the picture is missing, a part that perhaps we should be less proud of.
Every Canadian can go to a doctor and every Canadian can get a prescription for whatever drugs are needed to heal the symptoms of illness. For some Canadians they can even go to the pharmacist and get those drugs free. But for many, depending upon a variety of factors including where they live, they cannot afford to get the drugs they need at all.
As I said earlier, drugs are a major industry. The annual revenue is $4.5 billion. This revenue is divided
Private Members' Business
between a number of sources: the manufacturer, the wholesaler, the pharmacist. At each stage the price of the drug gets higher and higher.
Estimates place the mark-ups at between 15 per cent and 60 per cent by the manufacturer; 7 per cent to 10 per cent by the wholesaler; and another 30 per cent to 50 per cent by the pharmacist.
For seniors and for people on low incomes, these drug mark-ups can incur a considerable hardship. The people who most often need drugs will be the ones who are least able to afford them.
At the moment there is one check to the seemingly uncontrollable increase in the price of drugs which is the generic drug industry in Canada. It is strong and it is Canadian owned.
The generic drug industry has been able to flourish in Canada because the patent protection period on new drug products is much shorter than it is in some other countries.
Now the catch on the government side is that the government now wants to extend the patent protection on drug products to 20 years. It says this will be an incentive to the industry to invest in research and development. Will this move be a good one for Canada?
At the moment, 92 per cent of the pharmaceutical industry is foreign owned. It is not even Canadian owned. There are even monopolies in the system.
The two largest Canadian manufacturers are Novo Pharm and Apotex, both producers of generic drugs. By extending patent protection on name brand drugs for 20 years this government will severely impair the current efforts of these two firms to expand, two Canadian companies I might add.
The foreign companies that control the brand name drugs will have plenty of money for R and D that they can take back home with them, while the Canadian companies will be forced to cut back. And of course this will mean loss of Canadian jobs and more people on unemployment insurance than we already have in this country.
Statistics show that those on low income, due to a number of factors, are the ones most in need of drugs. What a vicious circle this government is creating.

February 19, 1992
Private Members' Business
As one constituent of mine has said, and I am sure she will not mind my quoting her. Her name is Gwenda Noad and she says:
For many Canadians, the purchase of essential medications is the major item in their health care costs. It certainly is for me. The ability to obtain generic drugs provides substantial relief and I find it difficult to understand why this action is being taken which will in future years erode our ability to obtain low cost drugs.
Mrs. Noad, I also find it difficult to understand. It is simply an uncaring, unsympathetic government.
This motion is so obviously necessary that I am surprised it has not received unanimous consent in this House of Commons. All this motion asks is that we keep tabs on the pharmaceutical industry.
As my colleague from Davenport has said, the waters are so murky here that he was not even able to discover how far-reaching this problem is or how many Canadians it is affecting.
This government has said that there is already a system in place to monitor the drug industry. Bill C-22 created the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, but the mandate of that board is so limited that it renders the board ineffective.
It deals only with the mark-up between the manufacturer and the wholesaler. In any case, all it can do is review the prices. If this board thinks the prices are too high it is powerless to act.
Another argument against federal intervention is that this area of price mark-up falls too much under provincial jurisdiction.
I repeat here what I have said before, that I am proud as a Canadian of our universal health care system and I think most Canadians are too.
If one senior or one child in this country, anywhere from Vancouver Island to Newfoundland to Whitehorse, dies because that person cannot afford to buy drugs that he or she needs then that is one death too many.
This motion is simply saying: "Let's force the players to put their cards on the table. Let's let Canadians know
what the mark-up is on these products that they do not buy for choice, they do not buy for enjoyment". People buy drugs because they need them to stop pain, to ease discomfort, and to make it through a difficult day.
Drugs are not a luxury item. If we really believe that universal medicare is important-and I for one am proud that Canada provides health care for all its citizens- then let us make sure that all Canadians, rich or poor, have access to drugs and medication that they need.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: It being eight o'clock p.m., the House will now proceed to the consideration of a motion to adjourn the House under the provisions of Standing Order 52 for the purpose of discussing a specific and important matter requiring urgent consideration, namely the situation in the Atlantic fishery.

speakeroldname: Hon. Roger C. Simmons (Burin -St. George's) moved:
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
That this House do now adjourn.
He said: Mr. Speaker, this is an important debate. It is about fish; more to the point, it is about people. I am grateful to the Speaker for entertaining my request and allowing this debate this evening. I have no illusions. This debate will not solve the problem which we face. What it will do, I trust, is focus some national attention on a national industry in distress and on a treasured way of life that is under unwarranted and vicious attack.
The debate this evening must also focus some minds and get the attention of at least some of those who are most responsible, and who must bear the lion's share of the responsibility for allowing a once proud industry to come so precariously near to oblivion. At the same time we must get the attention of those same people who happen to be in a position to do something to correct this situation.
I do not exaggerate; I do not overstate the case. The Newfoundland fishing industry is at a watershed. A way of life which has nurtured Newfoundland's sons and daughters for five centuries is slipping relentlessly beyond our grasp. If that is permitted to happen, Canada will certainly be the loser; all of Canada will be diminished by it because that will be nothing less than cultural genocide.
Chief among those who stand indicted of this doublebarrelled wilful act of destroying both a precious marine resource and a proud maritime people, is the Prime Minister of this country.
You see, this is all about political will or the lack of it. The factor which is most in play here is foreign overfishing, and I will have something more to say about that in a moment. The senseless, suicidal ravaging of the fish stocks off Newfoundland would have stopped long ago if the Prime Minister had taken on the issue.
As you know, this Prime Minister has a well-earned reputation of being a man who can grab hold of an issue and see it through to the result he wants. Thke for example the free trade agreement and the GST. He wanted these and he got them against all odds. Now many of us are suffering as a result, but that is for another debate. The point here is that the Prime Minister's commitment to a cause usually produces some results. His commitment and his agenda often prevail, and therein lies the crux of the problem in the present case. Foreign overfishing is not on the Prime Minister's agenda. He is not seized with the issue. Until that changes, the pillaging of Newfoundland's fish stocks by the Spanish and Portuguese will continue unabated and indeed will accelerate.
This year for example, foreign overfishing is up by 100 per cent while the local Newfoundland fish catches are down by 50 per cent. Do we need any more proof than those two statistics? Unless the Prime Minister focuses his mind on this matter, thousands of fishermen in my riding and elsewhere will sit idly on the wharf this summer and for a lot of summers to come. Plant workers will be forced to turn to welfare handouts. Fish plants by the dozens will close their doors forever and community after community after community will vanish off the map altogether.
Every single Newfoundland MP is on deck for this debate tonight. My friend and colleague from Bonavis-ta-Trinity-Conception is here. My friend and colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte is here. My friend and colleague from Labrador is here. My friend and colleague from Gander-Grand falls is here. They are here because they, like me, want to tell you something of the misery being inflicted on their constituents by this tragedy.
They are here because like me they want to inform you and the people of Canada of the situation. They are here because they want to implore this government to act while there is yet time to act.

February 19, 1992
I am certain my friend from St. John's East will also want to bring his concerns to this debate, and I look forward to hearing from him. I am especially pleased to see my good friend from St. John's West, the Minister of Fisheries in his place tonight. I understand that he will follow me in this debate. That is entirely as it ought to be because he is the Newfoundland MP among the seven of us who we want to hear from most on this issue.
Many Newfoundlanders are watching these proceedings on television this evening to hear from the minister of fisheries. As our sole representative in the cabinet he can do most to get the ball rolling to the immense benefit of his constituents and mine and all the others who have the privilege of sitting here representing the people of Newfoundland.
Therefore may I appeal to him not to miss the golden opportunity that is his this evening.
I saw him writing frantically a moment ago and I am sure that steel trap mind of his is working overtime this evening.
Is it too much to ask of him that when he rises to speak he resists the understandable temptation to score some easy debating points about lily white Tories and big bad Liberals? Newfoundlanders know that he is a first-class debater. He will know that the debate this evening is not about who can deliver the slickest line. It is not about one-upmanship.
As my friend from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception said yesterday, it is about the worst of times in the cornerstone of the Newfoundland economy. It is about foreigners laughing all the way to the bank. As I have said it is about a way of life, his way of life and mine, and it is about cultural genocide.
What is the minister prepared to do to help stop it and pull us back from the brink? That is what I want to hear this evening. I believe that is what every Newfoundlander who is watching and listening wants to hear from our friend from St. John's West.
I do not want to suggest for a moment that the minister is out to lunch on this one. Far from it. It is true he sat on his hands for about four years from the beginning of the 1985 fishing season when the overfishing began until the end of 1988 before he opened his mouth to even acknowledge there was a problem, let
alone protest it. But true to form, when he got in gear he took on the file with a vengeance and that is to his credit. We lost four valuable years but we cannot retrieve that now.
Indeed it occurs to me in reflecting on my friend from St. John's West that in some respects he may be seen more as a victim than a villain or culprit in this whole sony mess. After all, he is the one who has been left dangling by the Prime Minister on this issue. After all, he is the one who wages what must be a very lonely battle in cabinet.
Part of my purpose here this evening is to try to make his battle just a little less lonely. Unless that minister can change the mind-set in cabinet, I have to wonder why he even bothers to hang in there. Having said that, I must admit there is a part of me that prays he will, but another part of me is prepared to admit to him that I would completely understand if he does not.
I said a moment ago that this is an industry of national proportions. It is that. We often think of the auto industry as a great national industry and it is. Let me do a quick comparison. The auto industry, principally in Ontario but somewhat in Quebec, represents in total, in terms of the auto plants and the auto parts plants, about
117,000	jobs at the moment. That is almost precisely the number of jobs represented by the Atlantic fishery in terms of men and women in the boats and the plants in the four Atlantic provinces.
To put it differently, in Ontario terms the auto industry represents just over 2 per cent of the jobs. In Newfoundland the fishing industry represents 21 per cent of the jobs. It is at once a very important contributor to the regional economy, but in terms of absolute size it is right up there in national job numbers with the auto industry. I am sure most Canadians would identify it as being one of our great national industries.
Newfoundland means fish. It has always meant fish from the time that Giovanni Caboto, John Cabot, shouted in his native Italian buona vista which is where we get Bonavista, the town of a proud name in the riding of my colleague, Bonavista-Trinity-Conception. It has meant fish from the time he was moved to report to the King of England that the waters around Newfoundland were "teaming in codfish". From that moment on Newfoundland came to mean fish, so much so that the west country merchants of England succeeded in their lobbying at the English court in persuading the English king to make any permanent settlement in Newfoundland illegal. That lasted until the year 1829. Notwithstanding that, from the early 1500s Newfoundland
February 19, 1992

became something else. It was fish, yes, and it is fish today. It means that. But from the early 1500s it came to mean something else. It came to mean home for increasing numbers of people.
Today, five centuries later, it means home for well over one million people. I include the 560,000 to 580,000 who live there today, as well as about 600,000 who were bom there but now live outside the confines of Newfoundland.
The interesting question is: why did the first people settle in Newfoundland? The answer is very simple: fish. In other terms, why did they settle there? Because they were doing what Newfoundlanders have always done and continue to do to this day. They were going where the jobs were. That is what brought them to Newfoundland. They were going where the jobs were. Even if that meant defying the established tradition, defying the vested interest, the corporate agendas and the political agendas they went where the jobs are and that practice has not changed.
Why is it that there are 100,000 native-born Newfoundlanders living in southern Ontario today, 80,000 in the Boston area, tens of thousands in the Los Angeles area, thousands in Fort McMurray, Alberta, and thousands more in Cambridge, Ontario, and why do hundreds of my constituents make the trek from Terrenceville, Bay EArgent and other communities every year to spend six, seven, or eight months working on the CP rails in Saskatchewan or B.C.? Why is it that hundreds of my constituents and others operate the boats on the Great Lakes every summer for several months a year? It is because they are doing what their ancestors did 500 years before them. They are going where the jobs are.
It is part of this debate-if you are influenced by some of the editorials of the last day or so-so let us put to rest this cowardly, sick notion that my countrymen, my fellow Newfoundlanders, are a bunch of lazy conniving, nogoods who sit up nights trying to figure out ways to con a few more bucks out of the taxpayers of central Canada so they can keep their 10-42 lifestyle in which they work for 10 weeks so they can sit back for the other 42. Let us put that one to rest.
Let us also put to rest that gem of political wisdom, that bit of gibberish which seems to be consuming the energies of the Ottawa policy makers and some of the armchair experts at the universities which say that what is happening in Newfoundland has always been the case. Yes, the fisheries have been up and down, but so has the auto industry, agriculture, and the oil industry. It is always the case that consumer demand or foreign competition or the weather will create fluctuations in any industry. Mark my word that what is happening in Newfoundland today is absolutely without precedent. It has never happened before, never before.
While we are at it, a third red herring that we should dispense with is the one the minister unwittingly got involved in the other day. It is that the fish have discovered a new game, a Newfoundland favourite. They are out, they are playing hide and seek. You cannot find them because they hid away on us. That is the latest one. Scientists could not find them. The fish have gone AWOL, absent without leave to use the military term.
Another quasi-military term comes to mind. They are not AWOL they have paid the supreme sacrifice. The scientists are looking in the wrong place. They ought to be looking in the bone yards, in the fish offal piles in Spain and Portugal, or on the dinner tables of western Europe. If the scientists want to find the fish that is where they are. The scientists have probably been looking in the wrong places.
Those scientists should also check the ice-pans of the north Atlantic and they will find there what the ever-increasing seal population has left because it cannot digest the codfish it has killed. Yes, seals are part of the problem. However, do not let that issue, while it has to be dealt with, distract you from the much larger culprit, which is foreign overfishing.
In conclusion, there is a solution and it is a clear solution. I never said easy but I did say clear. It is clear what must be done and done without delay. Before I come to that let me note that at least in theory there is a less complicated and a more desirable solution. Simply put, that solution would have the perpetrators, basically the Spanish and the Portuguese, of foreign overfishing stop their piracy. Tb that end, the minister to his credit and some of his colleagues have repeatedly taken the message to the European community that overfishing is taking a dreadful toll on our industry and our way of life.

February 19, 1992
My friend from St. John's East and I did likewise. We went over to Brussels, Madrid, and Lisbon and talked to all the right people and gave them the same message, as has my colleague from Gander-Grand Falls. We appealed to their common sense, their humanity, their pocket-books, and their enlightened self-interest. None of it worked, and it is not going to work.
The time for friendly persuasion, for gentle talk, and for after dinner cocktails is over on this one. It is absolutely over. It is not going to work. It will not work. Anybody who keeps saying so is dreaming in Technicolor. We acted in good faith and for a thank you we got kicked in the teeth.
The time has come to do what it is necessary to do: to look after our own backyard. Clearly the only solution is to set in motion the necessary train of events to extend Canada's jurisdiction to the nose and tail of the Grand Banks and the Flemish Cap.
I see you signalling, Mr. Speaker. I appreciate your indulgence. I would have wanted a minute or so to elaborate on this point, but the minister needs no education in what is involved in extending the jurisdiction. A number of things can be said about it, maybe at another time, but for the present I appeal to him, when he rises to speak, to address this particular situation. It is at the crux of the problem and of course in tandem is the political will of the Prime Minister to do something about it. These are at the crux of the problem and hold the answer to a solution which will redound to the minister's benefit, will save a way of life, and will save a very great national industry.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I congratulate the hon. member on his speech. It was a very good effort. There is quite a bit of it that I can certainly agree with.
We are speaking tonight about a serious problem. I must say that I have become disturbed in the last few days with the attitude that seems to be taken on the mainland of Canada in newspaper editorials and the like with reference to the situation in Newfoundland. It is most dispiriting.
We have had several hard blows in the last 10 or 12 days. One was the threat to the Hibernia project which is a chance for Newfoundland to diversify, to get high-technological development and to use the resource off our shores to which the Government of Canada has given tremendous assistance. To see almost general cheers go up in editorial boards across Canada, painting this as some kind of terrible megaproject the Government of Canada should never have been involved in and this effort to develop in Newfoundland and Labrador this undeveloped area as a besmirching and ignoble thing that the government did, is most disturbing.
I saw two asinine editorials in the Tbronto Globe and Mail, which is supposed to have the intellectual leaders of the country in its editorial ranks. I have sent them a letter today which I hope they are going to publish dealing with their pusillanimous, silly and ill thought out points they made in their alleged editorials. It is not just the Toronto Globe and Mail. It is across the country.
Timing to the blow to Hibernia, in my opinion it is going to survive. I have survived hundreds of disappointments with Hibernia and I am going to survive this other one. We are going to overcome it, no thanks to mainland editorial opinion.
In addition, we have this blow with respect to the state of the fish stocks and the northern cod. Newfoundland members understand what the northern cod means to Newfoundland. It is difficult for mainlanders and those not bom in Newfoundland perhaps to understand this.
The province was settled because of the presence of the northern cod. The area we are talking about, 2J-3K-L, extends from the end of my district in Trepas-sey, up around the Avalon peninsula on the north-east coast of Newfoundland, up through White Bay, up through Labrador to the north of Labrador. This is the area we are talking about. This is the principal fish. The reason why Newfoundland was settled was the presence of the northern cod.
To get this in context, Newfoundland is not finished. Because the northern cod stock is in danger does not mean to say Newfoundland is gone or that this is the whole fish stock of Newfoundland. This is a serious problem. I am not denigrating that, but the idea is getting around that the whole fishery of Newfoundland
February 19, 1992

is gone, that the whole fishery of Labrador is gone, and that the whole fishery of Atlantic Canada is gone. That is not the case. There are many other species of fish in Atlantic Canada and around the shores of Newfoundland. The south coast fishery is not the northern cod. The gulf fishery on the west coast is not the northern cod. This does not affect crab. It does not affect other species.
What I am terribly worried about is the negative reporting of the last few days. Who is going to invest a cent in Newfoundland if we allow this impression to continue that all is gone in Newfoundland and Labrador; we are finished; we have had it; there is nothing left; there is going to be no economic activity.
What can we expect of the banks? They are already pusillanimous enough. They already do not want to invest in the fishing industry. I ask hon. members to keep in mind that yes, this is a very serious problem we are discussing here.
We are not discussing the end of the fishery in Newfoundland and Labrador. We are not discussing the end of the fishery in Atlantic Canada, but we are discussing a serious threat to one of the main fisheries of Newfoundland and Labrador, the fishery that attracted settlers to Newfoundland and Labrador, the reason why there is a rural Newfoundland and Labrador. This is of course a very serious matter.
TUming to the northern cod, 90 per cent of the jobs from the northern cod are in Newfoundland. It is 46 per cent of all the available cod quotas. It is 21 per cent of all of the groundfish that might be caught in Newfoundland; 85 to 90 per cent of it is caught and processed in Newfoundland and Labrador. I am advised that 63 per cent of all Newfoundland fishermen and 69 per cent of all of the plant workers of Newfoundland and Labrador are located in 2J-3K-L.
The present crisis we are still dealing with started really at the end of 1988 when CAFSAC, the Canadian fisheries scientists, had taken over from the NAFO Scientific Council. It had done the work on the estimates of fisheries stocks up to 1986 and turned it over to Canadian scientists. At the end of 1988 the scientists advised us that there was a major change in their prognostications with respect to what the cod biomass
was for the northern cod. That is when our problem started.
In that year the total allowable catch for the northern cod had been set at 266,000 tonnes by the then minister. The scientists had recommended that if we kept to the fisheries management level of FO.l, the mortality rate based on FO.l, that we could take 16 to 20 per cent of the biomass of the fish stock in question, the TAC that year could have been 293,000 tonnes. The minister wanted to be on the cautious side so he had set a TAC of
266.000	tonnes.
At the end of that year, in December 1988, the scientists came back with a revision of their figures. They said they had concluded that the fish stocks, which had been brought to a low level by 1977 when a 200-mile zone was established, had not increased since that time by a measurement of five but had only increased by a measurement of three. Their estimates of the previous several years had been out. They said that if the measurement we wanted to apply for the following year was the management tool of FO.l, we could only take
125.000	tonnes of the northern cod.
In other words, this would be a decline from 293,000 tonnes that the scientists said was the proper TAC in 1988 to 225,000 tonnes in 1989. I do not think that any sensible government would have immediately gone from a TAC of 266,000 tonnes, which was the cautious figure we had set, to a TAC of 125,000 tonnes. It wiped out the industry overnight. It just about wiped it out completely overnight as a result.
The TAC was reduced for the year 1989 from 266,000 tonnes to 235,000 tonnes, which the scientific advisers said was a TAC that would not endanger the stock, that it would keep it at its then present biomass. It was safe to set that as a TAC. Dr. Leslie Harris and a group were appointed to review the whole situation. That is where the problem we are still dealing with originated.
Dr. Harris and his group did a very fine job and made their final report in February 1990.1 just want to set the record straight about what they recommended or did not recommend. The first recommendation was that in respect of the northern cod stock and as a matter or urgency there should be an immediate reduction of fishing mortality to the level of at least 0.30 and, at the

February 19, 1992
earliest feasible date, to the level of 0.20. Now 0.20 is the management tool FO.l. It allows us to take about 20 per cent of the then existing biomass.
Dr. Harris has always stressed that the scientific analysis is not sure enough, that we should be conservative and that it would be safe to go below whatever the scientist was recommending. Mr. Speaker, I can tell you-and I only have 20 minutes-that we have not set any total allowable catch in excess of what CAFSAC, our scientists, advised could be done. For example, in 1990 we set the TAC at 199,262 tonnes. In 1991 it was reduced again to 190,000 tonnes and a three-year plan was adopted so that in 1992 there would be a reduction to
185.000	tonnes and in 1993, to 180,000 tonnes.
In December 1991 I set the TAC for 1992 at 185,000 tonnes, which was in accordance with the scientific advice I was given. I was told by CAFSAC what would happen if we continued with our three-year plan. I will just read it:
The assessment suggests that the stock will increase faster than was forecast in last year's assessment largely because of the strength of the 1986 and 1987 year classes. It also implies that the FO.l target may also be reached in 1993.
They suggested that the existing multi-year management plan be maintained, and so I maintained it. That was December 23, 1991.
I wanted to have CAFSAC continue to look at the fall results of surveys and all the latest information to advise me again in February as to what they then thought in February to see if any changes were necessary. At the beginning of this week, as I made public, their figures have been revised and they now say that the biomass, instead of being 1,330 million tonnes as they thought it was in December, now looks to be 780,000 tonnes. The spawning biomass, which they had thought in December was in the area of 270,000 to 300,000 tonnes, was now
130.000	tonnes, in their view the lowest that it was in the last 30 years. The average spawning biomass in the last 30 years has been 290,000 tonnes.
The situation was far worse than was presented to me in the period leading up to December 1991. A decision has to be made as to what to do about this, and that is what we are debating here tonight. Obviously there is going to have to be some reduction in the total allowable catch for 1992 and there are going to have to be other measures taken. Apart altogether from the scientists, we
clearly have advice from the fishing companies and the fishermen that the fish stocks are not in the shape they should be in. We do not know what all the causes are.
Least year, despite the fact that the total allowable catch set was 190,000 tonnes, Canadians caught only
127,000	tonnes. The French caught 1,850 tonnes. The French are the only people who have any right to take a cod fish within the 200-mile economic zone of Canada. They have it because of a treaty entered into in 1972 and as the result of their past history in connection with St. Pierre and Miquelon and fishing in this area.
In the same period last year it is our estimate that the European Community took 47,000 tonnes of cod outside the 200-mile limit on the nose and tail of the banks. What is the nose and tail of the banks that people talk about? The nose and tail of the banks is a little area beyond the 200-mile economic zone where the continental shelf still extends. Down in this area is the tail and up in 3L is the nose of the banks. The codfish stocks are 95 per cent within the 200-mile economic zone of Canada and at different times during the year from 3 per cent to 5 per cent swim outside.
We have been unable to persuade the European Community, principally Spain and Portugal, to observe the conservation practices or the quotas allocated by NAFO, the international organization to which we and they belong which operates in this particular area of the northwest Atlantic. There has been a moratorium declared on the nose and tail of the banks by NAFO since 1986. However the European Community refuses to observe it. Last year it took 47,000 tonnes. Five or six years ago it took 61,000 tonnes out. This is our estimate, not what it is admitting and not what it reports as having taken.
I have not the time tonight to go into the Herculean diplomatic efforts we have made to persuade them to cease and desist and observe the quotas of NAFO. We have not been successful. I intend to have our Ambassador Gherson go to Brussels next week with some of our scientists to put before the Europeans the latest figures we have on the state of the northern cod, the results of the fishery of the last several years, and to request that they start to observe the moratorium declared by NAFO on the nose and tail of the banks with respect to 2J-3K-L cod.
February 19, 1992

Whether they will respond or not I do not know. I only hope that they will.
Our campaign with respect to this foreign overfishing is going to continue unrelentingly during 1992 both with respect to public relations work in the countries of the European Community and a resolution we have before the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development setting out what the rights of the coastal state should be with respect to straddling stocks that are both within and without the economic zone of that coastal state, because the present law of the sea is tremendously ambiguous and does not set out the rights of the coastal state.
My hon. friend, during the course of his remarks, said that the Prime Minister did not have the political will to deal with this question. That is simply not true. The Prime Minister, together with the Minister for International Trade, the Secretary of State for External Affairs and myself, in several guises as a minister, has spent many hours discussing this situation with the leading politicians and ministers of Spain and Portugal in the European Community and asking them to rectify it. That will continue and it will be stepped up during this year.
At the UNCED meeting in New York in March our resolution will be pressed and in Rio de Janeiro in June the same action will take place. We intend to ask for a conference of the countries involved in high seas fishing during the year. We have asked for a special session of NAFO to be held in connection with surveillance and enforcement matters, that will be held in March.
Today, I had the Ambassador from South Korea in to see me because certain non-NAFO countries are also fishing on the nose and tail of the banks, South Korea and Panama in particular. The Panamanian vessels are owned by Spanish and Portuguese owners; they are flags of convenience.
The South Korean Ambassador has advised me that as a result of meetings I had in Korea earlier, in excess of a year ago, and the representations we have made, the Korean government is withdrawing one of its licensed vessels from the area now and will be withdrawing another one by the end of the year or the first half of
1993.	It has instructed unlicensed vessels, which are vessels not licensed by the Korean government but owned by Koreans, to withdraw from the NAFO area
during the first half of this year. It has instructed third country vessels that have Korean crews to do the same. Some progress is being made with respect to that matter.
Our problem is not simply foreign overfishing. There is no point in our believing that just the cessation of overfishing is going to solve our problem. It is far more involved than that. We have to deal with the question of what is happening to the stocks of capelin which the cod feed on.
We have to deal with the question of seals, because whether they eat cod or do not eat cod they certainly eat capelin. If there are no capelins it is going to be very difficult to find cod. That is a question related to this issue, as well.
We have to get more information about the environment and environmental factors and how they affect the presence or actions of cod, capelin and other fish. We have to do more work on that. There are a lot of new initiatives which we have taken that we have to continue.
We have to try to look after those people who are going to be affected by possible fish plant closures or a possible lack of fishing activity. I intend to be in Newfoundland tomorrow to meet with interested groups on Friday and I hope and expect I will announce what steps we should take, commencing on Monday.
In dealing with this question you can be assured, and Newfoundland fishermen can be assured, that we are not taking steps which are going to directly affect the traditional inshore Newfoundland fisherman using traditional methods to catch fish, who is not a mobile fisherman and cannot move 50 miles, 100 miles or 200 miles to fish. I have that very much in my mind. That will be a principle of the action I intend to announce, hopefully next Monday.
In addition to the actions I will announce next Monday there will be other actions in the fisheries management areas announced from time to time. It makes it easier to understand the difficulty fisheries managers have when you see one of our scientists today saying, as quoted in the St. John's Evening Telegram, that: "The calculations of a scientist can be off by 25 per cent either way when they are calculating stock size." That is a fact. I have to try to manage the fishery being told one thing, which I recited to you in December 1991, and getting entirely different information seven weeks later.

February 19, 1992
