speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
I am not trying to allege or suggest that there is anything wrong with the skills or qualifications of our scientists. It is just the nature of the beast that they are tackling. Present methods do not allow them to have a higher accuracy level than within these parameters which I have just quoted from the newspaper.
During the last several years we have put in place a number of programs, and will certainly be continuing the same kind of program, to try to help to diversify within the fishery and try to create employment and diversification outside the fishery.
A fisheries alternatives program is operated by ACOA. lb summarize, since its inception in 1990 some 575 projects have been approved at a cost of $41.9 million creating 1,547 new jobs in the rural areas affected by the diminution of fish stocks. In the province of Newfoundland there have been 485 projects approved and 1,356 jobs created to try to take account of and replace those jobs that have been lost. We have an economic diversification program under the Department of Fisheries to try to assist diversification within the fishery which will continue. Under that program $19.1 million has been approved for various projects in 1990-1991 and
1991-1992 which has enabled us to keep operating fish plants in Canso and Burgeo and at Grand Bank. Hopefully there will be others. This program has assisted us in starting a number of new businesses in rural areas of Atlantic Canada and of Newfoundland. This kind of program will continue to assist while this particular crisis is upon us.
Mr. Speaker, I did not know I had taken longer than two minutes. This is a very serious problem to cover in 20 minutes. I hope you will excuse me if I have gone a couple of minutes over.
I am pleased to be the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans at this time. What is the point of being Minister of Fisheries and Oceans when everything is going swimmingly and there are no problems because even then on all sides you are assailed because of the conflicting interests in the fishery. But I am pleased to have the opportunity to help my fellow Newfoundlanders and Labradorians in this crisis. I will make every effort I can to resolve this crisis fairly and equitably and get all the assistance I possibly can from the Government of Canada in that direction.
I look forward to the help of my colleagues opposite in that task. Do not be too harsh in your criticism of the government, but keep the pressure on it for the future. What happened in the past or who made an error or a mistake or who was wrong-I can cite instances against the previous government and you can cite instances against this government. We have to keep our eye on the ball and see that the proper action is taken now to help our province through.
I am completely non-partisan in this matter. We have to keep our eye on the ball and see what we can do to help overcome the serious problem. It is not the end of the province of Newfoundland and Labrador. It is not even near the end. There are a lot of opportunities in Newfoundland and Labrador yet and we have to counteract this terrible miasma of propaganda and ignorance that has spread across the mainland in the last 10 days since our difficulties with Hibernia and with this particular news.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George - Bulkley Valley):
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess it is a pleasure to participate in this debate tonight on behalf of the New Democratic Party and, in particular, on behalf of our critic in this particular field, the member for Nanaimo-Cowichan.
I find it a particularly important debate tonight because it is a debate about people, it is a debate about their livelihoods, and it is a debate about people in their communities.
People throughout Newfoundland and Labrador and, indeed, Atlantic Canada are watching tonight and hoping for some assurance from Parliament and from the Government of Canada that there is a message and a signal for the people of that area who have suffered so much. In fact, as important as this emergency debate is tonight, I wonder if the people of Atlantic Canada are not getting a bit tired of being the subject of yet another emergency debate and if it would not be such a bad idea
February 19, 1992

if maybe for once Atlantic Canada was not on the news because the news has not been good.
When we see the news from that particular region about the number of lay-offs and job losses we know how much that is hurting. We had the Hibernia project mentioned as well as Sears Canada in Halifax, 656 part-time jobs; Stone Consolidated; Dominion Textile in Yarmouth; Rio Algom, the list goes on. It is because of the approach, dare I say, we have had from previous administrations and this particular government in allowing the so-called free market to dominate. That free market is really supposed to determine with an invisible hand just what direction the economy is going to go. Piled on that are the problems in the forest industry. Tonight we are debating the fishing industry but piled on that are the problems from this government, the goods and services tax, free trade, and now the mention from the Government of New Brunswick about user fees in health care. The bad news piles up.
Perhaps people were hoping for something from the minister. I must say that I think there is some disappointment in his comments tonight. We were generous in allowing him some extra time. We are hopeful that his announcement on Monday will go some distance to giving some good news to the people of Newfoundland and Labrador and Atlantic Canada. We did not get any news tonight, we got a recitation of the problem. I think what the minister owed us tonight was a sense of his awareness and to give some assurance to the people on the east coast that the Government of Canada is concerned about their future.
We did not get that tonight so I think there is probably some disappointment. It raises the stakes, if you like, and the minister is very good at that. He is raising the stakes to see just exactly what kind of news he gets or he can provide on Monday. Let us hope it is some good news.
All we have to do is look at the importance of the fisheries resource in Atlantic Canada, and in particular the northern cod resource in Newfoundland and Labrador. We are talking about some $700 million worth of industry in 1991. The fishing industry supports some
31,000	jobs in Atlantic Canada, 90 per cent of them in Newfoundland. The minister, in talking about it, said that is what made Newfoundland and Labrador. Well, we in other parts of the country understand that. It is the three "F"s I have talked about here-our farms, our
forests and our fish. We come from communities that have relied on the three "F"s. Tonight we are talking about fish but tomorrow it will be about forests and the next day, on Friday, it is going to be about farms.
That is why this debate is so important, because in those people's homes tonight we are talking about their livelihood and their future.
I congratulate the member for bringing this debate forward tonight and I want to outline on behalf of our party, the New Democrats, the program we have developed. It is a quick, four-point program, and I would like to see how the minister measures up against that when he makes his announcement on Monday.
Of course all of this comes from the decision or the recommendation that the catch is going to have to be reduced dramatically or we are in serious trouble. We are in serious trouble now. We are not talking lightly. We are talking about a possible watershed, the future possible shutdown of an industry, and thousands and thousands of jobs.
This recommendation to the minister is not new. In 1988 the Canada-Newfoundland Inshore Fisheries Agreement had this to say: "That with few exceptions the fishery resources of the Atlantic have reached their maximum utilization and in some cases there is an indication that over exploitation is occurring". That comment was made in 1988.
In 1989 scientists indicated that their previous estimates of stocks strength were overestimated. They recommended a dramatic reduction be made immediately-
In 1990 Dr. Harris, who has been mentioned before, in a study commissioned by the government, confirmed what the scientists had discovered. Indeed, he stated publicly that "the reduction in the total allowable catch should move from 265,000 tonnes to 90,000 tonnes".
The crisis in the fishery was best expressed in a draft document circulated at the Atlantic Groundfish Advisory Council meeting on Monday. In 1991 the TAC for northern cod was set at 190,000 tonnes. Only 127,000 tonnes were actually caught. The inshore fishery was "the worst since 1976, with only 67,000 tonnes caught". Further evidence regarding the government and the previous government, when I referred to the 1983 Kirby report that had been mentioned previously, identified what the problem was.

February 19, 1992
I know tonight there is an attempt to set a tone that we were going to be non-partisan and not point figures. Fair enough. We will not point fingers but some have to accept responsibility.
The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans mentioned yesterday about 2,000 jobs-and that is a conservative estimate and about the future of how many people's jobs will be affected by this decision and by what he is going to say on Monday.
In fact, the First Ministers' Conference of 1989 was told that the collapse of the fishery could result in some
6,000	jobs that would be lost. In the case of Ontario, if we were to use the same measurement, we are talking about a loss of some 115,000 jobs.
The government's own Employment and Immigration Advisory Council in 1990, its vision and view of the Atlantic fishery said: "Hundreds of Atlantic communities will lose their only industry. Thousands of families left without adequate incomes will be forced to rely on welfare or to uproot their lives for the dubious promise of mainland wealth". That is from the government's own report.
Let us in the short time we have tonight take a chance to review the four-point plan that our party, the New Democrats, is suggesting. I know the minister will take notes on this and I hope we can measure that against his announcement on Monday.
I preface that outline with the comments that were made just yesterday by our party's leader in Newfoundland and Labrador, Mr. Newhook, who called on the Prime Minister to take a personal initiative in the face of this worsening situation.
It has been mentioned earlier how the Prime Minister when he has a problem at hand gets directly involved. In some cases he just calls George and they straighten out the problem.
Look at the problem we have now. It is time for the Prime Minister to take that personal initiative, to take hold of this problem and address it immediately, and for this government to address the problem of the northern cod fishery immediately.
What are we taking a look at in the four point action plan? The first point, and perhaps the most important point, is that this government should move immediately to assume fisheries management jurisdiction over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks effectively terminating foreign overfishing. We have a main reason for that.
We are talking about the conservation of a resource. It is an environmental emergency. Measures should be taken. We take up and accept the offer and the suggestion made by the minister of fisheries in Newfoundland and Labrador that this minister should give the international community its notice that as of January 1, 1993 Canada will take charge of that particular area.
That is the message that should be delivered in Brussels. This country has a moral obligation to restore not only the fish stocks but also to ensure the future viability of Canadian fishing communities.
If Newfoundlanders and Atlantic Canadians are prepared to make the necessary sacrifices, they must not be asked to bear the burden while foreign fleets continue to operate with impunity.
We should treat this as importantly as Canada has treated the debate about Arctic sovereignty. This government has not done the best of jobs in taking care of our sovereignty in the Arctic, but it has done virtually nothing to take care of sovereignty in this particular area. That is most important. That is the number one part of an action plan to resolve this problem.
The second point is that we must define the priorities for the future and what kind of fishery we want. Will it be corporate based or community based? If we choose the latter, we must move in conjunction with industry, labour and the provincial governments. The minister has mentioned that, putting in place the long-term strategy to achieve that objective and developing new fishing technologies which are not destructive of the ocean's ecology. A strategy which has as its premise of sustainable development.
February 19, 1992

There are fine words in the government's green plan about attempting to deal with the fish stocks.
I do not know if the minister has read the green plan. Perhaps he should take a second look at it to see that even the goals in this plan are upheld, because if we continue at the pace that we are going, they will not be. We will be in even greater trouble.
The third part of the action plan is to ensure and to watch that those communities, those people in those homes who are watching tonight at the very least, at the bottom line as Mr. Newhook said in his comments, get assistance to take care of those people who may lose their livelihood. Let us hope that that is not the case. As a bottom line, that is government's job as I see it.
In recognition that the offshore fishery could be shut down with job losses reaching between 3,000 and 6,000 people, the federal and provincial governments must be prepared to bring forward programs, perhaps on a level not seen before, of ensuring that thousands of families are not forced to go down the road in search of a future.
There is an old adage about how in war we always seem to be able to find the money, the energy and the effort. During the recent gulf war this government mobilized some $650 million for a six-month period. Under the adjustment program of this government we are talking about a figure of some $584 million over five years in five provinces.
If this is not a national emergency, it is one the government must put the same effort into to mobilize economic resources and government resources to ensure that the people in those fishing communities in particular are guaranteed and do have a future.
Those people want to make a livelihood in the fishing industry. They want to live in their homes and their communities, and they want to have a future there.
The fourth point in the New Democratic action plan is an important one. It is a point that is especially important given some of the debate now on the Constitution. It relates, of course, to the questions around the economic union and some of the necessary rules and
regulations that may be needed to protect some of those resources themselves.
We suggest close examination of that particular part of the constitutional package that will give some of those provinces some ability to ensure that they can manage those cases themselves.
In proposing and making suggestions tonight, we spent some time laying out some thoughts so that we have something to measure against what the minister will have to say on Monday.
We have taken this debate seriously enough to consider and lay out some suggestions and not to use the opportunity just to point fingers and blame Conservatives who perhaps duly should have that blame.
In conclusion, in this very important debate we are having tonight about just how important this issue is to Newfoundland and Labrador and to Atlantic Canada we must take a look at the people and their future there. That is my interest in this debate because it is an interest that I think is from coast to coast to coast.
How do we deal with those people who live in resource communities, dependent on our farms, our fish and our forests, if we continue to be the hewers of wood and drawers of water, we will always be or seen to be certainly under Canada-U.S. free trade?
We have talked about the fisheries resource but there is another resource. Perhaps it is the most important resource of all. I am talking about the resource of our people in Atlantic Canada.
As an example, I spoke tonight about young people. Of the pages who serve us in this House tonight, there are some nine who are from Atlantic Canada. I talked to a few of them tonight about their future. Do they have a future? Will they go back home to Atlantic Canada?
I think that is a message that we hope they will take in earnest, that they will go home, back to Atlantic Canada and help develop that area. I know that is a difficult one for them. It is a difficult one for all the young people of Atlantic Canada and it is difficult for everyone in those communities.
I encourage and hope that the minister, when he makes his decisions on Monday, has those communities

February 19, 1992
in mind and makes sure that he makes the right decision for the people of Atlantic Canada and the right decision for the people of Newfoundland and Labrador.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
On a point of order, just to forewarn the Chair that under Standing Order 43(2) members of our party will be dividing their time accordingly, 10 minutes each for the remainder of the debate.
I hope that the Chair will recognize that my colleague from Newfoundland was the individual who moved the emergency debate and I hope that the rotations will be in accordance with that.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to rise and participate in this debate this evening.
I would like to thank you, Mr. Speaker, for making possible this emergency debate on a topic that is critically important to the people of Atlantic Canada. Indeed, as has been said by some other members here, this should be a problem and concern for all Canadians.
I want to address five points in my remarks tonight. I want to talk about what has happened. I want to talk about why it has happened. I want to talk about who is to blame for what has happened because we have heard much about that. I want to talk about what we can do about it and a little bit about what we should not do about it.
Quite clearly, the single most important fishery stock on the east coast of Canada is in very serious trouble. In Atlantic Canada 35,000 jobs depend upon that stock and it is a grave, serious situation, particularly for the province of Newfoundland and Labrador, but also I should say for other provinces in Atlantic Canada, including my own and including the province of Quebec.
But we should not over-dramatize the situation. Not all fishery stocks in Atlantic Canada are in trouble, not the whole fishery in Atlantic Canada is in trouble. Indeed, many of our fisheries have never been in better health than they are right now and let us not over-dramatize the situation. Let us focus on what, in fact, is the problem.
The scientists have said that they miscalculated. In 1988, at the time when the TAC for northern cod was at
266,000	tonnes, they came to the minister of the day and
said: "Minister, somehow the numbers are not correct". They urged a vast and an immediate reduction.
The minister immediately reduced that stock to
235,000	tonnes and called upon a special task force to do a serious study of the situation to try to assess what it should be.
Dr. Harris and his colleagues reported and in consequence of that report the stocks were further dramatically and substantially reduced by the minister of the day. I might say it was not with the overwhelming approval of my hon. friends opposite, many of whom criticized the minister of the day and said: "You are putting people out of work". The minister of the day knew that.
Once again the scientists have come to the minister of today and have said: "You have to reduce that stock immediately by 25,000 tonnes over the next few months". In effect they have said: "Close the offshore northern cod fishery until June and then we will have a look at it and see what is going to happen".
That is a serious situation. It is going to directly impact at least three plants in Newfoundland and possibly one in my own province of Nova Scotia. It is going to mean up to 2,000 people, plant workers being laid off. It could mean up to 400 trawlermen being laid off. We have already just last week had 1,000 people laid off by FPI at Catalina. It is a serious situation and we have to ask ourselves: How did we get in this situation? I have heard my hon. friends opposite.
The hon. gentleman who opened the debate tonight said the whole thing is the Prime Minister's fault. Is it not interesting? Everything that happens in this country seems to be the Prime Minister's fault.
Last year the fishery in the Newfoundland was devastated because of ice. I suppose that was the Prime Minister's fault as well. Let us take a look. There is all kinds of blame to be shared by those who are less interested in solving the problem and more interested in determining who is to blame. Let us look at who is to blame.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: The Prime Minister is.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
There is climate. There is the food chain, seals, fishing technology, inaccurate scientific data, foreign overfishing and yes, maybe there is bad
February 19, 1992

management, but we will come to that and draw our own conclusion when the time comes.
Let us look at climate for example. Everybody knows that 1991 was the most extraordinary year for bad weather and ice conditions in Newfoundland's history. We heard the hon. member for Labrador yesterday talking about the community of Black Tickle where not a single fish was caught in 1991.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
I recognize that my friend from South Shore was not in the Chamber when the debate began and when the minister of fisheries and I spoke, so he might not have captured the spirit of the debate. We are here looking for some answers.
Could I appeal to him not to turn this into a circus because it is a very serious issue affecting a lot of people in my riding and elsewhere.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: I do not think that was a point of order. The hon. member for South Shore has the floor.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
As I said, I certainly would love to avoid partisanship here, but I was at Question Period today and yesterday, so let us talk about what I was talking about.
I talked about the ice conditions and climate being part of this problem. We have to recognize that.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: Well do something about it.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
I think my hon. friend from Burin-St. George's ought to talk to his colleagues over there.
Let us talk about the capelin stock. Cod fish feed on the capelin. The capelin stocks have been very low. As a matter of fact in the 1991 season, the Russians had difficulty finding any at all and they are the only people who have ever fished that capelin. The reduction in their catches had nothing to do with overfishing because they have never had a quota that exceeded 13 per cent of the TAC of capelin. Capelin has always been a variable stock but it has always been a harvestable stock and there has been plenty of it. Why the disappearance in 1991? Quite simply, we do not know. Perhaps it had to do with cold water. Perhaps it had to do with unusual distributions. The bottom line is that for whatever reason the capelin is
not there, and that has obviously impacted on the cod stocks.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: Blame it on the seals.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Then we come to the seals. The member for South West Nova wants to talk about seals. It is interesting that scientists say they do not know what the score is on the seals and what impact they have. I will tell you the fishermen know. The fishermen in my area can tell you about seals and the fishermen in Newfoundland can tell you about seals. The fact is that in 1983 the Europeans destroyed our seal hunt. I cannot remember who was in government then but perhaps my hon. friends opposite can. The seal population at that time was about 2 million. Today it is 3.5 million because the seal hunt was destroyed.
It is said that the average seal eats 1.5 tonnes of fish per year. If you multiply that out it means that the amount of fish eaten by seals increased by 1.8 million tonnes per year, or 3.6 billion pounds of fish. That has to have something to do with why cod fish stocks are down.
Fishing technology is another possible factor. The fact of the matter is that our fishermen are a lot better than they were because they have better technology. It is not that the fishermen of today are any more skilled than the fishermen of days gone by. They have better equipment and can find the fish a lot easier than they could then. So naturally their harvesting effort is a lot more productive. This has to be a factor in the situation.
Then we can talk about scientific advice. If you are in government it is an easy thing to blame the scientists for wrong advice. It is true the minister can only act on the advice he is given and if he is given bad advice it may well lead to bad decisions. The fact of the matter is that it is not fair to blame the scientists. This is a very difficult challenge. This government, through its commitment to dealing with this problem, has more than doubled the amount of money made available for science in studying the northern cod stocks. The bottom line is there will never be enough resources. The only way you can ever count the number of cod fish in the ocean is to drain the ocean and count them. It is not really practical to do that. You cannot blame the scientists. You have to recognize that it is always going to be an inexact science and at best it is going to be a difficult challenge.

February 19, 1992
Then we come to the next possible villain and we are getting down to the core of it here. We are talking about the impact of the Europeans in overfishing. There are two issues of overfishing that are significant. I am afraid that some of my hon. friends, having heard what I have heard in this House for the last couple of days, get very confused about the impact of foreign fishing in the North Atlantic on the northern cod stocks. There is fishing that goes on inside the 200-mile Canadian zone and there is fishing that goes on outside the 200-mile Canadian zone. The difference is that we control what goes on inside. We are accountable unequivocally and unquestionably.
We have had the destruction, or the apparent destruction, of the 2J-3K-L cod stock which is a trans-boundaiy stock. Where is the problem there? We hear my hon. friends opposite speak about the vessels that are licensed to fish inside Canadian waters. We have heard some suggest this is the source and cause of the problem. Let us take a hard look at it. How many tonnes of cod fish are Europeans licensed to catch inside the Canadian 200-mile zone? The answer is 2000 tonnes. This stock has declined from the point where the TAC was 266,000 in 1988. The minister is now being told to drop it somewhere into the low 100-plus tonnes, and we have 2000 tonnes allocated to the French. This is supposed to be the source of the problem. Well, no, not at all.
Our hon. friends talk about allocations of witch, plaice, and various types of flounder. This apparently is the source of the problem. That is not the source of the problem. Interestingly enough, the foreigners were licensed some years ago to come into our waters. It was in the period of 1981 to 1986 that the EC was given a long-term agreement which gave it access to 45,000 metric tons of northern cod over five years. In 1972 the government of my hon. friends opposite made an allocation of three million metric tons of cod fish inside the gulf to France in a five-year period.
This government had the wisdom to conclude an interim agreement to France that brought the rampant cod fishing by France under control to the point that this year France will probably catch less than 2,000 tonnes. My hon. friends opposite may wish to talk about foreign vessels fishing in Canadian waters as the problem, but the reality is it has absolutely nothing to do with the northern cod.
I might just say, as a digression, that foreign vessels inside Canadian waters are very much to the benefit of Canadian fish plant workers. Ask the people in Canso and Burgeo. One thousand Canadians are employed because of the deal made by this government to exchange silver hake and capelin for cod fish. That has put Canadians back to work. Is it the policy of my hon. friends opposite that those fish plants in Canso and Burgeo should be closed? It is the same with respect to silver hake allocations under joint agreements between Canadian and foreign companies which make use of resources that Canadians would leave in the water, provide a market for Canadians to sell fish back to those foreigners, and provide work for Canadian fish plant workers. No, the problem has nothing to do with the licensing of foreigners to fish inside Canadian waters.
However it has a great deal to do with illegal, rapacious, unenvironmental, and destructive fishing by Europeans outside the 200-mile zone on the 2J-3K-L cod stock. One need only look at the level of non-co-operation that has come from the Europeans. Although they are members of NAFO, each year they ignore the NAFO assigned quotas. They unilaterally give themselves a quota and then proceed to go out and catch every cod fish they can. The story is that in 1991 they caught upwards of 47,000 tonnes of fishery for which they were assigned a quota of absolutely zero.
I find it shocking that European environmentalists have the gall to talk about environmental problems in Canada, to talk about whether or not we harvest seals, to talk about how we harvest our forests, and they look the other way. I have talked to Greenpeace and parliamentarians in Europe. They look the other way at this environmental problem. We as Canadians should not be talking about what this government or the government in Newfoundland did or anything else. We can all stand united on the issue that this is outrageous and unacceptable.
The question is, can the Government of Canada do anything about it?

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: Of course they can.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
My hon. friends opposite say of course they can. Well the government can meet with the Europeans and say this must stop. It can work with them co-operatively and try to persuade them, but the bottom line is that if it is international waters, it is their right to do whatever they want unless there is co-operation. My
February 19, 1992

hon. friends opposite have suggested we should ignore the International Law of the Sea Convention of 1973. We should throw away our 200-mile zone and unilaterally say that we are moving out and taking over, just as Saddam Hussein did with Kuwait. He said he was moving in and taking over. He had no legal right to do it but he did.
My hon. friend opposite from the NDP suggested we should unilaterally push it out. There is no international law that allows it. We face the possibility that the rest of the world will revoke recognition of our 200 miles and come in and take it all. Or maybe my hon. friends opposite say the solution is to send out the navy and start sinking ships. Is that what they are suggesting?
We have to deal with this in a realistic practical way. There are many people who can be blamed for this problem if you want to. If you want to ignore all those reasons I have given and blame the minister of fisheries or the Prime Minister go right ahead. But having done that ask yourself: How do we solve the problem?
I want to tell you the first way to solve this problem is by having a minister of fisheries and a government that has the courage to do the right thing and see that those stocks do come back. They must have the courage to face up to the fact that we are going to have to close down that fishing for some period of time. They must also have the courage and integrity to put programs into place that are going to help these people get over this time as they have done before, as they did last year with the ice problem and as they did when they brought in the Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program with $584 million. To my NDP colleague that is a pittance, but it is a lot of money to us and has created jobs in my riding, in all of Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and other parts of Atlantic Canada. That is the kind of proper, intelligent, courageous response.
I look to this minister to show leadership in dealing with the seal problem. We are going to have to tell the Europeans that maybe it is time we started shooting more seals. That is the only way to deal with the problem and if they do not like it that is their problem. We are going to have to get more aggressive with the Europeans.
Perhaps it is time for us to react in the Icelandic way and go out there and rough them up a little bit if that is what it takes. It is not the proper thing to do, but we have to protect the Canadian interests.
Now what should we not do? There are two things we should not do. We should not panic. We hear people across suggesting we should panic about this, that Atlantic Canada is collapsing around us and it is "woe is me" everywhere. This is not the case. We have a serious crisis and a serious problem with one fish stock that impacts greatly on Newfoundland and to a lesser extent on other areas. This government must deal with it and this government will deal with it, but we do not want to take the entire fishery. Let us not take the silver hake plan let us not take the turbot plan let us not deal with tuna or lobsters. Those things each have their appropriate place. They are developing as fisheries. They are going to create jobs for Atlantic Canadians in the future as they have in the past.
We have a problem with northern cod. We must deal with northern cod. Thank goodness at this time in our history we have the minister we do today. He is a man who is sensitive to Newfoundlanders and to Atlantic Canadians, a man who is intelligent and understands the issues and the complexities of the fishery. He is a man who has the courage to do what is right, a man who has the ability and toughness to stand at the cabinet table, a man who is not afraid of the opposition or the labour unions. He is a man who is going to solve this problem for Newfoundlanders and for Canadians.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have listened to the speeches that have been made here tonight. I want to congratulate my colleague from Burin-St. George's. I also want to thank the minister for the information that he has passed on. The member for Prince George-Bulkley Valley spoke a lot about the fishery. I am not really sure what he said.
I could have sworn that the last speaker from South Shore was speaking from this side of the House. He had a lot to say about the ills of the fishery. He hit the problem which has been skirted around for the last few minutes, but then he did not say what he could do about it. I have to remind him that he is on the government

February 19, 1992
side and it does have a responsibility for taking some action.
I do not take any pleasure in talking here this evening. Normally I do in this House. There are any number of subjects that I would rather speak on.
I want to put a human face on this. I want to speak directly to the problem and I want to suggest a solution. The human face is that I come from a riding which I boast is the biggest fishing riding in Canada. I have not been challenged on this yet. The fact of the matter is I have 57 fish plants. Two days from now on Friday evening the largest plant and one of the most up to date, if not the most up to date plant, is going to close. Eight hundred and fifty people are going to walk out that gate, 155 trawlermen are going to stop work, and they expect to go back in anywhere from two and a half to three and a half months. I hope they will but they are not sure. Their company is not sure and I am not sure.
We are talking tonight about the northern cod stock, 2J-3K-L, that forms a large percentage of the Newfoundland fishery, of the Canadian Atlantic fishery. Yes, there are variables, all kinds of them, plus or minus 25 per cent the scientists tell us. The Labrador current will change. The temperatures will change. The fish migrate.
I want to talk about one aspect. It is the aspect that causes me the most frustration but it is an aspect for which we have the figures and it is an aspect about which something can be done. I have made-I counted them tonight before I came here-20 speeches making that recommendation. You have heard me make some of them, Mr. Speaker.
These are the figures. The northern cod stock until about the 1960s was basically caught by the inshore fishermen. Because of technology and the size of trawlers and those kinds of things the catch of that particular stock of cod reached a peak in 1968 when 815,000 tonnes were caught.
I would remind the House that one tonne of fish works out to about 35 jobs. Every time I say one tonne, it means 35 jobs.
Last year we went from 815,000 tonnes to 127,000 tonnes. That is a reduction of 85 per cent. There are any number of reasons why this happened. I want to take one
aspect and that aspect has to be a large part of the problem.
We have talked about NAFO, we have talked about the European Community, and we have talked about overfishing. Two years after this government came to power an allocation of 9,500 tonnes was made to the European Community. It took four and a half times that amount, 30 per cent of what the Canadians took. The next year it had another allocation of 9,500 tonnes and it took 20 per cent of what the Canadians took, 35,000 tonnes. The next year it had no allocation and it took
26.000	tonnes.
What was the government doing about it? Up to now, nothing. The member for Gander-Grand Falls was complaining about overfishing. This government denied there was a problem.
Let me take you to the next year, Mr. Speaker. There was no allocation and they took 35,000 tonnes. What did the government do? It started to talk. It started to enter into diplomatic discussions. It started to send politicians off to the European Community.
Last year, and we you have heard the figures before, the European Community with no allocation caught
47.000	tonnes, the second largest in 15 years, a 100 per cent increase from the year before, while Canadian fishermen took roughly 50 per cent of what they took before, 127,000 tonnes.
The conclusion is that we have known figures. We do not need the scientific plus or minus 25 per cent. We know we have a problem and we know we have to do something about it. Time has run out. Time has stopped for talking, cajoling, coaxing and diplomatic missions. The time has come for the Prime Minister to get personally involved and for this government to do something about it.
The hon. member for South Shore said that you cannot just go outside the 200 miles and do what you want. I would remind this House that in my lifetime, the control of the ocean has gone from three miles, because that was the range of a cannon, and when a cannon became obsolete it moved out to 12 miles, because that was the range that high definition warning radar could pick up an average vessel in a certain sea state-I think it was sea state 3-and then it moved out to 200 miles
February 19, 1992

because people found that there were nodules, there was oil, and there were lots of fish out to that limit, generally speaking, the continental shelf of most countries.
Canada happens to be the second largest country in the world, with the world's largest continental shelf.
When the limit was three miles it was said that we would never be able to get beyond that. We are out to 200 miles now. Anybody who says that cannot be done does not understand international marine law, or does not particularly want to. The difference between international marine law and civil law-the Saddam Husseins and taking over another country-is that it has been recognized that unilateral action creates a precedent in international marine law and it can be done providing there are certain things that accompany it.
First off, there has to be a good reason and when you are looking at the livelihood of a section of your country, then I think that is a pretty good reason.
You have to be able to support it and enforce it. I would suggest that with the record that our navy had in the gulf war-it had 3 per cent of the force and it did 25 per cent of the interdictions- it is quite capable of enforcement. Then you have got to send your bureaucrats and your politicians out to speak out on this subject. Then, you have an action plan. You are doing something about it.
This is not the first time the minister has heard this. It is not the first time members have heard it. I have mentioned it 20 times in this House. Dr. Harris of the Harris report mentioned it in recommendation number 5. It was a Liberal policy platform, page 22, recommendation 10, in 1988. Premier Wells is now saying it; Mr. Carter, the Minister of Fisheries in Newfoundland, is saying it; Mr. Cashin, the head of the Fishermen's Union in Newfoundland, is saying it; and pretty soon everybody will be saying it except the government. When will it be able to say it? What is it afraid of? Why will it not do it?
In 1948 the Truman declaration was a unilateral declaration for the United States to take control of their mineral rights and fish out to 200 miles. It took a while for it to take effect. In 1974 a little country, Greenland, with a minuscule navy, took on the Royal Navy, the British Navy, and won its case in the International Court of Law, by a unilateral declaration because somebody
else was catching the fish that caused the livelihood of its people to shrink. Canada did it in 1977.
So we are not inventing something here. We are not doing something that has never been done before. We are suggesting a precedent that has precedents in law, can be done, has been done, and should be done.
As I wrap up my thoughts here this evening, I find it very hard to explain why the government that has a problem, knows what the solution is, is not doing it. I find it very hard to explain to the plant workers in the FPI plant on the border of Port Union and Catalina that this action is not being taken, an action that could ensure that they go back to work and that they will not be on unemployment insurance, and the other 56 plants in my riding, will not be taken.
With all the enthusiasm that I have, and I know that I am joined by my party in this, we are urging this government to pack up the nonsense, to get rid of the fuzz, stop the talking, and let us get on with some action to do something that is meaningful, helpful, and will help save the lives and the dignity of those people who are affected.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to begin by thanking the Speaker of the House of Commons for recognizing, at the request of the member for Burin-St. George's, that the situation in Atlantic Canada, specifically the situation confronting Newfoundland and Labrador, is indeed an emergency.
It is an emergency that requires the attention of the House of Commons of Canada. It is an emergency that can be defined as being in the national interest. It is an emergency that justifies the quite extraordinary, and Canadians should realize the unusual and rare decision of a Speaker to grant a request by a member for the holding of an emergency debate.
It is important to point that out because it seems to me that in very large measure what we, from Atlantic Canada, and we from Newfoundland and Labrador, have to face every time we debate this matter is the disbelief, the misunderstanding in many quarters and regrettably too often in this House, certainly sometimes across this country, that the fishing issue, the question of the 200-mile limit, the responsibility for conservation of the

February 19, 1992
fish stock, the responsibility for policing, patrolling and managing Canadian waters is not a regional issue.
It is not a Newfoundland issue. It is an issue of national interest and national importance. It is an issue that speaks to and defines in part the sovereignty of a nation. Tonight we are not speaking to fishermen, to plant workers who feel in great peril in their homes. Tonight we are speaking to our fellow Canadians and we are asking our fellow Canadians to bring the moral weight of their intrinsic sense of what is right to bear on a government that has refused to stand up and be counted for the fishermen and plant workers, for a way of life in Atlantic Canada.
Do members realize what it means when we say that the northern cod stock has collapsed as dramatically as it has, when we say that some 2,000 jobs in this industry are going to be immediately and directly affected by management decisions that are going to be forced on the minister of fisheries, when we say that it is the equivalent of an announcement from the province of Ontario that one-third to one-half of the entire auto industry had shut down?
Can we begin to even imagine the response and the reaction across this land if tomorrow the Premier of Ontario announced that one-half of the entire automobile industry of Ontario had gone down the chute?
This Parliament would find itself sitting around the clock day in and day out to deal with a national emergency, because that is what it would be. The economic consequences for Atlantic Canada, and in particular for Newfoundland, are no less when we say that the Atlantic cod stock, the northern cod stock, has collapsed.
There were 31,000 jobs in Atlantic Canada dependent upon the northern cod stock. The northern cod stocks make up 46 per cent of the entire cod stocks of the east coast of Canada.
In 1988, the quota for northern cod was 266,000 metric tons. By 1991, that quota was down to 185,000 metric tons and the fleet was only able to catch 127,000 metric tons. In the same year, the foreign fishing effort resulted in a doubling of the foreign catch. They are catching
20,000	to 47,000 metric tons.
The destruction, the wanton, deliberate destruction of the Atlantic cod stocks, in particular the northern cod stock, is every bit as great a criminal environmental action as the wanton, knowing, and greedy destruction of the rain forests. It is exactly the same because the nations that go out and deliberately overfish on the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks, that wantonly destroy this resource belonging to all mankind for greed and profit in one year, are the same hypocritical nations that stand up in the world-wide agencies, in the UN, and cry about the destruction of the rain forests. Those are the same hypocritical nations, members of the EC, that stood up and banned the seal hunts off the east coast of Canada because they were people of great conscience. They are not people of conscience. They are people of greed and their principles can be bought and sold.
It is time that the Government of Canada understood that the destruction of those cod stocks is a national issue. It is in the national interest. It is time that this government is prepared to upset some of our so-called trading partners. It is time that we are prepared to establish linkage between good behaviour in the cod stocks on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks and a good relationship with Canada in other matters.
I will tell you what Atlantic Canadians feel. More than that, I will tell you what they know in their gut. They know that they are mere bits of plastic to be shuffled around on the world-wide Monopoly board. They know that they are expendable. They know that the government is fully aware of the criminal activity of nations fishing outside our waters and they know that the government is prepared to do nothing because this government has put the interests of Newfoundland, Labrador, Atlantic Canada, and the people on the east coast of this country secondary to other trade interests. That is the reality. That is a form of second-class citizenship that we will not accept in Newfoundland and Labrador.
Earlier tonight the minister of fisheries asked that we on this side of the House be generous in our response. I will tell him that in the area bordered by 2J-3K-L in my constituency people, some living two families to one house so they can save a few dollars, do not have any room for generosity.
February 19, 1992

In the small communities of northern Newfoundland and Labrador, and on the south coast where my colleague's constituents have seen their plants close, nobody can afford generosity for the member of St. John's West. It was that member who, for his time as minister of fisheries and before his time as minister of fisheries, stood in this House repeatedly and ridiculed the efforts of members on this side to point out that foreign overfishing was destroying the cod stocks off Newfoundland. Every time the member for Gander-Grand Falls stood in his place, or the member for Labrador, in all the years between 1984 and 1985 and said: "my God, open your eyes", the member ridiculed the representations of those members of Parliament. Since 1988 the member for Burin-St. George's, the fisheries critic, the member for Bona Vista-Trinity-Conception, have stood in their places and spoken up for Newfoundland and Labrador and the member for St. John's West has ridiculed their efforts.
I do not feel generous tonight. I do not feel generous. The people of Newfoundland and Labrador who suffered one blow after another in these last two weeks do not feel generous. They cannot afford to feel generous because they are preoccupied with putting bread and butter on the table and keeping a roof over their heads.
I concur with my colleagues. The government must finally prove that it has more than good intentions when it comes to the proper management of fish stocks, that it has more than a warm wish and warm feelings when it comes to the people of Newfoundland and Labrador. This government must stand up and take the action required, the one described by my colleague from Bona Vista-Trinity-Conception, an action that is bom out of a will to unilaterally extend Canada's jurisdiction over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. That is what this government must do. I will tell you what else it must do. It must acknowledge that the destruction which has been wrought upon this stock will not be quickly repaired. It must acknowledge that the management measures which will be put in place to restore this cod stock, because that is the minister's responsibility, are going to take three, four or five years.
It must acknowledge that people are going to be displaced from their livelihood for that entire period of time. As a result of the fact that those people are
innocent, they were not the managers of this stock, the government must commit itself to seeing that they survive this time of tragedy brought about by the incompetence, mismanagement and cowardice of the government opposite.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to comment on a matter that is extremely important, since the problem facing the Atlantic provinces today is a problem that Quebec and the gulf must cope with as well.
I will share my speaking time with the hon. member for Bonaventure-Iles-de-la-Madeleine.
According to scientific data released this week by the Atlantic Fisheries Scientific Advisory Committee, northern cod stocks have dwindled considerably. The total biomass, estimated at 1.2 million tonnes in 1990, is reported to have dropped to 780,000 tonnes in 1991, while during the same period the spawning population fell from 270,000 tons to 130,000 tonnes.
Northern cod represents the most abundant ground-fish stock on the east coast. It provides a living for 31,000 Canadians working in the fisheries and processing sectors. Cod catches have been dwindling rapidly since 1988, and in 1991 inshore and offshore fishermen caught scarcely two-thirds of their quotas.
CAFSAC has recommended that the total allowable catch be substantially reduced. It will be cut by 25,000 tonnes for the first six months of 1992, which means half the volume taken during the same period in 1991.
The effects of a dwindling resource are already being felt. A lack of northern cod during the winter closed down one Fishery Products International plant in Newfoundland, resulting in 1,000 lay-offs and forcing 11 vessels to remain in port.
On Monday the minister of fisheries met with representatives of unions and industry and with his Atlantic counterparts.
Tomorrow and on Friday we will have bilateral talks with representatives of fishermen's groups and the provinces in St. John's.
Immediately after these meetings, decisions will be made and probably next week, measures will be an-

nounced by the government. The government's plan of action will be guided by specific objectives: first, to strengthen the scientific base and reinforce measures to deal with violations, in order to provide for better management and protection of this capital resource; second, to help the communities, fishermen, and plant workers affected by these events; and third, to continue the all-out campaign to stop foreign overfishing.
A number of unique programs have been set up to restore fish stocks, make scientific surveys, and intensify surveillance and enforcement.
The government has already launched a series of major programs to facilitate Atlantic Canada's adjustment to changing circumstances.
The government's latest initiatives include the Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program which includes a plant workers adjustment program and a scientific program on northern cod, the Quebec fisheries federal development program, the Atlantic fisheries assistance program, and the compensation program linked to ice conditions.
AFAP, a five-year program with a budget of $584 million, was launched in May 1990. It includes a series of initiatives and concrete measures designed to ensure the lasting viability of the fisheries and help Atlantic Canada adjust to the drop in fish stocks and cuts in groundfish quotas.
Since the AFAP was implemented, operational activities have been started in many areas. Mr. Speaker, the Standing Committee on Forestry and Fisheries, which I chair, will start reviewing the program's activities a few days from now. Yesterday, we had an initial meeting with opposition critics.
The Quebec fisheries federal development program was announced in the summer of 1990. The overall objective of this program is to provide for the lasting viability of the fisheries industry under the jurisdiction of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans in this province. The program has four components which focus on marketing, processing, operations, research, and infrastructure.
There have been several major achievements since these programs were implemented. For instance, new
data were produced for evaluating stocks of northern cod, Scotian shelf groundfish, gulf crab and cod from the northern part of the gulf.
Considerably enhanced surveillance and enforcement has increased compliance with all fisheries regulations by Canadian and foreign fishermen. Compensation was paid directly to fishermen and plant workers affected by poor catches, ice conditions, and plant closings. Financial assistance was given to companies and individuals to enable them to diversify operations in the fisheries and other sectors.
Under AFAP, the federal government entered into agreements with the Governments of Newfoundland and New Brunswick, and it is continuing negotiations with the Government of Nova Scotia.
In 1991, as part of its measures to compensate fishermen affected by poor catches and ice conditions, the federal government injected $57 million into the economy of Atlantic Canada, part of which was taken from the AFAP budget. These two initiatives have helped cushion the impact of the worst ice and marine conditions ever registered throughout the region, and the impact of generally poor catches said to be due to abnormally low temperatures.
Under the compensation program for ice conditions, between May and October 1991, $18 million was paid to fishermen who were unable to leave port because of ice conditions. Mr. Speaker, since 1986, EC fishermen have exceeded by more than 400,000 tonnes the quota set by NAFO for cod stocks on either side of the Canadian 200-mile limit in the Northwest Atlantic.
In this respect, we have been very active before all international tribunals to support our case against foreign overfishing. The problem is not as easy as all that, unfortunately. Overfishing is significant, but what about the seals who feed on both capelin and cod? However, fishermen can rest assured we will do all we possibly can to deal with this situation.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hear a lot of noise from the other side of the House. I hope that it is because of the position our government is taking for Newfoundland fishermen.
February 19, 1992



Let us look at the situation we have. I concur with my colleagues from Newfoundland when they say: "It is a problem for Newfoundland". It is. It is also a problem for Canada and myself as a Quebecer.

As a Quebecer, as a Canadian, as the member for Bonaventure-Iles-de-la-Madeleine, I am with the Newfoundland fishermen today in everything that has to do with fishing in our area, the Gaspe peninsula, and everything to do with Newfoundland because they are our fishermen.

For the people who are listening tonight, as has been mentioned before this is not a political debate of the decision the minister of fisheries must make. We have to live with reality. I would hope the decision the minister of fisheries will be for the fishermen of Newfoundland and Newfoundlanders especially but also for the east coast fisheries. The time has come many times over. If I understood the initial speaker on the opposition side, the first minister of fisheries was John Cabot. He did not have the social programs and the network that are in place now. We can blame former governments or we can blame the present government, but that does not do any good. The fishermen and the workers in the fish plants have to be treated not from the past but from today and tomorrow. We will do that. I have confidence.
I am sure, Mr. Speaker, you realize that there are two very difficult jobs in this great land, of course with all respect to the Prime Minister. There are two difficult jobs: that of the Minister of Finance who brings a budget down once a year and spends 11.5 months or whatever defending it, and that of the minister of fisheries who has the most difficult job in this land.
Again I say as a Quebecer and as a Canadian that we have problems in Quebec and in Newfoundland, but we must work together. The west coast has different problems. The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has the most difficult portfolio that anyone would ever want to have. I am honoured to be on the government side and to be able to work with a gentleman and a competent person in the name of John Crosbie.
Let us look at the problem we have in this debate, as I mentioned, and what has happened in the past. A
decision is going to be made: Do we agree with our scientists?

I said before that we are only 295 elected members in the House of Commons; however, we have 300,000 public servants who represent us, who administer our programs throughout Canada, in all the provinces and territories. But what is important for us, and I believe that the minister of fisheries pointed it out, concerning research and information-
