subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: Just a reminder. The Standing Orders do not allow mentioning members by name. Since it is the second time, I would remind the hon. member to refer to members by their riding or their department.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker. So for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, with the research that has been done, with the people, the officials who work for us, of course, to save the fisheries in Newfoundland and the Magdalen Islands, these facts which have been presented to us must be respected. Where are we going?
The third problem is: What do we do after to keep these programs? How can the federal government get involved?

I was impressed this morning listening to the minister of fisheries from Newfoundland. He said: "Yes, we will bite the bullet for two or three years but it is a renewable stock". That is the type of co-ordination we must have in the east coast fisheries.
I will have the honour to be on the Magdalen Islands for three days this weekend to touch on all of the demands of the fisheries: lobster, crab, mackerel, codfish, and whatnot. We have to go back and listen to the scientific information to say what can be done and what we can do. The politicians in the past have created a monster. We have built bigger boats subsidized by both federal and provincial governments and we go back 40 years. We have built the boats, we have subsidized the fishing nets, and we have said: "Go and get it". Now we can catch in a week what used to take 10 weeks. That is the domestic side.

February 19, 1992
On the foreign side-and I understand the foreign problem with the Portuguese and the Spanish-there are measures to be taken. At the same time as we have increased our boats and our fishing gear they have also done that. When we talk about historic rights for foreign fisherpeople, they have done the same thing, but the foreign fisherpeople are not operating as they did historically because they are working with fishery factory trawlers. We must address that, and I know that our Minister of Fisheries and Oceans is looking at it.
After we do those two things, the one dealing with history and the other dealing with the present situation and the foreign fishing, what we have to do is address ourselves to the people of Newfoundland particularly and to the spin-off for the rest of the east coast, the Gaspe. the Magdalen Islands, and the coasts of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.
Where do we go? The politicians have to get out of the game of playing politics with the fishermen. We should let them know what we can do and where we should be. Then, after all is said and done, let the fishermen decide themselves. They have to. Fishermen like our farmers, like our primary producers, must be together. They must know and they must have the assurance that we in Ottawa, in this great Chamber of perhaps controversy, will back up our people and our fishermen. I am convinced and I know that on behalf of my people from the Gaspe.

As Dr. Marin just said, what is happening to us, the people of Gaspe and the Magdalen Islands, is just the same as what is happening in Newfoundland. We will all work together to find a solution. But the most important people concerned in that, are the fishermen of eastern Canada.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate the member for Burin-St. George's for calling this debate and I want to thank the Speaker for having it, because this is probably the most serious crisis we have faced.
I have been in the Chamber for 20 years and I cannot recall a time when we have faced a more serious threat in our province. It is, as my colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte on the west coast of Newfoundland and in part of my former riding has said already, not a regional issue; it is a national issue. My colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception and others have documented the reasons for the decline in the cod stocks. They are clearly evident. As the catch for Canadian fishermen has gone down, the catch for foreign fishermen has gone up. Something like 47,000 tonnes is taken by the European Community, which is almost half the total catch taken by Canadian fishermen out of the total allowable catch. The evidence is clear.
There are some who say that possibly there has been some Canadian overfishing as well and possibly the Canadian offshore fleet is not completely innocent in this matter at all. Perhaps there has been some overfishing on the part of the Canadian offshore fleet, but whatever the cause is the European Community has to bear the main brunt of it. Clearly it cannot be laid at the door of the fishermen of Labrador because on the Labrador coast there is an inshore fishery. We are talking about boats of 20 feet and 30 feet and 40 feet. You can count on one hand the number of boats over 40 feet on the Labrador coast, in Makkovik in the north, in Inuit communities and farther south in Square Island, Triangle and in places like Battle Harbour, a name that is synonymous with the fishing history of our province, in Fox Harbour and farther down in the straits, in Red Bay, Lance au Clair and Lance au Loup, all of these are small communities with small plants and small boats and fishermen who make a small income.
They make almost no income at all at the present time as a result of the fishing offshore and primarily the overfishing by the European communities. That is all they know and that is all they want. They are there because the fish are there. That is what they know and that is what they want to do.
It is not their fault that we are in this situation at this present time, and yet they suffer. In Black Tickle last year, on the Labrador coast, there was hardly a single pound of fish landed. The year before, 2 million pounds of fish were landed in Black Tickle on the Labrador coast. They came there from all over. There were
February 19, 1992

probably 1,500 boats, not just from the island of Newfoundland, but from Nova Scotia and Quebec in that community.
There were two million pounds of fish landed two years ago, and last year, there was hardly a single pound. That sounds incredible. That sounds hard to believe, but it is the fact. It is a fact of life. What do those people survive on now that the fish are gone?
What they are surviving on is what we heard latterly from the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans tonight. He recited all the grants and all the programs that were available to these people. What it amounts to is a handout. What it amounts to is keeping people, and that is not good enough. That is not why they came there. That is not what they know. That is not what they want and that is not what they need.
What they need is not handouts from the minister, but action. What alternatives do we have? Very few, Mr. Speaker. We have the alternative of crab, which we are exploiting at the present time. We have the alternative of shrimp which, thanks to the Liberal government when it was in office, allocated to Labrador fishermen offshore shrimp quotas which are keeping them at the present time and created two small fishermen co-ops on that coast.
Those are alternatives. Apart from those, there are very few alternatives except for an industry that we used to have which was sealing. The Inuit culture to a large degree has been built on the seal. They use it for food and clothing. They have historically. What we suffered from in the sealing industry was overzealous environmentalists such as Greenpeace which told us that it was cruel and inhumane to kill seals. That population is gone. That industry, that door is closed to us.
The seal population has multiplied to the point where it, too, is killing the very cod on which we survive. Each seal eats a tonne and a half of fish. That is depleting the resource almost as much as the European Community.
That door has been closed to us. What has to be done? There has to be a cull of the seal herd. Seal can be used for food, and surely there are people in the world who need food. The seal population has to be culled. That is the first thing.
Second, there must be a limitation. The minister is going to take action next week. He has said here tonight, and we have to hold him to it, that he will protect first
those people who depend most on fishing, that is the inshore fishermen. I ask him to keep his word on that and to make sure that when he delivers the new quotas he bears in mind, first of all, those people who depend on the inshore fishery.
Third, he has to do what the member for Bona Vista-Trinity-Conception, my colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte, and my other colleague from Burin-St. George's have suggested, that is to extend unilaterally the jurisdiction of Canada to the nose and tail of the Grand Banks.
I can recall when the 200-mile limit was brought in. It was a Newfoundlander who negotiated that 200-mile limit. Don Jamieson was the Minister of External Affairs at the time that the Government of Canada brought in the 200-mile limit. Alan Beasley was our ambassador overseas. Between them, they negotiated on behalf of Canada and pushed on behalf of Canada, and fought to get a 200-mile limit. As my colleague from Bonavista- Trinity-Conception has said, before that it was a 12-mile limit. It can be done and it must be done. There is no alternative.
I have just come back from Europe and I can tell you first-hand that we are not making a dent at all. We are not getting anywhere in Europe. Quiet diplomacy has not worked. Discussion has not worked. The only thing that is going to work is unilateral action and a forceful unilateral action.
I am not one normally to suggest dramatic courses of action, but I am at the point where I would like to ask my colleagues to join me, to get on a boat ourselves to go out within the 200-mile limit to take action on our own to stop what is going on. Some dramatic gesture has to be made. The Government of Canada has it in its power, if it has the political will, to extend that jurisdiction and that must be done.
Fourth, once the jurisdiction is extended then the enforcement has got to take place. We have frigates and coastal defence vessels. They can be used to exert the will of the Government of Canada inside that 200-mile limit. These are the things that must be done.
I want to remind the government finally, as I said in the beginning, that the people on the coast that I represent are wholly dependent on fish. There is no alternative. That is why they are there and that is what they want to do.

February 19, 1992
In the minister's pondering of this in the next few days, I ask him to remember that this coast depends on fish and I ask him, when he makes his decisions, to act in their best interests.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I, too, wish to participate in this emergency debate. In doing so, I want to thank my colleague from Burin-St. George's who made the application under the provisions of Standing Order 52 for this debate, which I believe to be fundamental not only to the regional economy in Atlantic Canada, but indeed the entire Canadian economy.
It has been said by many in this Chamber that fisheries and particularly Atlantic fisheries is a regional issue. It ought to be stated here again that this particular issue goes well beyond the geographical boundaries of the four Atlantic provinces. This is a national problem with very significant repercussions for the entire Canadian economy. It requires the Government of Canada, which has sole authority under the Constitution for management of the fisheries, to take bold initiatives in order to resolve the very serious situation that we find ourselves in today.
I say national because I talk about jobs. I make reference to the social welfare of our citizens and, yes, I refer to the Canadian environment. Whether one lives in Newfoundland, British Columbia, or somewhere in between, all of us as parliamentarians, indeed as Canadians, must accept, must understand and must go to bat for an industry and a way of life that is in serious jeopardy.
I agree with the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans from St. John's West, at the outset of my remarks, where he made reference to the somewhat ill-conceived mainland editorials which have appeared recently in our newspapers across this country. What arrogance. I make specific reference to the Toronto Globe and Mail which likes to refer to itself as a national newspaper. What hypocrisy at its best to say: "I will not read the entire paragraph because I only have a few minutes in which to speak". I say to them, Mr. Speaker, through you and to other members of this Chamber, that those of us in this Chamber, regardless of our political stripe, ought to say to those newspapers across the country which put down the poorer regions of this country and try to make out
that we want to live on the public trough for the rest of our lives is just not acceptable. The issue must be put, however, in the few moments I have left. What, where and who is running the fisheries in Canada. Is it the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans? Is it the Prime Minister or the Secretary of State for External Affairs? Before I give that answer I want to put on the record what I believe to be some very obvious facts so that the reasonable Canadian will clearly understand.
In 1991, factory freezer trawlers inside the 200-mile limit were given 100 licences. The Department of Fisheries and Oceans in Halifax issued these licences to Cuba, France, Japan, Norway, Poland, the U.S.S.R. and Bulgaria.
Mr. Speaker, you are an intelligent individual. These factory freezer trawlers are not like the 18-foot rowboats that can be seen on the beaches in some of the more prosperous areas of Ontario. These vessels, I suggest, are anywhere between 300 and 450 feet whereas in Canada, a factory freezer trawler is roughly 175 feet.
We are not dealing with any pleasure boats. We are dealing with substantial floating fish plants. That is what they are. In St. John's, Newfoundland, in 1991 they issued 23 foreign licences, 9 factory freezer trawlers and 14 Faro Islanders, ships which are not factory freezer trawlers. They caught such fish as redfish, capelin, squid, Greenland halibut, silver hake, and numerous bycatches. So, I ask the question: Who is running the Department of Fisheries and Oceans? It is my humble suggestion that it is not the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans. He is the tail that is wagging the dog. The people who are administering Fisheries and Oceans are in the Department of External Affairs.
An hon. member shakes his head. Well, let him get up and participate in the debate. Let him show beyond a reasonable doubt that the Department of External Affairs is not running the Department of Fisheries and Oceans when you have that kind of fact.
My other colleague from the province of Newfoundland will participate later this night. He will provide additional evidence that any reasonable man or woman in this country will conclude that fisheries management is being run by the Department of External Affairs.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
What about Environment?
February 19, 1992

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member opposite interrupts me while I speak. I did not interrupt him when he spoke. I want to say if that is not the case, why has the Secretary of State for External Affairs been such a silent individual, as was her predecessor, the Minister for Constitutional Affairs?
I say to this government through you, Mr. Speaker, that it is this cabinet, this Prime Minister, which have acted negligently on behalf of fishermen and the fishing industry in Canada. That is the crime. We have no Department of Fisheries and Oceans. We have a few scientists. We have some able individuals who are sincere in their work. But the fact of the matter is that the decisions are being made by the Department of External Affairs and the Prime Minister of this country.
The Prime Minister, the Secretary of State for External Affairs and the Minister for Industry, Trade and Commerce have not taken their responsibilities seriously-
They have not exercised their fiduciary obligations on behalf of fishermen across this country. They would rather be on the front pages of the newspapers, in The Globe and Mail, cutting the ribbons in the foreign nations of this country as opposed to standing up for the fishermen across this country. That is the problem.
And I say in conclusion that the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, for whom I have some time and a good deal of respect, and I concur with my colleague from Burin- St. George's that the minister is a victim of a cabinet which does not care, does not understand, and has lost the political will to govern for a sovereign nation such as Canada.
They will be called accountable, not only for their acts but, more important, for their gross omissions in ministering one of the most important common resources to all Canadians wherever they may reside in this great country.
Shame on the Prime Minister, shame on the Minister of External Affairs, shame on the Minister for International Trade, and shame on the Minister of the Environment, as well as the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to take part in the emergency debate this evening.
I do agree with the members across the aisle that it is very timely and very necessary not only to listen to both sides of the issue, but also obviously to point out what the government is doing in regard to a very great problem indeed.
The rhetoric in a debate that is as emotional as this tends to heat up during the course of the evening. I think we have seen some evidence of that this evening on both sides of the aisle.
But it goes beyond attempting to lay blame somewhere. We have done that historically in this House over the years, regardless of who the government of the day happened to be. I say that based on something that happened in this country just in the last couple of weeks that brought it to mind, in the sense of laying blame, who is to blame, how do we solve this thing, how do we get through it?
It has to do with our latest astronaut, Roberta Bondar, when she was actually interviewed on CBC television a few nights ago by I believe it was Barbara Frum.
I was really taken with that interview because she was asked what it was like to be in space and what it was like to look down on this planet of ours. I was really taken with almost the poetic sense with which she answered that question. She said: "You know, it is a feeling that you really can't explain, that you really can't articulate".
But she did a very good job in attempting to articulate it. She said she was really struck by the solidarity of this planet in relation to the rest of the universe when she was up there looking down. She was taken by the immensity, the size of Canada as a nation. I think we are now questioning whether Canada is number one or number two in sheer geographic size in this universe of ours at the present time.
What I am attempting to draw or paint is the sense that when we are talking about the fisheries we are talking about a finite resource. It is not an unlimited resource. It is certainly a renewable resource, but it is a resource that we really do not have a lot of control over.

February 19, 1992
If you asked a team of scientists today what is going on with the cod stocks you would have as many opinions as you would have individuals. There is no real easy answer to what is happening to the stocks.
This evening I give credit to members on both sides of the House for stepping us through some of the possible causes or reasons for a decline in the stocks. There is some commonality of thought in some of the expressions articulated here this evening.
There is no question the seal problem is a real problem. When you have a seal herd in excess of 3 million, each one eating approximately one and one-half tonnes of fish per year, it is obviously a problem.
That problem stems from the ban that was imposed on the seal hunt many years ago for maybe the right reasons, maybe the wrong reasons. There is no question that fishermen bear the brunt of a decision made many years ago. Basically the seal herd has grown unchecked in recent years and there is no question that it is having an effect on stocks.
We can look at the technology that fishermen today have at their disposal to locate and catch fish. We do not have to be skilled in the fisheries area to recognize that they do have the ability to catch more fish than they did just a few short years ago.
Take a look at the capelin, the feed of the cod. What has happened to that resource? Again, no one can tell us.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: We gave it to the Russians.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
My hon. friend from Moncton is telling us that we gave the capelin to the Russians. He knows that is totally false.
That is the difficulty with this debate this evening. When you attempt to apply reason on this side of the House, you are always interrupted by a suggestion which is totally false, totally inaccurate.
Let us talk for a minute about giving fish away. I want to quote the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and what he had to say yesterday about what happened in this sort of give-away of fish in Canada.
Let us talk about what happened back in 1972. I am quoting the minister in his response to that question: "I wonder why Canada in 1972 committed such insanity by signing a treaty with the French under which they took
300,000	tonnes of cod in the gulf".
It was not our government that did that; it was his government at the time. That is only the start, the minister tells us. They are taking 4,000 tonnes more this year because of that treaty which has no termination date. So they are the authors of some of our misfortunes. They cannot crawl out from underneath that legacy because that is a reality that stares them in the face. It is the treaty that they entered into.
The minister went on to point out that the people who are criticizing us today are the very people who gave away 75,000 more tonnes of fish in 2G and 2GH.
When we want to get into name calling and laying blame nothing happens at the end of the day. It is just rhetoric on both sides of the issue. The reality is that we are into a real problem. It is not going to be solved by pointing fingers and laying blame.
The government of the day has been very generous in support of the fisheries recognizing the problems that we do have out there. Looking at the raw numbers, the federal government is putting about $3.15 into the fishing community for every dollar that it has generated by the fishery itself. It is an equation that is totally lopsided. It tells me that we are actually putting more into the fishery than we are getting out of it as a resource. Again, we can argue why that resource is not there. Maybe mankind itself has something to do with it.
I opened my remarks by suggesting it is a resource that not even the most talented, the most skilled of all the scientists can accurately predict. We have gone through these highs and lows. We have historically done that in this country.
Again, let us go back to the generosity of spirit. I know some of the members over there are saying, and I agree with them totally, that it is very difficult if you are living in one of those little fishing communities in Newfoundland to have any sense of generosity of spirit, generosity of heart, when you are looking at a resource that is almost disappearing before your very eyes.
That has to be acknowledged and it is being acknowledged by this government. Again, I agree with them. It goes beyond just the sheer geography of Atlantic Canada. It is a Canadian problem. We have to start addressing it from that point of view.
February 19, 1992

I do not think there is anyone in this House who would deny that the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has done everything within his power, within his capacity in the last number of years to make it a little easier for those fishermen who are being affected by that downturn in the resource.
I can step through some of the numbers. I suppose the most obvious one is the $584 million that the minister secured almost single-handedly for the downturn in the fisheries for Newfoundland.
This debate is going to grind on for a few more hours. I want to let the people of Newfoundland know that we have a feeling for them. We do not all live in Newfoundland but we understand the problem. We do want to be generous as Canadians.
I totally agree with the members that have spoken before that it goes beyond just being a problem for Newfoundland. It is a problem for all of us as Canadians, particularly at this point in the history of our country. We have to show a little more generosity than we have in the past.
We have it within our capacity to do that as a nation. I am very proud to be part of a government that does have that generosity.

speakeroldname: Mr. Charles A. Langlois (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Industry, Science and Technology):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened to the speeches of opposition members tonight, and especially those members who represent ridings in the Atlantic provinces.
I will admit that tonight there is some concern in the fishing villages in the riding of Manicouagan.

Anxiety and uncertainty in the homes of fishermen on the lower north shore is a fact. There are several reasons. The first reason is that they heard at the beginning of the week that there was a report tabled to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans by a committee of scientific experts, a committee of scientific advisers that has told the minister that the northern cod stocks are declining at a very rapid rate.
The minister received that advice earlier this week. As the responsible minister he has called to Ottawa a
meeting of all the people involved in the fishery in the Atlantic provinces. He has reported to them the findings of that committee.
The findings of that committee are of course not very bright for the future. They indicate to us what we have been fearing for quite a few years that the cod stocks are declining at a rapid rate and that if we do not address that issue rapidly we will face much more hardship in the very near future.
These fishermen and the members of their families in my riding are asking themselves tonight what will happen for the 1992 fishing season.

They wonder whether their wives, sons and daughters, and other members of their families will find work in the processing plants in their communities next summer. They have a perfectly legitimate reason to be concerned.
They are also worried this evening because since eight o'clock opposition members have been painting a picture of gloom and doom. And in addition to discussing the subject at hand, those opposition members are shouting and insulting government members because of information released earlier this week by the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans. Instead of scaring fishing communities in Atlantic Canada, perhaps they should have waited to hear about the measures the minister will be announcing very shortly to provide some relief. As I was saying, the minister is about to announce a number of measures that will try to ease the situation next summer.

The purpose of the Liberal Party speakers tonight is to plant fears and anxiety in the heart of the fishermen and their families. One day they will have to answer for that. I say to the people of the lower north shore, I say to the people living in every community in my riding: look at the situation with cool heads. COSA, the Committee of Scientific Advisers, earlier this week informed the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans of findings that are based on a series studies accumulated over a number of years. The minister will address that issue. The minister is strong, and based on his track record he will implement measures that will take care of the situation and alleviate the hardship caused in the fishing communities because of that situation.

February 19, 1992
As for the minister's track record, I would like to remind the House and the people in the fishing communities that he was the one to introduce programs and measures that directly provide support, provide work, and provide funding in the fishing communities of Atlantic Canada, to help those communities take charge of some of the local operations, to help those communities get involved in developing their industrial bases, both in fishery activities and other types of activities as well.

I would like to comment briefly on the Quebec fisheries development program, designed under the direction of the present Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and announced by him a little over a year and a half ago. The four components of this program provide fishing communities, organizations, and committees with the means to organize their own activities, diversify their economy, and become more actively involved in the fisheries as such.
The Quebec fisheries development program has a dynamic marketing component that will provide the processing industry with the means to reach new markets and sell fish species we have not been able to sell up to now.

There is a component in the Quebec fishery development program that addresses resource management. Programs have been put in place the last year and a half to ensure that us down the line we manage our stock better, that together with the fishermen, the communities, and the department we will provide better, sound management for our resource. There is also a component that addresses research by the scientists with the aim of providing us with data on fish stocks and information that we did not have before. For quite a few months I have seen concrete results from this program in the communities in my riding, I have seen an active role played by the fishermen. We will continue this.
Yesterday I had a meeting in my office with the general manager of the Lower North Shore Fishermen's Association. We discussed the issue. I will be visiting the communities at the beginning of March and will be in a position to talk further with them and assess with them what can be done to alleviate the situation. Those are
positive steps that we will take, as a government, to provide support and incentive to the fishermen to help them pull through this very difficult situation.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Newfoundlanders have sustainably fished for hundreds of years off the coast of Newfoundland. They have fished and others have also fished off the Grand Banks, and so on. They have made a living, provided for their families, and built their communities.
The fish stocks survived those hundreds of years of fishing. They replenished themselves. They were a renewable resource, a constantly renewing resource, indeed one of the world's great protein sources.
Today those fish stocks are dangerously low and the livelihoods of Newfoundlanders and those in Labrador are threatened. There is a tragedy of enormous proportions in the decline of the fishing stocks off Newfoundland.
I think Canadians ask us to suggest solutions to problems and not to lay blame. They ask us to ensure that government action, on behalf of Newfoundlanders and on behalf of Canadians, is taken in the face of this tragedy.
However, we do have to remember some recent history on how we got into the situation the Newfoundland fishery is in, how that fishery got into the trouble it is in today. We need to understand why because it teaches us how to deal with the solutions in the future. It teaches us how not to respond to the problem we are facing.
The establishment of essentially two large fish corporations, Fishery Products International and National Sea, under a Liberal government meant treating the fish stocks as a resource to be plundered for profit, handsome profits in some years, a resource to be dealt with from the point of view of a corporate balance sheet and short-term profit considerations with no thought for the future. Indeed, it was short-sighted in the extreme as we see today with so many of Canada's resource industries.
Governments, both Liberal and Conservative, both federal and provincial, shared this view so that scientific advice to reduce the total allowable catch was ignored. It was assumed that there would always be plenty of fish, the big corporations' profits and projections were believed in the face of scientific evidence, foreign fishing went essentially uncontrolled for fear of upsetting our


HbBH
February 19, 1992

European trading partners, and big corporate freezer trawlers were encouraged to plunder that resource.
That approach, that rather typical Canadian big business resource industry approach, has taken us to the disaster we face today.
We in the New Democratic Party and those in the Official Opposition predicted many times over the last three or four years that this was a tragedy of enormous proportions and warned of the situation we are in. Scientist after scientist, study after study, warned against the tragedy that we are now facing. In a sense this is reliving an emergency because it is at least the third or fourth time we have discussed, in terms of an emergency, the disaster facing the fishery off Newfoundland.
The size and extent of the problem is enormous. However the problem is not beyond our ability and scope to deal with.
There are solutions. My colleague from Prince George-Bulkley Valley presented earlier a four-point plan to address in the short term and the long term, the problem of the fishery in Newfoundland. I will mention that in a minute as a way of getting out of this problem.
It is not sufficient to talk about retraining fishermen because what are we retraining fishery people for? There are no jobs in the communities where they live. They have every right, it seems to us, to continue to live in communities in which they have grown up, in communities in which they have a tradition stretching over hundreds of years.
They have a right to continue to be able to exercise their skills in a way in which they choose. With no fish because of the plunder that has taken place, because of the inactivity of the federal government, they need some assistance to survive until these fish stocks are hopefully replenished.
Over and over again, warnings came. In 1988 in the recommendations to the minister leading up to the Canada-Newfoundland Inshore Fisheries Agreement, there were warnings about the impending over-exploitation of the fish stock.
In 1989 scientists indicated that stock strengths were over estimated. In 1990 the well publicized study of Dr. Harris, commissioned by the federal government, confirmed what scientists have been saying. He publicly called for a major reduction in the total allowable catch.
The Department of Fisheries and Oceans predicted just last year enormous worker lay-offs as a result of the decline in fish stocks. We are seeing those predictions coming true, unfortunately, today.
We have seen some initiatives to try to deal with this problem, but those initiatives clearly have not been up to the task because otherwise we would not be where we are today. It is not enough to retrain. It is not enough to assist older plant workers to readjust.
We have to do something to ensure the replenishment of the fishing stocks which means we have to hold back on the exploitation of that resource and we have to do something to enable those who live off the sea to survive until those fish stocks replenish.
This is an ecological tragedy which compares to the devastation of the Brazilian rain forests. It is our own ecological tragedy in Canada.
Before I suggest the approaches we could take to deal with this problem, Canada has to ask herself what sort of fishery she wants. Does she want an offshore corporate fishery as we have had which led us to the situation we are in? Or do we want an inshore community based fishery which Newfoundland experienced over hundreds of years and which enabled the communities there to thrive?
It is clear we have to make a major shift away from the solutions posed by Liberal and Conservative governments to one which is more community based, which actually will create and keep jobs in the community.
We have to move immediately to assume fishery management jurisdiction over the nose and tail of the Grand Bank to effectively terminate foreign overfishing. We must immediately define our priorities for the future. We must define that we want a community based inshore fishery and not a corporate based fishery.

February 19, 1992
We need a fishery which is premised on sustainable economic development, which will keep that critical protein stock replenished and yet provide livelihoods for those who live off it.
In the process, there will be many jobs lost and many communities in severe economic difficulty. Both federal and provincial governments must be prepared to bring forward programs, perhaps on a level not seen before even in the difficult economic times we face, of ensuring that thousands of families in those communities are not forced to leave Newfoundland and Labrador to go down the road for a future somewhere else.
In other words, we have to maintain those communities in a viable way until the fishing stocks return. It is, as we know, not a solution to encourage those without jobs in the regions of Canada to go to Alberta or to Ontario for jobs because our economy is not providing jobs there either.
We must also ensure that proposals in our current constitutional debates which would see the end of any provincial trade protections and trade barriers be really carefully looked at in the context of the Newfoundland fishery. Newfoundland has regulations which require fish caught by Newfoundland fishers to be processed in Newfoundland. Nova Scotia, on the other hand, permits fish caught by Nova Scotians to be shipped out of the province costing, as Conservative MPs have indicated, at least 1,000 jobs.
We need to reassess what would happen if we broke down provincial trade barriers and we have to ensure that they are sustainable and remain in effect for Newfoundland so that the communities can be protected.
Basically we have to do two things. We have to ensure that fish stocks replenish. We have to stop overfishing by foreign fleets and we have to control the fishing done by Canadians. Second, we have to sustain those who live off the sea until the fish stocks replenish.
I think that the point about responding to the foreign overfishing by taking control over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks is one which is not free of problems, but as the minister of fisheries indicated just last year, the discussions that have taken place with the European
Community have not been successful. He indicated that in spite of repeated efforts by the government to make Europeans realize the serious effects of combined overfishing by their member states, they have indeed continued to overfish and indeed, in recent years, have overfished to the extent of 100 per cent of their allowable agreed upon catch.
We have the problem of foreign overfishing, foreign governments, and foreign fishing organizations not paying attention to the seriousness of the depletion of the resource. We cannot, I think, rely upon moral suasion any longer. The government has to act to stop that overfishing, to take control outside the 200-mile zone and ensure that our stocks have an opportunity to replenish.
The New Democrat member of the legislature in Newfoundland, St. John's East, a former member of this House, has called upon the federal government to take control immediately over foreign overfishing off the Grand Banks. The Nova Scotia Federation of Labour has also called upon the government to extend fisheries jurisdiction beyond the 200-mile zone.
The provincial government has called upon unilateral action on the part of the Canadian government, and members of the Official Opposition have responded similarly.
We have all called for the Canadian government to take unilateral fisheries jurisdiction given that foreign fleets have continually overfished the stock. There is no question that this has to be done and has to be done immediately.
In closing, we have in Newfoundland a multi-faceted disaster, an ecological disaster, as we see the depletion of this incredible protein source, an ecological disaster of enormous proportions, an economic disaster of enormous proportions as thousands and thousands of families are thrown on to on unemployment roles, on welfare roles because of the inability to maintain the fish stocks because of their overexploitation and the ineffective management of that stock.
Of course, we see social disaster in enormous proportions as communities are tom apart, as people are forced to leave the province in search of some livelihood and last but not least, we see a cultural disaster as the culture of Newfoundland, the communities of Newfoundland are forced to suffer and some to close.
February 19, 1992

This multi-faceted disaster is one which the federal government must deal with. As I said, there are two ways in which this must be done. There is no choice any more. It is absolutely critical that steps be taken immediately to preserve and rebuild the fish stocks and we all hope that it is not too late to do this. We must also concentrate on the people who are affected and provide assistance to those who have lost their livelihood. The government must treat this situation as a national emergency. The survival of a fragile provincial economy that is so important to all Canadians is at stake here. It is our responsibility and obligation to preserve it.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not come from a riding in the Atlantic region which is directly affected by the disaster which has befallen the northern cod fishery, but it certainly is a matter that is of great concern to me as are all matters that affect the sustainability of our environment and our resources.
It seems to me that as we discuss a situation such as the disappearance of the northern cod, it reminds us of the continuing tragedy of man's intervention with his environment of the disappearance and endangerment of so many of our species. The cod situation reminds us and it scares us. It always seems to be too late when we get reminded and scared.
It is like the changes in our atmosphere, pollution, acid rain, global warming, and the ozone. Now finally the ozone has our attention and we are starting to talk about serious measures to stay out of the sun and protect our children.
So it is with the northern cod stocks and the situation in Newfoundland. It is a tragic and scarey situation.
My colleagues have spoken in great detail tonight about the measures which have been taken to address the fishery in Newfoundland over the past several years. There have been the constant scientific warnings and constant reductions in the total allowable catch. There has been tremendous investment in the Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program to provide not only scientific capabilities to deal with declines in the stocks and find ways of hopefully replenishing them, but endeavouring to find ways to deal with the economic tragedy that affects Newfoundland and Nova Scotia and all the fisheries areas of Atlantic Canada, along with the
malaise which we feel from the current recessionary circumstances in so many parts of our economy.
I would have to say that this government on balance has provided extremely sensitive, constructive, and at times courageous management of this resource. I do not think it does us any good at all to debate this subject in the constant harangue of who could have done this, or who should have done this, or who would have done this if they had been in power. It just contributes to the tragic nature of the whole situation.
I would be inclined to recommend to all hon. members that we finally take a situation such as this cod tragedy and constructively try to figure out together what has gone wrong, what the causes have been what the remedies are, and what we can constructively do to remedy and adjust to this significant situation.
It must be really hilarious to those Portuguese, Spaniards and others who are over-fishing just outside our 200-mile economic zone, to look in on this House of Commons today and yesterday and see the theatrics, the opera, and the high drama of television being performed without any significant contribution or consensus developing about what has gone wrong and what we can do about it.
I do not think I can add anything of great detail to the specifics of the cod situation in our Atlantic fishery tonight. I can certainly pledge my support for the Minister of Fisheries and for the constructive approach, indeed the courageous approach, he has to take to this issue because it is so sensitive and so personal to his own political affairs and service. He has to face this every weekend not only as the minister of fisheries for Canada but as the member of Parliament for the city of St. John's and many of the fishing areas around it. I applaud him for the approach he takes. I applaud his department for the comprehensive and scientific approach which they take. I would certainly call on all members of this House to support that approach and to work in addressing this as an environmental disaster, an environmental challenge that we all have to face together. I think if we do, Canadians will start to have some confidence that we in this House of Commons may find a way to deal with it.
On that threshold I would like to address another fish resource in which I have had some particularly unique experience and for which I have a great deal of high

February 19, 1992
regard and respect, almost as a symbol of our natural environment. That is the Atlantic salmon.
The Atlantic salmon which is one of the most magnificent creatures in God's world has been in peril for many decades, for almost all of the decades in my life. Yet we continue to live on the edge with practices that we know are destructive and hope will be successful. But we know inside they probably will not be, and constantly retreat from the sort of management we should be taking.
With respect to Atlantic salmon I think there is an analogy to the cod situation or vice versa. The signals have been there for years that the resource is in trouble. It is under constant attack. It is under constant overharvest. The runs do not show annually as we expect. We blame it on the weather and on phenomenon that is beyond description when in fact it all boils down to a reality that if we are not at least the cause of it, we are not the solution to it either. We have not been able to manage ourselves sufficiently well to manage the resource.
With respect to Atlantic salmon I would remind the House of the tagging system we have introduced, of the catch and release approaches we have taken, of the elimination of commercial fisheries in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, of the reduction in commercial licences in Newfoundland. Despite all of these measures we continue in a very significant way to debate the merits or demerits of gill net fishing. It is a destructive indiscriminate manner of harvesting fish so that everything that is touched is dead when it is retrieved. The opportunity to release spawning fish, as has become the practice in angling traditions is not possible.
Yet as we advance cases for the termination of gill netting we are still confronted with debate and argument about the fact that the courts may not see it as an adequate conservation measure. We may not be able to sell it as a conservation measure, and we do not dare take the risk of banning gill netting because it will have political and social implications among our citizens of all cultures.
Yet if a resource disappears as the northern cod is on the verge of disappearing, and an entire economy such as Newfoundland's is struck with real tragedy, does it not seem like hollow talk when we wonder if we are over stepping the bounds of conservation by managing a little too tightly or a little too closely?
I would call on the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans who I applaud, admire and support completely. I would call on him to approach the Atlantic salmon resource with the cod resource in mind, to dare to take the conservation measures now that are required to preempt a precipitous decline in the stocks, to take the kind of measures that will prevent us getting to this day with Atlantic salmon that we are with cod saying that we have failed. We are in trouble and we do not know how to cope with it. We do not know what caused it and whatever we should have done, it is now almost too late.
I think as we search for a solution to the cod tragedy, it is a solution to which we all must commit ourselves. I ask my colleagues and I ask our minister, with the greatest of respect, to ensure that we do not end up approaching the issue of Atlantic salmon in the same manner and bring about the same sad result we are now experiencing with the northern cod.
Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker, for this opportunity-

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague, the member for St. John's West, has already addressed the problem of foreign overfishing, its underlying elements, its complexities, and its dimensions.
A clear result is a severe depletion of the biomass and the tragic economic and social implications for the economies of the Atlantic provinces together, and Newfoundland in particular.

Therefore, we can clearly see the human tragedy, the result of plant closures and job losses. The question is: What is Canada doing to resolve this serious problem?

Before describing the measures that Canada is and will be taking, I want to make four important points on foreign overfishing generally:
First, these fisheries are taking place outside the 200-mile limit in international waters where Canada, to our great frustration, has no jurisdiction and flag states alone have the legal authority to enforce rules on their own vessels. International waters do not belong to any one state, Canada, or any other state, or even to an organization like NAFO, the North Atlantic Fisheries
February 19, 1992

Organization. They belong to the international community. It is up to individual sovereign national states to control the actions of their citizens and those vessels that are in those waters.
Second, most of the countries that fish in the NAFO area-Japan, Russia, the Faro Islands, Norway, Denmark, Cuba-support fisheries conservation, respect their NAFO quotas, and co-operate with Canada. They do not fish for northern cod. The problem of overfishing is centred on the activities of two countries in particular: Spain and Portugal. They are not the only ones but they are the primary ones.
Third, the small number of countries that do not co-operate with Canada, certain EC member states as well as Korea and Panama, are not eligible for benefits in the Canadian zone. Their fishing vessels are barred from Canadian ports, except in very serious emergencies. They are not allowed to fish for surplus stocks in Canadian zones. They are not eligible to take part in commercial ventures involving any fishing by their vessels in Canadian waters.
Fourth, the number one priority in international fisheries management is improving effective controls. All NAFO members must agree on measures to strengthen surveillance of vessels and to control actual fishing in international waters. They must take all steps necessary to ensure that conservation rules are enforced.
This government is committed, as no other has been, to ending foreign overfishing in the northwest Atlantic outside the 200-mile limit. Since 1989 we have carried out a comprehensive campaign, both at home and abroad. We have undertaken a high-level political initiative led by the Prime Minister to ensure that leaders of the EC, its member states and other nations, including members of the G-7, are aware of the serious consequences of overfishing. The Prime Minister has raised this with his colleagues-heads of government, the head of the European commission-at every available opportunity and frequently to our cost. The tensions that have resulted from our raising the issue of overfishing have created tensions in other areas. We are glad to do that on behalf of the fishermen of eastern Canada.
In bilateral and multilateral discussions we have sought to persuade the European community to return to compliance with NAFO decisions. Sometimes I feel as though I am beating my head against the oak door up there in the gallery. I raise this in every international meeting I have with European ministers, the presidency of the EC, and the Commission of the European Community. Canada's ambassador to the United Nations raised Canada's concerns in the last session of the UN General Assembly. A comprehensive Canadian information campaign has underlined the ecological risks of overfishing and called on the European public to oppose foreign overfishing in the northwest Atlantic. We have to make the Europeans realize that overfishing is to their disadvantage as well as to ours. Believe me, it is one of the most frustrating parts of my job to try to get them to listen, but try we do on every potential occasion.
Work has begun within NAFO-and this is a hopeful sign-to improve its system of surveillance and enforcement and to eliminate fishing by vessels registered in countries that are not members of NAFO. Canada has also spearheaded international efforts to improve the effectiveness of international law as it pertains to high seas fish stocks. A major objective for Canada in this legal part of our initiative, as opposed to the political element which we emphasize every time we can, is international recognition of the special interest of coastal states, others as well as Canada, in conservation and management of fish stocks which are harvested both inside and outside national fishing zones.
A special ambassador for fisheries conservation has been appointed to co-ordinate and carry forward Canada's diplomatic, legal and information initiatives in this important area. He initiated bilateral consultations with the EC Commission early last summer but the community rejected Canada's proposals to help resolve the problem.
Much remains to be done but there are signs of progress, however frustratingly slow. For example, the European Community, which is increasingly Eurocentric and as a result we have to consistently build our efforts there, did accept eight of the 11 NAFO management decisions for 1991 and 1992. In 1991 the EC assigned a fisheries patrol vessel to the regulatory area for seven months and it is likely that the patrol vessel will return to the NAFO area in 1992. We will certainly urge

February 19, 1992
that it does. The EC is co-operating within NAFO to reduce fishing by non-NAFO vessels, including its own reflagged vessels. Of course reflagging is another of the problems which we have to fight on another front. Canada will continue to press the EC to control EC vessels fishing in the regulatory area and prevent reflagging by its vessels.
In the meantime, we are pressing ahead on other fronts and we do so consistently. The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has laid out an ambitious plan of objectives and initiatives for 1992. Canada has asked the chairman of the NAFO fisheries commission to convene a special session of NAFO to improve international control in the NAFO area. This is a special meeting and will take place in May. It is very rare that NAFO agrees to have a special meeting of this nature. Canada will be taking its proposals on high seas fisheries conservation to the United Nations Convention on the Environment and Development, the Earth Summit in Rio, to seek international support for our efforts in terms of conservation of what is an important international resource.
We have met with, and hammered on, the government of Panama to ask them to take action to end the use of Panamanian flagged vessels in northwest Atlantic fisheries. The minister himself has travelled to London and Tokyo to speak eloquently on behalf of the fishermen in Canada for effective control of international fisheries. He will visit other capitals over the coming months to build up support for Canada at NAFO and at the Rio summit. These are some of the ways that we are working to end the foreign overfishing outside Canada's 200-mile limit.
The new scientific evidence that has come to light this week as reported by my colleague serves again to confirm the devastation of the northern cod stock by the relentless foreign overfishing and seeming disregard of NAFO's rational conservation decisions in the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks outside the 200-mile zone.
The Prime Minister, my colleague the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, and I have repeatedly and at every opportunity registered with our colleagues in the community that the northwest Atlantic fishery, especially northern cod, is in serious trouble because of continued and excessive overfishing by EC vessels.
This is not an issue just of critical importance to Canada which is our primary concern. It is of importance to the entire fishing industry and fisheries conservation of the world. The EC and the non-members of NAFO have got to recognize this. They have to address it seriously.
If this important resource is to be saved, these countries have to bring their fleets under effective control in compliance with NAFO conservation decisions. We will continue to beat our heads against any door that is available to us to make this point clear.
I should say that those who fish inside our waters, which has been suggested tonight as a kind of sinister failure on the part of the government, are here because of obligations under the Law of the Sea, frustrating though it may be that under the Law of the Sea, people can come into our 200-mile limit and fish for underutilized species.
We are doing everything we can to conserve the fishery that is under our control and to convince others to conserve the fishery and save it when it is under the control of others who are beyond our borders.
We have been doing that daily and weekly. We will continue to do it until we manage to resolve this issue on behalf of the fishery of Canada.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is sad that this House is once again debating the many troubles of the Atlantic fishery. Had the government paid the attention that the fishery deserved over the last few years, we would not be here tonight.
We all know that the government has not paid enough attention and the fishery is in crisis again. The other day in Question Period the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans said that this government has done everything possible to help the fishery and that the fault for the problem was an
February 19, 1992

agreement signed by the Liberal government 20 years ago.
I say to the government that 20 years ago there was enough fish off our shores for everybody. Today, after eight years of mismanagement, there is not enough fish to keep the communities alive. The European Community has consistently overfished its NAFO quotas for several years and the government has done nothing.
The minister says that he has talked with his European counterparts about the problem. He has told the Spanish and Portuguese that they must stop the raping of Canadian fish stocks outside the 200-mile limit. The minister says he is doing everything he can and that he is conducting delicate, diplomatic negotiations.
If the government had any concern for the groundfish-ermen of Atlantic Canada, it would claim its right under International Law of the Sea Convention and extend the 200-mile limit to include the nose and tail of the Grand Banks and the Flemish Cap. This is our right and was recommended by Leslie Harris over two years ago.
Many of my constituents think that the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans is afraid to offend the Spanish, Portuguese, Koreans, and others. The time has come for this government to take action and enforce Canadian management of all fish stocks, especially straddling stocks. Unfortunately we all know what this government is like enforcing our fishery regulations.
While government allows the harassment of small inshore groundfishermen and forcing dockside monitoring down their throats, it lets Spain and Portugal rob us blind.
The government should cancel all foreign fishing licences in Canadian waters, especially for food fish. What sense is there in allowing foreign vessels into Canadian waters to fish for things like mackerel, capelin and squid? These fish are the basis for the food chain and the foreigners are literally stealing the food from the mouth of the cod. No wonder fishermen are saying that the fish are getting smaller, the cod are starving to death.
It is not only food fish that foreigners are allowed to catch in Canadian waters. The French are allowed to catch 1,600 tonnes of 4T cod each year, the fish that groundfishermen in my riding depend upon for their livelihood.
Fishermen in my riding want to know why they have to take over 10,000 tonnes in quota cuts since 1990 and the first French quota has gone up by 260 tonnes.
The crisis in the Atlantic fishery is not only a crisis of declining stocks, it is a crisis of mismanagement and the government is to blame.
The crisis is not only in cod stocks off Newfoundland and Labrador, it is in every harbour and bay across Atlantic Canada. Ask any fisherman in Prince Edward Island about DFO and he will give you a list of things the government is doing wrong in the fishery: lack of repairs to small craft harbours, lobster size increases, and dockside monitoring to name but a few.
Since I was elected in 1988, wharfs and breakwaters in the Cardigan riding have been falling apart. Wharves like Graham's Pond and Launching required only about $50,000 of maintenance work two or three years ago to keep them in shape.
However, because the federal government did not spend that small amount of money two years ago, the cost of doing major reconstruction has gone up to well over $1 million for the two wharves. If this is not mismanagement I do not know what it is.
There is also the issue of increasing lobster sizes for island fishermen. Last year, DFO increased lobster size for fishermen on the south shore of P.E.I. while keeping the same size on the north side. This move by government has been a disaster for the fishermen in my riding.
In a year where there was a 5,000 metric tonne reduction in cod quotas, the government reduced canner catches in zone 26A by about 1.3 million pounds. These small canner lobsters filled a very special market area and the size increases could effect a loss of over $14 million in that product area alone.
There was no problem with the lobster stocks, there was no need for conservation measures, in fact lobster stocks have been increasing steadily for many years.

Playing with the lobster size has been a major financial blow to the fishermen of Prince Edward Island. It is mismanagement pure and simple. Snow crab fishermen in my riding are concerned about a proposal to allow licences for more fishermen in that fishery.
According to a DFO proposal, Island fishermen are to be shut out from applying for the new licences despite the fact that the licences are for the area off eastern P.E.I. Indeed, Island fishermen were not even told by DFO that more licences were being considered. Fishermen found this out by word of mouth. Fishermen from eastern Prince Edward Island should be given a crack at the new licences. Not giving Islanders a chance is mismanagement as far as I am concerned.
The real crisis in the Atlantic fishery is a mismanagement crisis. Because of mismanagement by this government, the northern cod stocks are dropping like a stone, throwing thousands of people out of work. Because of the government mismanagement, wharfs and breakwaters in my riding are literally falling into the sea.
The fishery has been a way of life in Atlantic Canada for about 500 years and that way of life has been destroyed. The fishing industry in Atlantic Canada is more than simply dollars and cents. With proper management, Atlantic Canada can handle a proper fishing industry with thriving communities scattered around the coast.
Until this government takes concrete action against mismanagement and foreign fishing, the fishermen and plant workers in Atlantic Canada will continue to suffer needlessly.
Concerning the repairs to small craft harbours, I have some information compiled by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans. I believe it is a prime example of why the Savage Harbour breakwater on which I tried to persuade government three years ago to spend a small amount of dollars to repair and why Graham Pond wharf needs $1 million today. Launching and Georgetown and many other harbours are in a desperate state.
I just happen to have the figures of DFO spending on small craft harbours for the riding of St. John's West which happens to be represented by the Minister of
Fisheries and Oceans and the dollars allotted to Prince Edward Island which has four ridings.
I will give a couple of examples since time is short. In
1990-91 about $8.5 million was spent in St. John's West and $1.3 million was spent in the four ridings in Prince Edward Island. In 1991-92 $3.5 million was spent in St. John's West, in the hon. minister's riding, and in the four ridings in Prince Edward Island we did not get $1 million.
It is no wonder that the breakwaters and the wharfs in Prince Edward Island are falling into the sea. This is total mismanagement. It is totally unacceptable and hopefully, with these figures becoming public, pressure will be put on government and the minister will see fit to spend the proper dollars on small craft harbours in Prince Edward Island.

speakeroldname: Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands- Canso):
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to take a few minutes to speak on this emergency debate.
I want to begin by congratulating my colleague, the hon. member for Burin-St. George's, for taking the initiative to bring this emergency debate forward and Your Honour for accepting his motion.
The revised information from the scientists of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans on the state of the northern cod was released this week. It demonstrates that the biomass or the stock of the northern cod in 2J-3K-L off the eastern coast of Newfoundland and Labrador is much lower than was previously estimated. It is indeed an emergency. It is a crisis and warrants the concern of all members of this House.
There is a certain sense of deja vu in the debate we are having this evening. I remember the last time we had an emergency debate on the fishery. I remember very well because I called for the emergency debate. That debate took place on December 18, 1989, in response to a decision by National Sea to close its fish plant in Canso, Nova Scotia, thereby throwing 750 fish plant workers and trawlermen out of work and effectively shutting down this coastal community in my constituency which has been a fishing community for over 400 years.
February 19, 1992

At the same time National Sea Products announced the downsizing of its operations in Newfoundland and other parts of Nova Scotia and Fisheries Products International did the same. That was a crisis and an emergency affecting all of Atlantic Canada.
The crisis was precipitated by a fall in Canadian fish quotas and an increase in the difficulty both offshore and inshore fisheries industry had in catching the quota available to the Canadian 'fishery. As a result, National Sea was making the corporate decision to close these plants, as was Fisheries Products International.
Members will recall that as a result of that debate and the passionate interventions that were made on all sides of this House during that evening and as a result of a very determined fight led by the mayor and town council of Canso for about four months, this government finally relented, intervened and worked out, in conjunction with the Government of Nova Scotia and other consortia in Atlantic Canada, an arrangement that allowed the fish plant in Canso to be purchased and reopened and allowed the fish plant in Burgeo to reopen and essentially save those communities.
We have to say that because of the government's actions in this respect, the people in Canso are grateful, even though it took a tremendous battle on their part. They are grateful that this action was taken and that this company, Sea Freeze, was allowed to preserve the jobs in those communities. That was in May or August of 1990. What has happened since then?
The underlying cause of the crisis is basically the failure of the government to control the over-all effort by Canadians and by foreign fisheries vessels to control the pressure on our cod stocks and the entire groundfish stocks which exist off our coast. The failure of the government to do this means that we are once again confronted with the evidence which precipitates this crisis and this emergency debate only three years later.
The crisis we face this evening, as other members have said, is not a crisis affecting only one part of Canada. It is not a crisis affecting only Newfoundland. It is a national crisis and it is a social crisis. It is a crisis for the thousands of families who live in coastal communities all across the northeastern coast of Newfoundland and Labrador who have absolutely no alternative but to pursue the fishery, the way of life which they and their ancestors have followed for generations.
If there is no fishery, if it continues the way it is, these communities are decimated. Either those families live on welfare or handouts or they have to leave. They have to leave behind that part of the country and that way of life which they have carried on for generations. So it is a social crisis.
It is an economic crisis because 21 per cent of all employed in Newfoundland, 41,800 jobs in 1989, depend on fish harvesting and fish processing. It is a similar number in Nova Scotia. There are 100,000 jobs in Atlantic Canada that are fisheries related. If the fisheries goes, there is no immediate prospect for those communities that depend exclusively in many cases on this industry. This government in seven years and with all the talk and the so-called initiatives about development in Atlantic Canada has not found a satisfactory alternative to those traditional industries which nurture so many parts of Atlantic Canada. The collapse of the northern cod stocks is an economic crisis.
It is an environmental crisis as well because it represents a plundering, mostly by man, of a resource which had heretofore been considered to be inexhaustible. We are discovering that it is not inexhaustible. It behoves us as a society to begin to understand the environmental consequences of the failure to manage a resource, to consider that the pressures on this resource, if they are not checked, will ultimately lead to its extinction, that we take the kind of drastic action nations around the world are beginning to take to control another environmental crisis, namely, the depletion of the ozone or the global warming which we, after ignoring this crisis for so many years, are finally beginning to address. This is a problem not unlike that.
To conclude, because I realize my time is up, I want to point out this is a crisis of sovereignty. It represents a failure of Canada, of this government, to exercise its sovereignty. For the people, not only in Atlantic Canada, but elsewhere in Canada, it is all too familiar. It is all too familiar that this government talks a good line and talks in this House of Commons about all the efforts, as the Secretary of State for External Affairs said just a few minutes ago, it has taken to convince other countries, but still nothing happens. Still we see that in 1989 the economic community overfished its own quota by 44,700 tonnes. It overfished its quota in 1990 by 60,000 tonnes and in 1991, while our own quota dropped from 197,000

tonnes, the amount we were able to catch, to 127,000 tonnes, it over fished its quota by 47,000 tonnes.
It is time, as we have suggested on this side of the House, to unilaterally extend that jurisdiction, to get control of that zone, and to begin managing that resource properly.
