subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: I would appreciate if the hon. member would indicate to the Chair how long he intends to speak.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would think two or three, maybe four hours, but if I am restricted, I guess 20 minutes will be the maximum.
It has been a long time since I have spoken in this House. In fact, it has probably been a long time since I have been in this House, preoccupied, perhaps unjustly for my constituents, but preoccupied as I have been in the matters of national unity and the Constitution. Not even the Constitution could keep me away this evening.
I want to congratulate the hon. member as well for this debate. I think this debate is important. I think this debate provides us with the opportunity to ensure that all members of this House, and indeed anybody in this country who is interested and is watching, understand how important the fishery is to Atlantic Canada, and particularly to those of us from Newfoundland and Labrador.
I was asked the other day by a reporter who wanted to know about the debate. I congratulated the member and said that what it does is it continuously allows us to reinforce across this country that this is indeed a national issue. This is not some regional issue. This is not something that just pertains to us in Atlantic Canada and primarily us in Newfoundland and Labrador who are most directly affected by the impact of reduced cod stocks.
The fishery in our province I think represents about 6 per cent of the economy. That is just economy. Some people say: "That does not sound like a lot". It probably
represents 25 per cent of the employment, and that represents a lot. That is direct and indirect.
As well, in every part of the island of Newfoundland and in every part of the mainland part of our province in Labrador, the fishery has a psychological impact and it has an emotional impact. My family has been involved in the fishery for years. My father took the oldest company in Canada, older than Molson's, out of the fish business in 1967-68. My God, history was being rewritten. They had come from Liverpool in 1720, 1730 and operated in the fish business in our province until 1967 or 1968. It has been a part of me.
It is a part of all of us because we are affected when others are affected, not only in terms of the economy. They always say in Newfoundland and Labrador that you can tell how the fishery is doing by how the car sales are going or how things are going in the hardware business. People say: "What is happening with the fishery?"
For far too long we disregarded the views of the fishermen, inshore and offshore. We sort of said that they have an opinion but they do not understand the science or they do not understand the cycles of fish or their evidence is anecdotal. I like that. I have always liked that, "anecdotal". Finally, thank God, we are recognizing that there is wisdom and knowledge there.
This tie I am wearing is in honour of Dr. Bondar. This is the space agency tie and it was presented to me some four or five years ago. It struck me that we can put Canadians and Americans and representatives of the economic union of states, or whatever flag in the Olympics, people from Indian and Pakistan, into space and we wonder why we cannot find fish. People in Newfoundland and Labrador wonder about that.
Fortunately or unfortunately, aeronautical science or space science is much more developed than fish science. We are coming a long way on fish science. I think it is recognized that in 1974, 1975, 1976 and 1977 when we moved into the implementation of our end of the deal on the Law of the Sea, the imposition of the 200-mile economic zone, our knowledge of science was not that good and it put us in a bind. We made assumptions at the time that were probably invalid on which we made a variety of decisions, repeatedly making mistake after
February 19, 1992

mistake in good faith, based on the best knowledge available.
We have had to improve our science. We have had to improve our science in the pure science end of the world. We have had to improve our science and the ability to collect more information and to analyse it better. We have had to improve our science and the way we use it, the type of information we provide and the type of decisions that get made on the basis of that science.
In 1986 there was a significant strengthening in the effort in Newfoundland and Labrador, a 22 per cent increase. Under the current Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program we are spending something like $150 million over five years to improve the amount of data we have, to improve its collection and its analysis.
We are also doing something that is new and different and is perhaps more significant than all the money we are spending, and it probably costs us nothing. We are saying to the people in the industry, in the inshore and the offshore: "You know about fish, in an anecdotal way, but you know about fish. Come and participate in the process of science, come and tell us what you know, come and tell us what we are doing that might be made better. In the process we will show you what we as scientists do and how it may in fact make your lives better and improve your ability to fish".
Science is an important part of what we do but it is only one component, as I think everybody in this House knows.
We have had an evolution in our fishery. We have the capacity today to catch a lot more fish than we have had in the past, both in trawlers offshore and in the inshore fishery, with the evolution of equipment and gear, particularly the development of the Japanese cod trap. The fishermen in Torbay, Flat Rock, Pooch Cove, Bau-line, Portugal Cove, Fox Trap, Kelligrews, Holyrood, Conception, Harbour Main, Brigus, Cupids, Bell Island, and Collier's-please, if I have left anybody out in St. John's East forgive me. It is certainly not to forget the people of Lance au Clair, Loggie Bay, Middle Cove, Outer Cove, and certainly the people of the Battery and Quidi Vidi.
What are they saying about all of this? They say: "All we want is the opportunity to fish. What we need is the fish. As for the rest of it, we can deal with governments at a variety of levels, or we can collectively as fishermen
manage the fishery as best we can, to use equipment and the resources of government as best we can". They also say: "If we don't have fish, what is it that we do then?"
They have come to government and said: "We're in trouble, we need help". Frankly, my experience is for the most part that the fishermen who do that are really in trouble and really do need help. They do not ask until that time comes.
In the meantime there are a number of things that government can do. As I think all members know and I am sure my colleagues have said earlier tonight, when the need has been there the government has been there. Certainly there have been emergency response programs in the last three or four years to ensure the fishermen qualify for unemployment insurance. That is something they do not particularly want to do but they must if they can only fish six, eight or ten weeks a year, or as some fishermen in the constituency of my friend across the way who expect to fish in the winter and there are no fish in the winter. We have to provide that protection, and we have been there.
Last year, in response to a critical situation caused by an abundance of ice, we provided about $18 million to try to pick up that slack. As well there was a terrible catch failure last year. All the inshore fishermen are aware of that. That is not to mention the offshore fishermen. We caught just over half the inshore fish last year that we had caught the year before. The government was there. People expect government to be there in the bad times. Hopefully government can be there in the good times, not to hand out money needlessly but to support the development and evolution of our fishery. I want to come back to that.
I want to remind members that the last two or three years have not been good. They have been desperate. They have been desperate for fishermen and their families. They have been desperate for communities and they have been desperate for provinces. Government has been able to provide some support. The Fisheries Adjustment Program has provided $584 or $585 million. As I mentioned $150 million of that was to try to rebuild stocks, improve science, improve monitoring, have more flights and surveillance inshore and offshore to deal with foreigners. Adjusting to current realities is what they call a program that is saying to communities: "You are the source of the solution to your problems. We are there to help you with all the resources that we have including

February 19, 1992
money". The Public Service has been tremendously supportive.
I also remind members of the ability of two levels of government to work together, the ability of four or five departments at two levels of government to work together, primarily at the municipal level with regional economic development commissions, in developing Community Futures Programs, developing local responses to problems, trying to find opportunities in the fishery, trying to develop alternatives, trying to diversify the economy where possible. We provided about $150 million for that.
It is not enough just to put money into response to the fishery in crisis. It is critical that we build so that when the stocks return, when the opportunities are there, it is a modern fishery that is integrated into an economy based on technology, efficiency, effectiveness and international trade in a competitive way.
The world of the fishery these days is unbelievably competitive. In the old days it was one species against another, one country's cod against another country's cod. We are long past that. The substitution in the large markets has been terribly threatening, particularly to the east coast cod fishery as pollack from Alaska has replaced it in the big American fast food markets which are now our big customers, which are now the source of good contracts for big offshore companies and for many smaller operations that buy from inshore fishermen.
The Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency played a substantial role in the ability to support the fishery, particularly in terms of fishery's innovation. We have supported the centre for fisheries innovation at the Marine Institute in St. John's which is now becoming part of Memorial. There has been a number of initiatives marrying education with industrial initiatives, bringing people together who have ideas, others who have a technical capacity, others who have a marketing capability, others who have an academic capability that provides some good research and development in market development, product development and health and safety standards.
Today there are 15 co-operative agreements between the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and the Government of Canada. I guess co-operative agreements are a new way of saying DREE or DRIE or whatever manifestation they have taken over a period of time. It is government sitting down and working out programs to attack problems, to take advantage of opportunities and to deal with challenges. Just going through the 15 of them from my own memory and my own knowledge, some of them I am not particularly familiar with. The inshore fisheries development agreement is obviously direct. NAFTA has provided tremendous support, particularly to small plant operators, to fishermen who need equipment and to those who have innovation and are able to take that innovation and make it grow.
The comprehensive Labrador agreement has done a tremendous amount to improve facilities along the coast of Labrador. The ocean industries agreement is not directly related to fishery, but it builds on the capacity that after 450 years of having a fishery we now have a technical capability that is focused on our marine world. We live along side of the Atlantic Ocean. We have traded across the sea. We have traded with products that come from the sea. We have a capability in our province that involves marine communications and the application of computer and high-technology innovations to a world that is bounded by oceans. One very exciting innovation has been over the horizon radar. We in this country are world leaders in that development and that has come from the fact that our history is based on the fisheries.
As we look at the environmental improvement agreements, the rural development agreement, enterprise agreements, they are focused on what we can do in the fishery. I would be a fool if I stood here and said: "We have done it all. We have taken care of it. Everything is copacetic". It is not. We have a serious problem. The fish that people, communities, companies large and small in Newfoundland and Labrador and Atlantic Canada generally have depended on are apparently not there. Sometimes we wonder: "My God, what more can happen to us?" Sometimes we wonder if it is some bizarre whodunnit and if we just clicked the channels it would all go away. It does not happen. Believe me, I have clicked a
February 19, 1992

lot of channels lately and it is still there. It is right there in the kitchens, the bedrooms and the boats of people all across Atlantic Canada.
What do we do? We obviously cannot make the fish come back. We have to continue to find ways of managing our knowledge of the fishery, making sure that the decisions we take in the management are based on the best knowledge, advice and analysis available. We have to continue to work with the industry to ensure that we get the best productivity, the best use of the resources we have, and the best benefit to the fishermen, the plant workers and those in between so that we can continue to export a high quality, competitive product around the world.
We must continue as governments provincial and federal to be responsive to needs in times of tragedy, in times of crisis, and in times of threat. We must be there with the support that is necessary to keep the industry moving, to keep the communities whole, and to keep families together.
We must continue to ensure that the world knows that we are under a direct environmental threat that in my view is wanton and deliberate and callous, that is totally uncaring of knowledge of the damage and the threat that is being caused to this resource we have worked so hard to manage, and that we have taken decisions that closed whole communities, that put families and people in jeopardy, literally at jeopardy of survival. Yet the Europeans continue to fish not at levels of the past, not to meet their commitments to reduce, but to increase.
I and other members of this House have gone in good faith to our colleagues in legislatures in Europe. Some think of it as a grand boondoggle. It is hard work. We have sat in the Senate in Paris. We have looked at the bullet holes in the ceiling of the Parliament in Madrid. We have talked to representatives of the fishing industry and communities that go through somewhat the same thing we do. We say: "We want you over there. You have been part of our lives for 400 years. But, by God, if you don't do what is responsible for all of us, there will be no fishery there".
The Prime Minister, senior ministers in this government, senior officials of the opposition parties, colleagues, senior people in provincial governments, industry and labour have gone to Europe, have talked to the Spanish and the Portuguese and have talked to the European Community. We have yelled. We have
screamed. We have begged. We have cajoled. I would not be surprised if there were probably a few bottles of rum offered, but to no avail.
At the end of the day what offends me more than anything else is that there is a deliberate, wanton, uncaring process of continuing to take fish outside an agreed management system, threatening the viability of our four Atlantic provinces, Quebec, and this country, without regard for the people who are there. Despite the very direct approaches that process cannot continue.
I end with those words. We have a future in the fishery. We have to manage it properly. We in government with the support of the opposition and others will continue to provide that help, but we cannot continue this environmental threat.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise tonight to take part in this debate on the state of the fishery in Atlantic Canada. It is certainly not a happy occasion because, as has been said here tonight by many of the great speakers that have gone before me, this is not a regional or provincial issue. This is a national issue. This is one of the oldest industries in Canada. It is a vital segment of our east coast economy.
A number of years ago Atlantic Canadians stood on the threshold of a bright and prosperous future as a result of the potential of the fisheries. The extension of the fishing limit to 200 miles should have, in and of itself, guaranteed that the fisheries would be a major income producer in Atlantic Canada.
Instead over the past few years it has become the source of continual economic bad news.
Again here tonight we stand to debate fishery policies and again we hear the government claim it is not its fault. Well it is time for someone to take some responsibility for the sorry state of affairs. If the members of the government do not realize where the blame should be placed, let me tell you the people of Atlantic Canada know.
There is an expression that we are all familiar with that says: "Don't lock the door after the horse is stolen". It is fine to stand up now and say that the northern cod stock, the main part of the Newfoundland and Labrador fishery, is depleted and our quota must be cut in half. Surely a person with the intelligence and the integrity of the current minister, backed by the expertise of his

February 19, 1992
department, should have been able to foresee this alarming development long ago.
We have allowed this potentially golden goose to be stolen away from the residents of Atlantic Canada because this government does not have the fortitude to deal with the European Community, and other communities continue to plunder this resource.
If the government was as tough on non-Canadians as it has been on the residents of this country, we would not be involved with such things as the disastrous free trade deal.
Earlier this week the minister spoke in the media about foreign overfishing as if it was a newly discovered phenomenon. The presence of foreign trawlers and the lack of effort of policing the fishery off the east coast has been with us for a good number of years. To raise the issue now with such indignation is like trying to convince Canadians that this government is a stalwart supporter of supply management and marketing boards.
Like the marketing boards at the negotiations at GATT, I fear that the fishery has been abandoned by this government. We will now see a bit of window-dressing trying to convince the fishermen and the taxpayers of Canada it is really strongly supporting this fishery.
I fear it may be too late. The horse has been stolen and it is time to replace the watchman at the stable.
We live in a hungry world, a world in which people, such as we who control such a large proportion of the available food supply, should be able to turn to our advantage. It is ludicrous that we should be constantly telling Newfoundlanders and other Atlantic Canadians not to fish. But it is just as ludicrous that thousands of tonnes of fish have been dumped back into the ocean because the government is not able to develop a policy which would firstly protect and secondly conserve this precious national resource.
By allowing others to continually deplete our resources, we are on the verge of creating an economic and an ecological wasteland in Atlantic Canada. Although many people do not realize it, the east coast fishery is one of our very special natural resources.
Why do we allow the fishery, which should be one of the main economic engines driving our economy in the east, to be plundered in this fashion? Why will the government and the minister not stand and defend our east coast fishery and, in doing so, show Canadians how important they believe and we believe this industry is?
There is very little offshore fishing in my province, but the inshore fishermen realize the harm which has been done to their fishery by the management of the offshore resource.
The catches inshore are declining because the fish have been scooped up offshore by vessels from around the world. I can agree with the minister and with officials at the department that there is a limited number of fish.
What I want to see as a maritimer is fish which should be considered a Canadian resource being utilized to the benefit of the residents of this country. Let the minister who had this responsibility develop policies which will see that the number of fish available are used by Canadians. Also let the minister help Canadian firms and companies develop ways to add value to that product.
Let us keep the fish plants operating and let us keep the fishermen of Atlantic Canada fishing. The precious natural resources of our region should not be used as trading chips in the international games any more than the resources of other parts of the country should be.
When John Cabot came to the waters off Newfoundland 500 years ago he reported that codfish could be taken by lowering a basket over the side. No doubt the numbers have declined but I now ask the minister to always remember that those fish in the Atlantic waters are part of our birthright.
Do not mismanage and do not give away one of the things which could bring our economy out of the economic slump we are in at the present time. These are good people, good fishermen, and good workers. Manage our resource to the benefit of Canadians first and to the benefit of the maximum number of fishermen workers.
This is an industry that was built for the small operator. I say to the government and to the minister: Do not turn your back on them during this present crisis.
February 19, 1992

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is the second time in two years that this House sits late at night to hold an emergency debate on the Atlantic fisheries.

I want to say a few words on the fishery because it is rather interesting to think that less than three years-actually two years and a few months, probably a couple of months, three months-this is the second emergency debate that we have had on the Atlantic fishery.
This has to tell Canadians there is something wrong. We do not need the Globe editorials to tell us that this government is doing something wrong, or that it cannot handle or manage the fishery. On this side of the House, we certainly know that. My colleagues and I have fought for many years on the subject of foreign fishing.
This is the third minister of fisheries we have had since November 21, 1988. That goes to show you, Mr. Speaker, that something is definitely wrong with the calibre of this Prime Minister's cabinet in dealing with the most important natural resource that we have on the east coast. It is a natural resource. It is a renewable resource and it is food.
We are debating tonight foreign fishing in and outside our 200-mile limit. I listened to the minister for external affairs. I totally agree with her. Under the 200-mile limit, Canada is fortunate to have such a large coastline and to have such a bounty. That natural resource, that bounty, is food. It is food to feed the world.
Not once did I hear her say, or did I hear her colleague the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans say, that we were going to fish the underutilized fish and put the biggest effort into fishing what foreigners that come from Japan, Cuba, eastern Europe, Europe, all over come to fish. They fish outside the 200-mile limit but they come inside and fish the underutilized species that supposedly are excess to our needs under the Law of the Sea and the share in the 200-mile limit that we were given in 1977.
I was looking at the notes of the emergency debate and I said at that time, over two years ago that yes, there was a crisis yes, we had overcapacity fishing, overcapacity in
plants, but we also had over 100 freezer factory ships fishing within our waters, fish that our fishermen could catch.
I have not seen one realistic incentive to put for those boats that have the capacity to go out and fish and those plants that have the capacity to work. We have some semblance of an effort but we do not seem to know exactly why the Japanese come over here and fish and why we cannot do the same thing they do. If it means money, then use the ACOA money that has been wasted for the most part in Atlantic Canada because it has not gone to create too many jobs in those fishing villages which have no longer a fish plant working, have no longer boats working.
I heard one of my colleagues in the House talk about cultural genocide. That is what it is when community after community is hurting because of the lack of a decision or a lack of an ability of this government to have a creative program. We have all that supply there.
Tonight I asked one of the pages who is from Nova Scotia this:

"What do you think needs to be done?" This young man, who was about 19 years old, replied: "We have the technology. We can do the whole production. How come it is not being done?"

That is what this government has to say to the young people in Atlantic Canada. Why have we not put money into research and development instead of having the foreigners come over here year after year to catch the under-utilized species? As they catch the under-utilized species they get a by-catch. That by-catch is not a small amount. That by-catch could keep a plant going in one small community in Nova Scotia. Not once has any one of the three fisheries ministers put any effort into going out and saying to the Japanese: "Next year we are catching that fish", or to the eastern Europeans, or to the Cubans: "We are going to catch that fish and we will sell it to you, and if you do not want it, we will get rid of it somewhere else. We will sell it somewhere else because it is food". What does it take to sell food in these countries where people are starving? Not once has that happened and we have had three ministers.

February 19, 1992
Obviously the intelligence of three ministers is not as high as the young student who said to me tonight what he would do. That is a young person looking at a natural resource on his doorstep. I have to read The Globe and Mail and be told that we are always looking for handouts. If this government would start focusing on the fact that we have the capacity, we have the technology to fish and to process. What we need is the political will to change.
I sit back and listen to this debate on foreign fishing within our waters and outside our waters. If we could do away with those 100 or more freezer factory ships that come well equipped to process fish for those countries that we should be fishing, I would think as you did away with the effort of those 100 ships or more, they would not have the same desire to come and fish outside the 200-mile limit. Perhaps again we might be able to show NAFO we were serious about what we were doing within our 200-mile limit. As we came to show we were serious, they would begin to put teeth into what the foreigners are overfishing and what they are doing in raping a natural resource. It is a bounty that we do not mind sharing outside, but certainly within our 200-mile limit. We are not a very strong example to the foreigners who have come repeatedly and repeatedly and in larger numbers every year to fish stock that we are forbidden to fish because they have a by-catch in spawning areas.
I know my time is coming to a close, but I have sat here and listened to the ministers. I cannot believe there is that inability to react. I cannot believe the fisheries committee has not met. I heard the chairman tonight. I cannot believe people at The Globe & Mail can just write an editorial crossing us off and saying we are going down the road again or Atlantic Canada is going down the road. I cannot believe they can be so stupid to not criticize this government instead in an editorial once in awhile.
We are going to see our agriculture go out the window if the GATT agreement is signed. The Prime Minister says it may come to that land we have to sign it. President Bush is not saying that. We have a Prime Minister who is going around saying we may have to sign it. The President is not saying that.
It is the same thing here with the overfishing and the foreigners' fishing. We do not have a Prime Minister who is going to stand up and say that we are going to protect our natural resources first.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker.
We have before us tonight a motion for the purpose of discussing a specific and important matter requiring urgent consideration, namely the situation in the Atlantic fisheries sponsored by the hon. member from Burin- St. George's. Truly this is indeed an emergency situation and a situation in which we from every side of the House of Commons have every right to take part in and put our collective minds together.
Earlier this week in the local paper, there was an article entitled "Where Have All the Fish Gone?". It was written by Elaine Flaherty from Southam News Service out of Halifax. It says:
The accounts from the early explorers of Newfoundland described a sea of plenty; cod fish that swarmed to snatch bait from a man's hand; fish so thick by the shoal that we hardly were able to row a boat through them. The northern cod fishery built a sustained Newfoundland. Historically, it is the reason for the province's existence and today it accounts for about 30,000 jobs in Newfoundland and $700 million of the country's economy.
A popular poster showing an old photo of a small child dwarfed by an enormous fish beside him underlies the rock's resilience on the fishery. "In cod we trust" it reads. Today that trust is seriously undermined, if not gone like the abundant catches of the past. All last summer fishermen off the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador hauled in empty nets and wondered about where the fish had gone. This week the scientists delivered the bleak news.
The news delivered by the scientists was a very sobering scientific report of the state of the northern cod. It was made public this past Monday. It was discussed at a special meeting of provincial fisheries ministers and the Atlantic groundfish advisory committee. The Canadian Atlantic Fishery Scientific Advisory Committee or CAFSAC have told us that the northern cod biomass has declined from 1.2 million tonnes in 1990 to 780,000 tonnes in 1991. Truly that is a remarkable change in one year. The spawning stock has dropped to
130,000	tonnes from 270,000 tonnes. We from the west coast do not understand that the cod stocks on the Atlantic live for several years. Seven years is really the prime of their existence. On the west coast the cycle for salmon is four years and after they spawn they die. In the Atlantic it is different. We want to make sure that there are sufficient spawners. They start spawning around age three. The hon. members opposite from the east will know this far better than I do, being from the west coast. Nonetheless the spawning biomass has been seriously depleted and the new numbers that have come in have really been shocking.
February 19, 1992

Catches of northern cod have been falling since 1988. Last year barely more than two-thirds of the Canadian quotas were caught. The minister is now considering the CAFSAC report and the views expressed at the meeting and is consulting widely with the representatives of industry. I am sure we can expect an announcement shortly on the government's response to this serious situation.
Earlier tonight the minister said he would be making his announcement next Monday. I know it is his plan to be back in Newfoundland for the latter part of this week.
In considering what to do it is clear that the government must put a priority on conservation and the long-term health and viability of the stock. It must also consider the potential impact of quota cuts on the incomes and well-being of inshore and offshore fleets, on fishermen, on plant workers, on the communities in Newfoundland and elsewhere which depend on the fishery.
Another very important factor in this complex equation is the continuing supply of this important species of fish to world markets. Although it is only one of twelve Canadian cod stocks, northern cod is by far the most important. We are known and want to continue to be known as reliable suppliers of cod. We need a balanced response to the new situation but we also need a balanced perspective on the complete picture for Canadian fisheries. We still have an ample supply of Canadian cod for the marketplace this year, not to mention other species of fish, shellfish and seafoods.
I do not need to explain the benefits at the end of the chain, to the retail market. However, we do need sound fisheries management that can be promoted from year to year so that there is a reliable resource and a source for the retail market.
In another paper in an editorial entitled Less Fishing Will Replenish Stocks it said: "NAFO recommended a northern cod catch of zero for 1991". Earlier tonight we heard people commenting about the overfishing by the Europeans. This article goes on to say: "The European Community fishermen ignored NAFO's advice and caught an estimated 42,000 tonnes of northern cod last year compared with 132,600 tonnes by the Canadians in the rest of the area. If a resource management regime is
to be effective it must cover the entire resource. Otherwise our efforts to conserve stocks will only benefit and be neutralized by the foreign fleets who catch the fish when they cross the 200-mile limit".
Some tonight have suggested that Canada should unilaterally take possession outside the 200-mile limit. However that is easier said than done. The Secretary of State for External Affairs has explained to us tonight some of the things we would have to watch in trying to do that. It is all very well to talk about gunboat diplomacy but is that the real answer that we need? Once again we must try to see if we can get our European neighbours across the Atlantic-in particular two countries, Spain and Portugal, that we feel have not played by the rules as the others have-to joint in.
There is also a suggestion concerning the number of foreign licences permitted to fish within our 200-mile limit. It must be remembered that these are for the species that Canadians have not caught, have not wanted to catch, and in some cases have not been able to catch because we do not have the equipment to do it. I am sure this will have to be seriously looked at in light of what is now taking place in the industry.
We also know what has been taking place since we had to stop taking young seals. Now we only have some culling of the adult seals. We now know that the numbers of seals have more than doubled from what they were some five to six years ago. We know they feast on part of the food chain within the fisheries. We do not know precisely what they eat but we know it starts with the capelin. If they eat the capelin then it is not there for the cod to feed upon to allow them to continue their growth cycle. Therefore, very serious consideration will have to be given to how to handle the seals and how to cull them much faster than they are now.
Tonight we have heard a great deal of blame being attached to the present minister. This minister has been in this portfolio less than one year. This minister has been part of the government during the downturn in the northern cod stocks. However, I think it is most unfair for people to hold this minister responsible for the drop of the biomass and problems like that when our own scientists have changed their estimates of what was out there just within the last three months. The advice they were giving to this minister has changed negatively, very

February 19, 1992
drastically, from as late as November and December of this past year.
It is a situation in which we all must be vigilant be very much aware of the people who are going to be affected if the minister has to announce on the weekend a serious cutback in the amount of fish that will be allowed to be caught over the next several months. We know this resource is renewable. It is something that will not become extinct. If we carefully nurture and watch over this resource it will renew itself and return to the condition it was in and has been in for these many years.
I would ask the indulgence of members opposite as well. I would ask that during Question Period in this House they ask the questions that need to be asked. However, by the same token, it serves no useful purpose to do it in such a way as to cause hysteria in people's minds because their constituents are watching at home. What kind of a message are they trying to send? Are they trying to say: "Oh, it is all the government's fault" when nature has a very serious influence on what takes place.
We, in this government, have done many things. However, I am sure that we do not have much influence on what nature does. We did not have any influence over the ice situation which affected the fishery last year. When there are changes in the atmosphere or in the water temperatures, whether it be on the east coast or west coast, the government does not have any control over them.
Yet it seems that some members opposite take great delight in fingering government members as the ones who could have an influence over that.
I welcome the opportunity to take part in this debate. I want those on the east coast, particularly those in Newfoundland who are going to be more seriously affected by this than any other single group of people, to know that we all care deeply about them and their welfare. We will be doing everything possible to make sure that we are able to tide them over through these next several weeks and months.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is a difficult issue we are facing here this evening. It is with thanks to you that the emergency debate was allowed. As has been said before, an emergency debate is an unusual thing and is something the Speaker does not normally grant that readily. From our vantage point, it shows the seriousness of this particular crisis in the fishing industry.
We have heard all kinds of talk this evening, with blame and all those sorts of things attached to the issue. I think we have to look at this as a national issue, the impact on all of Atlantic Canada and really all of Canada. When you look at the number of people who are involved you see astounding numbers in the hundreds of thousands of people. Even in my own province of New Brunswick there are almost 12,000 or
13,000	people involved directly as fishermen and plant workers in the fishing industry. This all has an impact. What we are seeing in Newfoundland could very easily be happening somewhere else. You really have to ask yourself this question. You can give the government the benefit of the doubt and say it managed this industry properly, everything worked out fine and it is just an environmental catastrophe that struck out of the clear blue and there was nothing that it could do. The other answer is that it has totally mismanaged the industry and there was a whole bunch of things that it could do.
Either way, no matter which way you look at it, and I am sure that people in Newfoundland would agree, if the industry was properly managed, they would have anticipated this problem. There were warning signals that had been cast about for the last number of years. I know that we on this side and the members from Newfoundland in particular have been warning the government year after year, Question Period after Question Period, and the fishermen the same. This government tinkered. It did not actually deal with the problem. It was a tinkerer rather than finding the root problems and solving them. Now we have the crisis and we are going to go into crisis management. That, again, is not the way it should be done. We are facing mismanagement of a resource. That is the reality of the situation and something has to be done.
We know there is overfishing. We have heard all the statistics of the European overfishing. We realize that is the nub of the issue, probably the thing that grates the
February 19, 1992

most. We know there has been illegal fishing. It has occurred year after year after year and nothing has been done, and so the frustration does come forward and people are concerned. This has caused the environmental problem. You see things and you scratch your head and you try to wonder what will be going on in people's minds when they give a quota to the CIS, the Commonwealth of Independent States, formerly the Soviet Union. They give them capelin, the feed stock of northern cod. You just scratch your head and ask why they would do that. Yet they did. Then they say that it was an environmental disaster. Granting the licence was the disaster. It had nothing to do with the environment.
This is where we become frustrated. I feel compassion for Newfoundlanders who sit there and watch Brigitte Bardot and other Europeans come over here and say: "No killing of seals, we can't allow that, this is a terrible disgraceful thing", the movies, the news items and all the rest of that. At the same time they will come over here and plunder our fish stocks. You say: "What a bunch of hypocritical you-know-whats".
We realize that presently the statistics show something like three million to four million seals are in the Atlantic coastal region. I am sure that you realize this, Mr. Speaker, but others do not. Those three million or four million seals are making about 300,000 baby seals every year and every one of those is a hungry mouth. We have all heard the statistics on how much they eat. We have an environmental problem there. I was thinking about that. It is just an aside but if we are going to deal with that and were to cull that herd, what are we going to do with the cull because we would have to cull probably 300,000 to
500,000	seals? Where are you going to put that cull? What are we going to do with it? We have got ourselves in a mess. We in Atlantic Canada have to be concerned. If the mess can occur in such a major resource as the northern cod stock, what can happen in the rest of Atlantic Canada, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence and the Bay of Fundy, areas that affect my riding?
I think we have to go back to square one to see if we can adopt a plan and take the necessary steps to have something that functions properly. We can talk and we can make suggestions and all the rest, but we have to try some things. Rather than saying it cannot be done and that we had better not attempt it, let us try some things.
We could take a look at the nose and tail. They say it cannot be done, therefore, we will just let it go. Why do we not opt in favour of doing something that may work, rather than giving up before we try? Why not extend our limits to include the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks?
We hear reports from our military as to how successful they were during the Persian Gulf war. What was their task in the Persian Gulf war? It was not to engage in combat as much as to verify and support the blockade of Iraq.
I think we should use those same initiatives and those same skills, because our Canadian troops were the best over there, to verify the overfishing and to prosecute, capture and bring to justice those people who break the law. We have the capabilities and the abilities to do that.
I will hear the arguments from the other side about gunboat diplomacy, et cetera. Maybe that is true. But I look at what happened with Iceland and Great Britain and when the Icelanders stood up and said: "Enough is enough and we are not going to put up with it any more", we knew who owned Icelandic cod. It was the Icelanders and not the people from Great Britain. They were a small nation and they took on the big nation and they came close to winning.
Therefore, we have to try the same thing. Rather than saying it cannot be done and there is no point in trying, let us try to do something to salvage this situation.
I know my time is going by quickly. I say to the people in Newfoundland that this is not the end of the world. This is a renewable resource. There are things that can be done. I am just very concerned about the management of this type of problem by this government.
We in Moncton faced a similar problem. We lost 1,500 jobs and this government's attitude was: "It is just a cyclical thing in the economy. It will go away. Do not worry about it". That is the attitude it seems to be taking in this particular matter.
We as parliamentarians in this place must send a message to the people of Newfoundland that we stand with them and that we are going to be there and support them all the day long, as they say, to make sure that they do not have the heartache, the stress and the impact on family life and all of those things that are associated with

February 19, 1992
the fact that they are out of work and the appearance is that they have no future.
Newfoundland will rise above this particular problem. We have to be there to help. That is the role of Canadians, That is the role of this place and that is what we are going to do.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to stand tonight as a member from Ontario to support my colleagues from Newfoundland and from Atlantic Canada in general.
We in this country have to realize that we as Canadians must stand together or we are going to hang separately. What we need in this country is a good dose of medicine called national pride, national meaningfulness. We are going to support our own to the same degree that other people who are taking advantage of us are supporting their own. But we will not go around stealing from our neighbours. That is what is happening in many issues in the fisheries today.
It is a lack of proper conduct on the part of the international community. A lot of it is coming about because there is no muscle in Canada to say: "You cannot do it".
If next week when the budget comes down there is a cut in the shipbuilding program, then this is a clear signal that we will not have the additional ships that we are going to need to guard our fisheries here in Canada.
I remember very well that in 1984 during the election campaign the present Prime Minister criss-crossed this country and said: "If you just give me a chance to be Prime Minister of Canada, if I just get there, I will guarantee that in a few years' time, you will not recognize Canada".
Little did we know how meaningful that statement really was. We wish he had kept his other promises as well as he has kept that one.
The importance of the fishing industry to the GDP of each Atlantic province in commodity producing industries in 1986 really impressed me: Newfoundland and Labrador, 20 per cent; Nova Scotia, 15.8 per cent; Prince
Edward Island, 15.9 per cent; New Brunswick, 5 per cent; and while the corresponding number for Quebec was less than 1 per cent, the industry is vital in the Gaspe and the north shore region of the St. Lawrence.
Tonight I listened to the member for Cardigan who delivered a very good speech on behalf of his home island of Prince Edward Island.
About 500,000 Atlantic Canadians live in 1,300 small fishing communities strung along thousands of miles of coastline. That last statement reminds me a great deal of the situation in northern Ontario and eastern Ontario where lumber is so important and where there are so many small communities. They too are in trouble.
There is proof, absolute proof here. I was amazed at some of the figures on the overfishing of the fisheries area around Newfoundland. It is sad that people around the world, with all the talk about the environment today, seem to have absolutely no respect for conservation.
Over the years of Canadian history there are three things that have been very important to the Canadian economy. One is fisheries. Far beyond the years of Confederation and right back to the early days of the first settlers, the fisheries were important.
The history books tell us of all the problems of the fisheries over the years. They were not problems necessarily on conservation but problems with foreign countries coming and taking the fish out, too many at one time.
Forestry was another main staple in the Canadian economy. This government has certainly fixed that industry today, too. It is in serious trouble.
The person who was responsible for undermining our forest industry, particularly softwood lumber, was rewarded by being appointed to the Senate. There was no fight there at that time, but worse still, there was no judgment in that case.
The third one was agriculture. Look what is happening to agriculture today. On Friday you will undoubtedly have the most farmers on Parliament Hill and in Ottawa than you have seen over the years of Canadian history.
February 19, 1992

That is because article XI of the GATT may be lost. If it is, the Liberal legislation that set up marketing boards in this country will be meaningless to farmers because they will lose their marketing boards. They will lose their milk quotas that they paid huge prices for over the years. It is a terrible issue for Canadian agriculture. Worse still, they talk about tariffication. We cannot put up tariffs against the United States to protect the farm industry in Canada. The Americans are going to come after us because of that insincere free trade agreement that we signed. They have been very insincere about it. We have all kinds of non-tariff barriers going up today.
The government is not fighting hard enough to protect the fisheries against intruders. It is not fighting hard enough to retain article XI of the GATT and hence save Canadian farm marketing boards and jobs in Atlantic Canada.
The government has not put into effect the necessary resolve to deal with those European countries that overfish in the Canadian Atlantic fisheries. Where is the Canadian resolve in dealing with the European community? It is failing in the farm discussions and it has failed in the-fisheries.
I would like to remind Europeans tonight that during World War II convoy after convoy of food was sent from this nation of Canada to feed the civilian population in free Europe and to feed the Canadian armies and other armies that were situated on British soil. It is time that these European countries for which many young Canadians risked their lives and lost their lives, both in the merchant navy as well as in the active forces during World War II, remember that Canadians sacrificed for them. The least they can do today is respect international law that involves Canada. That is all we ask. Surely it is not too much to ask people to live up to decent agreements in the world. Memories are short unfortunately, but history is long and history records the real facts of life.
The underlying problems of the fisheries catastrophe that we are discussing tonight must rest at the very heart of the present government. We have heard that they do not want to hear tell of gunboat diplomacy and so on. The present system is not working. We are not doing the work in the diplomatic areas that we should be doing.
Canada is not being respected. That message has to get through to the people who are not living up to the agreements with Canada, be they in fisheries, farm products or whatever.
These people have shown no respect for the Canadian government when discussing farm marketing boards. They show no respect for the Canadian government when discussing fisheries. We have a free trade agreement with the United States and what are we getting in return? All kinds of non-tariff barriers are thrown up.
It is time that we had a government in Canada that will fight for Canadians and not try to appease everybody in the world that is going to break international law and agreements with us.
We need a government that has some courage. We need a government that is willing to stand up on its feet and show some resolve, a government that means business when dealing with the international community. The day is over for a government that is too wimpish to take a strong stand on anything.
I just want to say that it is time not only to complain and march in Canada, but it is time to tell Europeans and others who are trespassing on the rights of this nation, on our sovereignty, to start abiding by agreements. It is time to make it plain to the world that they are not.
We did not pay the price in tens of thousands of lives of Canadians and in hard work in building this country only to sit back and be taken advantage of by other countries. From now on a national spirit in this country is needed that means resolve, determination, and play the game right.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I just wanted to say that there are two speakers left on this side of the House, myself and the member for Gander-Grand Falls. We will be taking our full period of 20 minutes each.
I want to start by saying that I compliment you, Mr. Speaker, for accepting on such short notice the request of my colleague, the member for Burin-St. George's, for an emergency debate on this issue. Your Honour has been sitting in the chair for many hours today. You have been here often during the last two and a half weeks and know that I have been promoting and advancing the idea

that on priority issues such as this we should take advantage of the time we are here in Ottawa when the House of Commons is sitting to extend the hours. I thank you, on behalf of all of us in this House and on behalf of all the people in our communities who want to know, when times are tough like this, that their members of Parliament are advancing debate in a constructive manner.
I must say that I believe the tone or tenor of debate tonight was the kind that many of my constituents would want to hear. Even though we tested the government or challenged the government tonight, there were positions put forward on both sides that I think should provide the beginning of some feeling of hope to Newfoundlanders, the people involved in the fishery. It is not only the fishery but people from all regions of the country. I mean, as the member for St. John's East said, direct and indirect employment is close to 25 per cent.
In my community of downtown Toronto losing 25 per cent of our employment is something beyond imagination. Our community could not function with an unemployment number that high. It is incumbent upon all of us to make sure that the government is seized with this issue and understands that the political will on this side of the House and on the government side as well is going to be there and is going to press the Prime Minister and the cabinet to act on this issue.
I could not help but reflect, as I was listening to the debate this evening, on what makes the leadership of this country, the Prime Minister, different from the previous Prime Minister who led this country, the Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau, a Prime Minister I had the honour and privilege of serving from 1980 to 1984 on his personal staff.
I tried to reflect, because we had times that were difficult in 1980, 1981 and 1982. We had a crisis in terms of the recession. It was one of the worst recessions that ever hit the world at that time. There are many differences between Prime Minister Trudeau and the present Prime Minister, but the one main difference is that Prime Minister Trudeau was a force in international affairs.
He was a force that was respected; he was a force that was admired and he was not afraid to take on the tough
issues. When I say that I am not trying to suggest that the current Prime Minister could not do some of the same. What I am suggesting is that he is not doing enough of it.
Here is a perfect example where the Prime Minister of Canada could take a page out of Pierre Elliott Trudeau's book and he could call up his chief of staff and say: "Get the JetStar ready. We are travelling to Spain. We are travelling to Portugal. We are travelling to wherever we have to go and we are going to put this case before the leadership of those countries that are causing this problem".
I am not suggesting that this is an easy task. I am not suggesting that the Prime Minister will score the first time or the second time that he does this, but he must try.
Right now, the foreign policy of this country is basically being influenced and directed from the forces of Washington. It has affected our entire economic policy. We got suckered into a poorly designed Free Trade Agreement and we continue to flounder in that area. In the process of trying to cope with that poorly designed Free Trade Agreement, our national spirit has dissipated.
When that national spirit dissipates, when it becomes a weakened spirit and there is a crisis like we have right now in Atlantic Canada, in Newfoundland specifically, do not think that the world forces do not see, do not smell our weakness. They do and they take advantage of it. They are taking advantage of it right now.
I just came back from the Middle East. I spent about 10 days in Syria and Amman, Jordan. The people in the Middle East have warm feelings toward Canada, but they wish that we would once again develop our own foreign policy. They wish that we would stop being a mirror image of the United States of America. This example of foreign overfishing is one of people ignoring the basic laws in relation to the environment.
I cannot believe that in this debate tonight we have not had the Minister of Environment here. This makes a mockery of the green plan, what is happening here in Atlantic Canada. This makes a mockery of some of the projects that we are involved in, in terms of Global '92, in Vancouver. This makes a mockery of our plan in Rio de Janeiro in June.
February 19, 1992

This is an environmental disaster equal to the oil disaster in the Persian Gulf.
I would like to know where Greenpeace is. What hypocrisy, Greenpeace. Where are all the non-governmental environmental organizations this week? Where are they? Are they intimidated by The Globe and Mail? I cannot believe it.
The priorities on this issue are upside down. This is not a regional issue this is not a national issue. This is an international issue. This is an international issue because we are custodians of that fishery, not only for our nation but for other nations on this planet. If we show a lack of will, a lack of fortitude, if we show an indifference toward the international environmental justice, if we show an indifference, what is the next stop? Is it going to be the Americans taking water out of the Great Lakes and we sitting back and just letting it happen?
Is it going to be something on the west coast where my friend must have concerns? There is west coast exposure in terms of the environment, in terms of sovereignty. My colleague for Cape Breton Highlands-Canso earlier in his speech this evening talked about sovereignty. This is an issue of sovereignty. Just because it is happening in a region of our country where it is not easy for the national media to get to it, it may not be as sexy for the national media.
We have to stop letting the national media control the agenda of this nation. We as members of Parliament have to control the agenda. We have to let our voice be heard, not only here in this House of Commons but we have to make sure it is heard in all the other international courts. If we let this issue rest, it is going to be the beginning of a series of advantages that other nations will take from our own sovereignty.
As a member from an urban riding from Toronto I am happy to have the opportunity to speak on this issue. There are close to 5,000 people in my community who are from Newfoundland. Many of them have parents and friends, aunts and uncles still living in Newfoundland and they expect my voice to be heard on this issue. Toronto, contrary to what many people will say, cares about this nation as a whole. Like Charlemagne once said to his son: "Give me one spear and I can break it
over my knee easily. Bring me ten together and I have strength". On this issue, all sides of this House must act together. We must encourage the Prime Minister of Canada to take a page out of Pierre Trudeau's book, get his foreign policy act together and start speaking for Canada, and leading Canada.
The people of Canada are saying there is a tremendous void of leadership in this country right now, that the Prime Minister is not leading, he is retreating. I say this without malice toward the Prime Minister but on this particular issue he needs a little nudge. He needs a little bit of a push and he needs to be told, in a very humble, direct way that it is time to fight for some international, economic and environmental justice.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will not be very long. It is pretty late and I am sure that a lot of people are a bit tired at this hour in the morning.
I suppose it is fitting that I have the last words on this emergency debate and, as I say, I will be very brief. It is fitting because I am the only member in the Chamber whose riding lies entirely in the middle of the northern cod stock zone.
My riding to the east has a community at the very end called Deadman's Bay and in the west a community called Nickey's Nose Cove. Those are the extremities of my riding and both of those communities are within the 3K fishing area on the map. The northern cod zones are 2J, 3K and 3L. I am the only member in this Chamber who has the privilege of having a riding so located and of having 13,000 licensed fishermen in his riding; not 100, but 13,000 who fish only the northern cod stock. They fish nothing else.
There are families who migrate during the summer, who take their children and put them on a boat and go up to the Labrador coast and spend the entire summer there in communities. One of the communities is called Punch Bowl. I do not suppose, Mr. Speaker, you know where Punch Bowl is, but everybody in the middle of my riding knows where Punch Bowl is. For the first time in the 18 years that I have represented those 13,000 fishermen, I had to arrange for welfare to bring them back, men, women and children, because there were no fish.

For the first time in 18 years I went down to a meeting in a place called Crow Head recently. It was in the month of December. There were 67 long linermen, crews, 67 vessels, and they did not have enough for unemployment insurance.
They had to arrange to go out and pick up rocks and garbage under the snow to get their stamps, their unemployment insurance stamps. This was a works program of the federal government for the best fishermen in the world, the longliner fleet.
The hon. member for Burin-St. George's who moved this motion in the House today knows exactly what I am talking about. In fact, he knows some of them personally. The greatest fishermen in the world were picking up rocks and garbage under the snow in order to get enough unemployment insurance to feed their families. It never, ever happened before in our history.
I want to restrict in my few remarks to only one thing. I am not going to talk about foreign overfishing outside. I am going to talk about something that the Government of Canada can do and do now. I am glad the parliamentary secretary is here. Next to the minister, he is the most powerful in the Government of Canada.
The 100 foreign vessels inside the 200-mile zone area licensed by Canada. Those people who believe that they do not have anything to do with the shortage of fish must believe that crew members on those 100 foreign vessels are suntanning.
The crew of 15 factory freezer trawlers from Cuba are around Newfoundland suntanning, because what else would they be doing? Playing bridge, or cards, or cribbage? Do they have an indoor pool? Their boats are big enough, they are 400 feet long. Do they go down and play video games? When you go inside the control room, it looks like Star Wars.
They are all at the television screens and they control their nets by remote control. The nets go down and around every bump in the ocean. They pick out the fish they want. Star Wars in the Atlantic Ocean.
Maybe they are playing video games for those people who do not believe that those vessels are harming the fishery. They must believe they are either getting a suntan or playing Pac-Man on the Atlantic Ocean.
I want to make just one brief reference to what the minister and the parliamentary secretary said. I noted it very clearly. They said: "The species of fish that foreign nations are catching legally"-these are the only people I am talking about, not the illegal ones-"are only catching it because we are not able to catch it or we are not interested in it".
I want to tell the minister and the parliamentary secretary that there is no such thing as an under-utilized species in the Atlantic Ocean today. The only under-utilized species in our ocean are our fishermen and fish plant workers. Those are the only underutilized species.
I will explain to the parliamentary secretary exactly what I am talking about. They are granting 100 licences to various nations. The hon. member knows the nations I am talking about: Cuba, the Soviet Union, Bulgaria to a certain degree, Norway, France, and so on.
These nations may not have quotas of cod in the northern cod zone, but I will tell you what they do have. They have quotas first of all for squid. The 401 for squid is off the province of Nova Scotia. Squid are bom in Florida and they die in Florida, the species that we have. They know where to go to die, don't they? When they are born they come up the coast of Canada and they pass to within 80 miles of southeastern Nova Scotia. It is there, the food supply of the cod. The squid we made so much money on in 1979. Men, women and children drawing squid, everybody was happy. Everybody had clothes to put on their backs to go back to school, everybody bought their books and shoes to go on their feet. They did not need welfare, they had squid. That squid is a restricted fishery in Canada today. I cannot get a licence to catch squid. A man on welfare cannot get it. A woman on welfare cannot get it. Not even a fisherman can get it unless he fished it previously for the last five years.
It is restricted, but Cuba has 15 factory freezer trawler licences this year to catch squid in our waters off Nova Scotia, right on the 401. The black line of squid come all the way up past Nova Scotia, go in around Cape Breton, on up the Quebec shore and New Brunswick, up around
February 19, 1992

Newfoundland and right back down to Florida and then they spawn and die.
We have not seen squid now since 1979. Is it not funny that Cuba and the Soviet Union with 25 factory freezer trawlers and scientific knowledge so accurate that the moment those squid are big enough to catch when they get inside our waters past Nova Scotia are there. The 25 of them are there and they put a barrier across the 401 and catch every squid that goes up there.
We do not see squid anymore. The hon. member can check with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and it will say that it is an under-utilized species. The poor man on my coast who cannot get a licence says: "Oh, yes, underutilized. Flow is that?" The minister stands up and he says: "But it is the law of the sea. We have to give anything in excess of Canada's needs". What is Canada? It is not National Sea Products Limited and Fisheries Products International. These are the people who are asked: "Do you want this squid quota"? The man trying to support his family is not asked.
The newspaper editor phones the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and is told: "Oh, no, this is in excess of Canada's needs". What does a newspaper editor here in central Canada know about the poor man and woman who cannot get a licence. The squid never reach our coast anymore.
It is the same with our capelin. We cannot get licences for capelin. It is a restricted fishery in Canada today. Only certain people can fish capelin and only in certain bays. You must have a certain size boat and you must have three in your crew. The Russians have 50,000 quota in my riding and Canada has 20,000. Capelin is the main food supply of the codfish.
If you were trying to catch a codfish out in the ocean-I have done it many times all my life-you would go out and you could put bubble gum on your hook and you would catch a codfish. Any child will tell you that. You could use a piece of cotton or something. However, the really good food is the squid and the capelin. Then if you had a piece of mackerel or herring just like a lobster.
Two years ago for the first time since the early 1970s Canada approved four factory freezer trawler licences for Bulgaria to fish-where? We have the biggest spawning area for mackerel in the world in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Since the Canso causeway was built in 1954
the mackerel cannot get in that way any more. They go through Sydney Bight at the end of May and spawn in June in the Gulf.
By September those fish are nine inches long and they go right up around the northern cod zone and they are eaten by cod fish. Lo and behold, who had the nets up? Bulgaria, compliments of the Government of Canada with a 30 per cent by-catch of herring, the largest by-catch our fishermen could ever have in our entire history since we joined Canada in 1949.1 can remember the day. The largest by-catch my people ever had was 10 per cent. Bulgaria had 30 per cent. When you look at the licences, everybody has 30 per cent if they are foreign. You have your capelin, squid, mackerel, and herring to a certain degree. What is the codfish supposed to eat in the northern cod zone? There is nothing left. They are scrawny. They are thin. They are not even spawning at seven years anymore.
One further point I want to make is this. I have done research since becoming a member of Parliament. I represent 13,000 full-time fishermen. When I say fulltime fishermen, I think twice about it because I think about all of those people out there who are part time or less than part time who are not allowed to get any of these licences that the foreign factory freezer trawlers have, none of these licences. Imagine, I have had fellows write to the Soviet Union and ask for a portion of their quota. Imagine. I sent a covering letter to the embassy here. We give them a portion of the quota in 3K in the northern cod zone. Of course the Soviet Union writes back and says no. Imagine, a Canadian asking the Soviet Union for a portion of his quota in the northern cod zone for capelin.
My point on the spawning is this. When you examine all of the scientific reports on spawning they are very interesting. It is interesting how a codfish spawns. A codfish takes about four weeks to spawn. Actually the male cod grumps for two weeks. You did not know that before, parliamentary secretary, but a codfish actually grumps prior to the two weeks spawning period. He selects his female. It is a very complex system. Just like your living room, he maps out this area, and he selects the female cod for two weeks. Then they spawn for two weeks. Every scientific study that has ever been done on the spawning of cod in captivity in incredibly large tanks and in bays show one thing. If you drop food down during

February 19, 1992
the courtship period or the spawning period, the codfish will go mad and they will collide with the sides of the tank or they will disappear. You cannot disturb them during their two week pre-spawning and during their two weeks of spawning. Who disturbs our codfish today on our spawning grounds?
Do you know that the policy of this country is that we are not certain? You speak to any scientist in Fisheries and Oceans and he will tell you that it is Canadian government policy to allow anybody to fish during a spawning period because we have never had a situation in Canada as long as they have studied cod when there has been no fishing during the spawning period. They cannot tell you whether it has any effect on the spawning of fish, that is allowing boats to fish in that area.
Who covers the main spawning areas of Canada during the spawning season, the Hamilton Banks, the Funk Island Banks? Ninety per cent of our spawning areas are inside the 200-mile zone. You know who covers it? It is those factory freezer trawlers. We do not have any factory freezer trawlers in Canada other than one. National Sea has one. Do not use it. A government fell in Atlantic Canada, I would say, when a fisheries minister approved factory freezer trawlers. We do not have one. Our boats are maximum size, 174 feet. Some of these foreign vessels are 400 feet long. These vessels go with their modem Star Wars gear through the very zones where codfish are trying to spawn during the spawning season.
So add two of those things together. You take away the food of the cod and you take away the privilege that codfish always had while the ice was in in February and March of being left alone, relatively apart from our own offshore fleet which is about 42 vessels, compared to the 100 from foreign nations we license to catch so-called underutilized species. Those are the vessels that disturb our spawning ground.
You add both of those things together. Yes, you can mention seals as the hon. member did. We have a law in Canada today. You are not allowed to get a sealing licence. I bet you did not know that.
The law was brought in by this minister of fisheries. There was no announcement made but you cannot get one for food. A man cannot get one for food, unless he had one for the past five years.
We are limiting Canadians, telling Canadians that you cannot do this and you cannot do that, saying for the sake of the law of the sea in excess of Canada's needs must be given to a foreign nation. It is funny. We are the only nation in the world that interprets the law of the sea that way.
We are not allowed to go within 200 miles of any nation in the world. Not one nation are we allowed to go within 200 miles and fish, even to put a hook over the side of a boat. We would be arrested. We are the only nation in the world that allows it.
The last one that stopped it was Namibia, that big powerful nation just north of South Africa. That small nation last November said: "We're not going to put up with this any more. We are not going to put up with the-

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext: One minute, the hon. member.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   FISHERIES SITUATION IN ATLANTIC CANADA
speechtext:
As I was saying, the vessels from Spain and Portugal that the hon. member who moved this motion from Burin-St. George's knows so well, 100 of them left the coast of Namibia and ended up off the hon. member's riding on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. That is where they ended up.
In conclusion let me say this. It is not very nice to have your constituents, full-time fishermen, unable to go out and fish. They look out in the water 12 miles off and see the flags of Japan and U.S.S.R. All these nations catching such things as Greenland halibut which we know as turbot. That is our mainstay but it is listed here as Greenland halibut by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, underutilized species. Our fishermen have fished it for hundreds of years. It is their mainstay. It is flatfish. Foreigners fishing; Canadians are not allowed to fish.
Anybody who believes that foreigners do not have anything to do-that is the legal ones now, the ones that are licensed; I am talking about my riding and the
February 19, 1992

northern cod stock- with the destruction of our cod stocks really believes that these foreigners in 100 large vessels are out there suntanning in the month of February.
